content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
Duelyst is a perfect mix between CCG and chess and probably one of the best strategy games I have ever played.You should definitely give it a shot If you like games like Hearthstone, Final Fantasy Tactics, Fire Emblem, or Advance Wars.It's EXTREMELY F2P-friendly. It turns out to be really rewarding since you get gold for pretty much everything.One good thing about it is that a very basic deck can get you started and boost you to the top of the ladder, as skill plays a bigger role than having good cards.In Duelyst you play on a board where you place creatures. In order to win, you need to kill your opponent's general while keeping yours alive.When playing this game you need to be smart, positioning is very important and it can win or lose you games. There are many ways to outplay your opponent and trust me, it feels darn good.The game lets you choose amongst 6 different Factions (or classes if you come from Hearthstone) which cover every archetype, and each faction has 2 different Generals (or hero powers in HS).It takes 5~10 games to actually understand how the game works, so I would suggest to read a bit about the game to learn the basics.Reddit is a good learning source where you can find some guides. I specially recommend watching the Kibler's and Mogwai's videos that you can find here:Reddit guidesThere are 4 game modes:Practice, where you can unlock the basic cards of each faction and get to know them.Ranked, where you can play against other players. There isn't a casual mode, but it's worth noting that once you reach a new tier (Silver, Gold, Diamond and S-Rank), you can't drop your rank and you get rewards at the end of the season, so it's worth it.Challenges, which are kind of puzzles where you need to defeat the enemy general in one turn. They are very helpful to learn the different mechanics and they give gold. I totally recommend doing them if you are a new player.Gauntlet, or draft mode. Similar to Hearthstone's arena.If you enjoy strategy games Duelyst will most likely hook you for a while. I totally recommend trying it atleast.Besides, the art and the OST is freaking amazing.By the way! If you are a new player maybe you want to use a referral code to get 100 gold for free. You can use it either when signing up, in your friend list or in the settings, BUT YOU NEED TO USE IT BEFORE PLAYING YOUR FIRST RANKED GAME.My referral code is "drakkenuvz". I mean, you get 100g and I get a Spirit Orb (card pack) if you reach Silver division. Sounds fair, right?Enjoy the game!

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												~ From someone who just started six hours before it was released on Steam. Read this in full if you need help on deciding whether or not to try this out. If the pixel art (or fear of P2W) is barring you from playing, I noted my experiences with it down below.I've been looking for an addictive game I can spend thousands on hours on for months and this is it. Historically, few games are able to hold my attention (Dota, League, CS:GO, Persona, Disgaea, Warframe, Trove) so this is a compliment of the highest order coming from me. Just for the record, I played 136 games in a span of 24 hours yesterday. If this isn't digital heroin, I don't know what is. Honestly, I've known of this game's existence for a year already. I'm not a diehard fan of card games but I do find that they have an innate quality of addiction so I've always been looking around for one. Hex, Infinity Wars, Spellweaver, Solforge, YGO, MTG, you name it, I've played it. Although there is an exception, I've never played Hearthstone and Faeria so I can't speak on how similar they are, I do suspect it is a vastly different experience though.The funny thing is, I only tried out this game out of desperation. While I'm a fan of Disgaea, Brigandine, Soul Nomad, Makai Kingdoms and other grid-based strategy games, the promotional material of this game led me to believe that the board is far too simplistic to be able to reproduce the same kind of feeling. So imagine my surprise. It doesn't quite play out like any of the aforementioned games but it is far from being dumbed down or otherwise. My first hour of playing against real people in this game, I instantly noticed how much thought was put into the design of this game. This ain't no joke, the effects, the balance are all really good. I got stomped multiple times for thinking I could just summon my monsters and rush straight to the other guy. No sir, it doesn't work like that.  Then there's the other reason, the art. The character portraits and the UI are modern and vivid. It oozes style, yet the in-game sprites are 8-bit-esque and really, really low resolution. That bothered me to no end and is the other core reason I forgoed trying this out initially. While the sprites are really, really done well, I'm not going to delude the both of us (if you're not a fan of low-res sprites as well) and say that I love it. I'm still not partial to it and it bothers me whenever I look at it but my dislike soon faded into the background as I clocked more and more hours in. A couple of dozens in, I barely notice it anymore. I still wish they went into full res sprites a la Disgaea's recent years, but for what we're given, it's more than good enough. Now, is the game P2W? As other reviews have noted, the  game is really, really generous to players without cash. Probably the most generous out of any card game out there. Furthermore, I've gone on really, really bad lose steaks but my losses were never about my opponent having better cards, it was about my own mistakes. Too many a time I was about to win a game but made one little mistake and lost. The basic and common cards are far from weak, you could hold your own all the way to Rank 10 (you start at 30) or even higher without even spending your in-game gold on a single booster. Even then, Duelyst allows you to craft cards for your ideal deck by disenchanting cards you have, so with a little bit of grind, you'll have it in no time.Those are my thoughts, of course, your mileage will inevitably vary but if what's holding you back from at the very least, trying out the game is the pixel art, fear of p2w or the simplistic looking gameplay, I can tell you without a doubt that you should try a few ladder games (or gauntlet games) before calling your judgement. If I helped you in taking the plunge in trying this game out, do use my referral code if you're feeling generous. You get 100 Gold and I get a pack and gold as you progress through the ladder. Referral Code is "cairus" which is the same as my in-game name. If you're going to use a referral code, remember to manually enter it under your account settings -> redeem referral because the other ways of claiming it are buggy at the moment. Add me if you ever try it out and we can maybe play some games or something. Also, play a game against a friend when go in (regardless of whether or not you used a referral code) to get a free booster pack. Should hang out in the Duelyst Discord Channel as well, they helped me a lot.

Posted: August 23, 2016
												I'm not a veteran CCG, strategy game or even a Duelyst player. I am however actively playing it for the past few months now and feel comfortable saying how I pretty much experienced all there is to it. And despite me usually not liking games of this sort, it still managed to get my attention. Here are some reasons why:- easy to learn, hard to master- new player friendly- game actively rewards you for playing- variety of competitive decks- low amounts of RNG- cards with higher rarity aren't necessarily better- high quality artwork and animations- devs communicate with players on almost daily basisNot to say the game is without its flaws though:- currently there is no casual game mode- some people will dislike the pixel art- certain interactions between mechanics aren't clear- UI could use some work- can feel grindy at timesAll in all, it's a very solid game with a team of passionate devs and community behind it. It's not particularly innovative, but it takes mechanics from various games and puts them together in a way that produces something amazing, familiar and yet different enough to have it's own identity.

												Duelyst is a fresh mix of Tactics-style games like the Final Fantasy Tactics Series or Fire Emblem and Collectible Card Games like Hearthstone. This game draws you in with its cunning finesse, gorgeous art style and fair game design.The free to play model works very well; you pay mostly for either cosmetics or to get cards quicker. There are daily quests which will keep you playing and currently there is an event where you can get a free Legendary skin and emotes. The developers are extending the game regurarly and communicate often with the fan base.All in all it's a highly fun and enjoyable game. I encourage you to check it out.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												(Don't let my hours on Steam fool you, I've been playing this game for months now.)Duelyst is a turn-based tactical CCG, with clearer inspiration from Hearthstone and board games rather than Magic: The Gathering. The true draw lies not only in the CCG gameplay and card collecting, but in the tactical board and movement system.The cards, factions and most of the mechanics are pretty standard for a digital CCG these days, but there's a good amount of mechanics which only work on the board setting. There's not much else I can say about the facts without parroting the store page, so I'll move onto my opinions now:The Good+Two patches per month, one for bugs and balance, and one for new cards.+Regular community communication. (Reddit, Forums and hopefully soon Steam.)+Reasonably quick balacing of problem cards.+Gameplay that makes you think at all times. Positioning and movement is extremely important.+More conistsent card draw and hand manipulation, making the game less about lucky draws and more about inevitability.+Counterplay throws free gold at you every day. It's not unrealistic to be able to buy a pack per day with just gold.+As a result, it's very easy to build up a card collection, a lot of Spirit (used to craft cards, like Hearthstone) and make a competitive deck.The Bad-Highly competitive ladder full of veteran CCG players. (Not great for newbies.)-While the business model for cards is good, the business model for cosmetics seems unreasonable. Emotes (small static images) shouldn't cost several dollars.-No card trading (like Hearthstone.)-Some frustrating (perhaps broken) mechanics that can make games frustrating, and make wins feel undeserved at times.-Cosmetic features that only exist because Hearthstone does them, and are very poorly executed, to the point of distraction/annoyance.-Due to recent events, I'll have to say that the devs have done a few things I can't agree with, such as lowering the amoutn of gold you get from a certain quest and then not adding it to the patch notes. Be catious in the future.Overall I'd say the game is great, and with every patch it just gets better. Recently they've improved cosmetic aquisition slightly and at the end of August they're releasing an expansion which comes packaged with a bunch of balance changes, as well as some truly unique new mechanics. You don't need to wait for the steam release to play this game, you can go to Counterplay's website and download the standalone client yourself if you're impatient.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
 Target Audience:   Anyone who likes Strategy.  Hours listed inaccurate, as I having played the game outside of Steam.  Note: Due to the stupidity of the reviewer and him making the review video a while ago, he got confused and indicated that he played a mobile version of the game. There is no mobile version of the game. It's upcoming. He's stupid. Summary:  Look, it's not Hearthstone, but when I say it's a Hearthstone Rival, I mean it's the kind of game that has the visual appeal and in-depth strategy that will draw people in, and want them to play match over and over again. And in all honestly, I prefer it over Hearthstone: as new players can easily be competitive against other players, and there's really a lot of strong strategies that can be created, even within a specific hero type. Strategy is actually key here, and playing to your heroes strengths is important, but being willing to go outside his comfort zone can give you a needed edge in battle. There's a lot to learn here, but some good challenge and tutorials help this out. And unlike other F2P games, I never felt that I was at a significant disadvantage if I didn't go and pay for cards. Granted, there are some powerful cards, but the synergy with some of the base cards you get can overshadow them, to the point where it really does feel like your skill with the game overcomes everything else. Look, it's free 2 play, and it's one of the best strategy games of its type, so there's absolutely no reason not to try it. Just be aware that you may get addicted to it. Video Review:  


YouTube™ Video: Duelyst (Critical Eye): Hearthstone Rival 

			Views: 1,159		

			Duelyst may have the power to replace Hearthstone if given the proper chance. I've said before that I think Hearthstone isn't that good, and I've been waiting for some good strategy CCG that could...		

 Lists: Positives: Strategy is placed over everything else: focusing on the chess match between the two players, and not necessarily whose got the best cards. Great cards are good, but they mean nothing if you can't really use them in combination with others. Lots of depth. Can really play around with different strategies, and the game takes a while to exhaust you.  Online play never gave me problems. Quick to find a match, quick to play, and the times to wait/strategize seem right on.  Knowing your opponent is rather important. Knowing what they could pull out so you could deal with them, and rewarded predicting what an oppponent could pull. .  All the different heroes have different archtypes that really play to different strengths, and make them feel very unique in the long run.  Definitely not a pay to win scenario here. Never felt any need to grab more cards because well, it feels like balance. Factions are well balanced.  Replace feature is nice to keep things fresh on the strategy element. Makes things a lot more dynamic.   Great designs.  Strong visual pixel aesthetic that has fluid animations, and makes the characters come to life. Unlike other pixel games, this one feels appropriate.Negatives: Provoke seems overpowered to me, even when I take a step back after the video was created. I think its just too useful in the long run. There's a LOT to learn. A lot.  Gold earning could be a tiny bit easier in the early game.  Honestly, it's a game that's just going to be better on mobile. Not because the PC implementation is bad or  anything, it's just nicer to pick up a game where ever you want to. It's that kind of game. UI does have too much open space. It's addictive. I know that may not seem like a negative, but this is to warn people that yes, you can get lost playing this game, and if you want to avoid that, well, avoid the game.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												Pros:1. The board element of the game creates tactically significant choices, because good players can play around cards depending on the correct positioning of minions and their general, and bad players can play into cards through bad positioning.2. The replace mechanic (you can put one card from your hand back into your deck and draw another card each turn) rewards players who know the cards in their deck and what the curve of their deck is most likely to draw. So, a good player can know how likely it is to draw an answer to a problematic situation on the board and make the optimal play accordingly.3. There is a diverse amount of similar power level cards (for their mana cost) that results in greater deck variety than other CCGs, and Counterplay has stated their goal (in a podcast) is to make the gap between the power level of cards as narrow as possible, so this trend is likely to continue.4. The game has challenges that act as tutorials for learning the mechanics of the game; I think these are very helpful for new players, and the challenges give new players gold. 5. Games are saved as replays in the match history, which lets players go over their turns and analyze their mistakes. Also, your friends can view your replays in order to give you advice on what to improve, or just enjoy a funny game that you played.6. Similar to your own replays, you can watch replays of ladder matches from the various divisions (bronze, silver, gold, diamond, and S-rank) in order to learn from other players, and streamers that are pillars of the community -- most of the time -- show up in that section: "Watch."7. This game is not pay-to-win because I have seen many, many free-to-play players make it to S-rank (the highest league in Duelyst). Pick your favorite faction and play.Cons:1. The pixel art style is disliked by some, and some parts of the UI doesn't fit into the pixel art style. The most recent example of this is the screen where spirit orbs (packs) are opened; it is smoothly metallic and shiny and doesn't fit with the pixel art of the cards. Perhaps Counterplay is trying to appease people who dislike the pixel art style, but I would prefer a unified art direction, personally.2. Each faction has access to two generals that have 1 mana (blood born) spells that they can use after the early stages of the game (similar to hero abilities in Hearthstone). The game is not properly balanced around some general's blood born spells (bbs), especially a general named Kara: Kara's bbs is that she buffs every minion in her action bar by 1+/1+ for 1 mana. Oftentimes this results in a 5+/5+ buff over 5 minions for 1 mana, which is clearly stronger than a lot of other bbs's. This balance issue won't affect new players -- really , because playing bad cards and misplaying are the primary factors for new players losing, but at the highest level of play, Kara reigns supreme. I expect balance fixes to Kara and others in the upcoming expansion on Aug. 31th, however.3. It does take a bit of grinding to unlock all the basic cards and generals once you start playing. This wouldn't be problematic for a player who wants to familiarize themselves with all the different factions before deciding what to play, but some new players may want to have a deck with a particular locked general with all the basic cards, so that they can jump right into ranked.4. There isn't an unranked mode; only practice (against the AI), ranked, or gauntlet (which is the draft mode). 5. For tournament play, you need to be friends with your opponent in order to challenge them to a match (no in-game tournament system, as yet), allowing them to potentially watch your replays or view your match history, in order to gain information about what you're likely to play. 6. The battlelog that keeps track of what cards have been played doesn't keep track of what card was replaced, which is important when viewing a replay, since replaces happen quickly on the screen, and it's sometimes hard to tell what card was replaced.Conclusion:Overall, if the art style isn't a deal breaker for you, and you can be patient while unlocking the basic cards and generals, and you can accept that no card game is perfectly balanced (and the balance is far from abysmal in Duelyst), and you don't care that there isn't an unranked mode, then Duelyst is an enjoyable experience that I would recommend.

Posted: December 23, 2016
												I've played TCGs and CCGs for a good part of my life, mostly MTG and I've never found a game I've enjoyed more until this. Duelyst combines great pixel-art, which classic card mechanics in a square grid who adds a whole other layer into the gameplay. The only problem is, as with most card games, the lack of cards for new players, even if Duelyst does have so much better rarity ratios than other digital games and a bunch of methods of getting gold when you start (bunch of hidden quests, challenges and also dailies) AND very great deals (buyings orbs + legendaries for 5 USD, last complete expansion costs 20 USD or 3900 gold which is less than a month of doing all daily quests) you might feel overpowered once you rank up and make progress if you stay F2P for a while. But don't panic, give it a try, keep playing, participate in the free events over battelfy (some with orb and other prizes that CounterPlay gives) and your collection will grow in no time!

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Don't let my playtime fool you, I've easily put over 500 hours into DUELYST since I got into the alpha back in 2014. The game has changed so much since then; Counterplay games has done an amazing job creating your new favorite CCG.Some things that set DUELYST apart from the rest:- Replace! Once per turn, you can shuffle a card back into your deck and be guaranteed to draw a different card.- Very generous economy! You can easily earn a pack of cards daily and drop rates for legendary and epic cards are much higher than other CCGs.- Depth of Deckbuilding! There are so many crazy deck ideas, and while they may not all be 100% competitively viable, it's fun to build and play decks with interesting synergies.- Monthly cards! Four new cards added to the game each month. You can even win copies of the cards based on your ladder placement for the month.- Daily Puzzle Challenge! Earn a bit of gold while learning about interesting card interactions. I've been playing for almost 2 years and some of the puzzles still take me a while to figure out :P- Responsive Developers! Counterplay has been relatively quick to address problem cards. And if cards get changed, you can disenchante them for full value.This is just a small list of things that have kept me playing this game for so long. The pixel art is gorgeous, the gameplay is quick but still tactical and the developers continue to improve the game with new features and content.There is a new expansion coming at the end of the month, so this is a perfect time for new players to begin!See you on the battlefield!

												I'm pretty torn as far as what I think about the game. The gameplay, art style and thematics are fantastic. I am enjoying it but as with most F2P games I have an extremely hard time wanting to buy into the monetization scheme. I find that the pricing is just too rich for my tastes. A purchase of 40 card packs for $50.00 is a fairly big price to pay, especially when there's no guarantee that you'll obtain the 'content' that you might be looking for. Furthermore, trying to price at the same levels as Hearthstone seems to be a poor strategy as being a direct competitor this game has no where near the same following.  I think that the devs could attract a lot more interest if they aggressively priced things lower in order to attract more users but I can't see it happening.

content:
Posted: March 16
												I can't recommend this game anymore. While the game's depth and tactical gameplay and fantastic art initially drew me in, the game falls apart at higher levels of play. Optimized decks focus around powerful minions with immediate impact (like Rush cards, who don't have to wait a turn to attack) and removal cards. The Vanar faction in particular specializes in dispelling/transforming/removing every single card the opponent plays. Do not be fooled by the screenshots on the store page showcasing complex board states with multiple minions in formation.The developers seemingly have no issue with the design of the game revolving around "Answer-or-die" threats kept only in check by cheap removal cards, having just printed an expansion featuring more of both.Steer clear.

content:
Posted: April 5
												Dueylst is a pretty entertaining card-game with wonderfully done art and character design, as well as an intricate story and lore-filled world found in various scripts on cards. That being said; the gameplay WAS fun. Now its just an awful contest to see who kills the other the fastest using  horribly unbalanced cards and spells, And of course, countering such with the same spells/minions to save their hides. Of course you have to be lucky in order to have these cards in your hand because otherwise you are just going to spend the game prolonging your slow defeat. This basic strategy is of course viable in every deck; However, the Vanar are the living embodiement of this. All of their cards/spells are centered around dumping impecable amounts of dps on the battlefield, all the while disabling anything that could possibly save you..... Quite a problem indeed.All of this could be remedied by tweaks in gameplay mechanics and nerfing  stupendiously overpowered cards so all the other wonderful and creative decks could actually be enjoyable to play. HOWEVER the devs seemingly prefer to simply pump out packs and even more packs absolutely brimming with cards more powerful and abusable than the last. Thus the problem that now plagues this game. It's rather irksome and so i can't bring myself to reccomend this game to anyone, but it is a free game afterall, and you can tell much effort has been put into the design. In the end, the decision is yours to like or hate this game. Let my review be a warning, not something to inherently change your mind.Tldr; Game has wonderful art but major balancing issues.

Posted: September 26, 2016
												!!!!MAKE SURE TO GET THE FREE 20 CARD PACKS AND COSMETICS FROM HUMBLE BUNDLE!!!!! Edit: Note they stopped giving away the code now, but they can be  redeemed until nov 17. Try finding a code from the internetThe first thing anyone does with a online card gamae is compare it to hearthstone. That is understandable as blizzard filled the hunger for online card games that many developers ignored. However many people, as well as I felt Heartstone was bland and unfufilling. The art style was too main stream, the omni prescint RNG was frustrating, the game never felt truly like a card game ( Yu-gi-oh or MTG), and I always felt like Hearthstone was trying to milk me for money because it was too unrewarding being a free player.Duelyst improves on many aspects on Hearthstone. There is more strategey in Duelyst due to a implementation of a chess board which gives a whole dimension on positioning your cards and utilizing cards to affect your opponents positioning. This positioning allows for a larger variety of card effects than what hearthstone allows. There backstab cards which deal additonal damage and receive no damage when attacking the back of a creature, there are cards which move your creatures and the opposing players creatures around. Flying cards can move to any space in the board which can ♥♥♥♥ up if you have on weaksauce card that is essential to your strategey and don't protect it with other cards.You can also shuffle one  card into your deck and draw a new card every turn, allowing card drawing cards to be less powerful than traditional card games. There are are at least two very obvious strategies for each class, with many less obvious ones as well, but that might require looking for decklists online. There are 6 classses, with two different hero powers you can choose, each one powerful in its own way.I have not felt punished for being a free player. Fifteen gold is gained every two wins on top of the daily quests and hidden acheivments. The Gauntlet is not as punishing as hearthstone arena, in hearthstone if you went 0-3 you would get 5 gold or so awarded. When i went 0-3 I got 15 gold. You also get legendary cards much more frequently than in hearthstone, I have gotten a legendary in at least every 5 packs.The art style is vibrant pixel art which is a pleasure to view.!!!MAKE SURE TO GET THE FREE 20 CARD PACKS AND COSMETICS FROM HUMBLE BUNDLE!!!Use the referral code "opensheep" so you gain 100 gold starting out, people don't actually get gold for referring people unless they reach silver/gold rank in solo que. Which could take quite a while. So don't think I'm trying to milk you.I also made a steam group, which you may want to join if you want advice or friends to play with! Additonally I will organize tournaments in the future.

content:
Posted: April 5
												Firstly a few credentials. I reached high diamond (highest rank behind S-rank) about 3-4 times and was extremely active on the forums during the games beta. I played many, many hours on the standalone client so my game time should not be taken at face valueThis game used to be strategic and fun, with board control counting for most wins, now it has changed into a swingy, aggro fest which is decided by luck in the first few turns. The power creep has made killing your opponent before they can react the prime strategy which is uninteractive to say the least. The game is also now behind a paywall, with 2 sets in exclusive, high cost orbs that unlock a pitiful amount of cards and require hours of grinding. This game takes all bad aspects of the frontrunner, Hearthstone and multiplies them by 10xDevs also cannot seem to find a good balance, with massive card changes often, upsetting the meta and rendering most of your decks useless, making it hard to build faction identity and loyalty with its players.The developer actually scrapped the forums for a long period of time because they could not handle community outcry at some of their decisions, if that isn't telling enough then I don't know what is.Aviod, check out other great f2p cardgames that have sprung up all over the show.

content:
Posted: February 4
												When it comes to Duelyst, the comparison with Hearthstone is easily made. The way you earn cards is the same, the ranked system is the same, the mana system is the same and the way classes work is the same, complete with special power.However, there's a few very key differences between the two games that make Duelyst less random and, to me at least, more fun: The board on which you play as well as the ability to replace a card from your hand once per turn.The board in combination with the various cards makes for some really deep and satisfying tactical play that allows you to bend the game to your favour with smart decisions. Every turn the board looks different as there's so much going on and every turn has a very large amount of decisions that you can make. I really enjoy this the most as a fervent tactical turn-based gamer. If you like the combat in XCOM and Age of Wonders 3, you will find lots to love here.Other plusses are the quick matchmaking, the active developers, the gorgeous pixel art and animations and the large amount of interesting lore.I am personally not a fan of random stuff (which is why I stopped playing Hearthstone) and to me Duelyst strikes the perfect balance between randomness and tactics. Highly recommended!

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Card game with two major layers of strategy. There's the bog standard Magic: The Gathering* gameplay that leads into the  2nd layer of gameplay with the placement and movement of your cards on a battlefield. The added depth means skill can trump raw card power; however while learning the game you will end up getting crushed under raw power this is part of the learning process. Once you start to get a card base going and you learn the different faction styles/cards the game truely opens up.Duelyst hits the sweet spots of collecting sweet cards while tinkering with decks. The duels themselves become more involved with the added complexity of positioning over simple attack and block. If you're willing to sink some time into Duelyst you'll be rewarded with a compelling and fulfilling experience.*Instead of a land system used in Magic, Duelyst has set mana that increases each turn.

content:
Posted: February 16
												Abosultely love this game! The strategy needed due to the infinite possibilities between the game board, placement of "cards", and of course the kick @$$ pixel graphics!!  A very satisfying game that could easily be played and enjoyed without spending a penny of "real money".  The daily quests (and free card) can get you enough gold to buy spirit orbs (card packs), gauntlet tickets (arena/draft play) and bloodborn orbs (card packs with cards you DONT have!).  Yes, if you get a crate you need a key to open it which costs $4.99.. BUT they did recently implement a "common crate" key reward for 15 quests completed in a month (easy).  However, if you are worried that you will be missing out on items due to not wanting to buy crates they are mostly filled with cosmetic items with 1 card here and there so they are not required to complete your card collection. The last thing I want to touch on, which is one of my favorites, is the fact that each "faction" or class does not only have 1 type of general that has the same hero power no matter the skin or avatar.  There are multiple general (main hero/"face") options for each faction AND your general always has at least 2 attack and can  move around the board like a chess piece, the same as your minions, instead of just being your avatar with a set power that never moves or defends themself without a weapon equipped.To get the FULL experience and really find out I suggest you JUST PLAY IT.  Nothing to lose since it is F2P, the system requirements are low, and if you want to get a free spirit orb (or just 100 gold) use my referral code "gdaddanyt" and friend me to play some matches!! :)

number of helpful: 14 of 17 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												I've been playing this game for quite some time. I like it and recommend it to anyone who enjoys card games.WARNING: I will compare Duelyst with Hearthstone quite a bit. The reason, is because it has some key similarites to Hearthstone but there are a few things, that in my opinion, make this game slightly better.Compared with Hearthstone:- Importance of proper positioning. I know Hearthstone has positioning as well but having a board makes positioning even more important.- Better access for F2P players. I'm sorry but my biggest issue with Hearthstone is that you have to WIN games to complete your daily quests. Duelyst only requires you to PLAY games. They give you slightly less gold but it is still worth it. I've earned a lot of free booster packs just completing daily quests.- Better first turns. In my opinion, Hearthstones first few turns can be slow. Duelyst generally starts off with interesting situations and it feels like the game actually starts when you start playing.- Better disenchanting rates. Last I checked, it only takes 4 commons to craft a new common. In Hearthstone I think it takes 8.Other pros that have nothing to do with Hearthstone:- Great little pixel art animations. Really, if you enjoy pixel art you might give this game a go just to enjoy the pixel art for a few games.- Fun daily challenges.- Great faction variety.- Lovely character concept art.Cons:- No unranked mode. When you play other people (outside of friend battles and gauntlet) it is always ranked.- Crate system. I guess I don't mind getting their loot crates but at least let me remove the stupid notifications about them. Or let me delete them.There are my thoughts. Honestly, I'm rather addicted to this game. It has been one of the funnest games for me to play in my down-time and I enjoy the fact that I get a new challenge every game, and can play without having to dedicate hours and hours of my time to get anything out of it. 20-30 minutes can give you a couple decent games.If you want to add me, my username is Torrid.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
												I've been in love with TCG/CCGs since I began playing at the age of 8 with my big brother and his friends. 20 years later I was lucky enough to find Duelyst. Some of my favorites growing up have been Netrunner and Magic the Gathering. Recently, while scrolling through my Steam 'recommend for you' section, I came across Duelyst.I was immediately drawn to the pixel art sprites. The beautiful high res and pixel art graphics blend really works here. Stunning visuals, music and sfx. Really well put together aesthetically, so gorgeous.Duelyst gives the player so many choices to make. Things I particularly love in terms of game play are replacing cards each turn, the great big board, the neutral cards, the ability to place and move cards/units around the board really pushes you to think and plan ahead that much more. The factions are awesome, each comes with different play styles and each can be tweaked to create new play styles. With such a massive variety of card types, through archetype decks and neutral cards you can really custom craft your deck. The 'luck of the draw' element is still always present in Duelyst, thanks to the card replacement mechanic. You can completely switch up the game with one replacement or you can draw a garbage card and headbutt the keyboard as you have your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you. Duelyst is FREE TO PLAY. This is one of the best free to pay games I've ever played, of any genre. I am happy to have put some cash into the game for some booster packs(orbs). The developers have produced something so special I'm currently at just over 30 play hours, I've not been playing competitive for long as I wanted to fully understand the different archetype decks. Another thing I should mention - When I've played with friends or online I've pretty much had the stuffing kicked out of me. I was not as prepared as I thought. But I had a ball, even when I lose, games are so varied and fun. The community around Duelyst seem to be really fun and laid back, I'm not seeing any snippy remarks or arrogance. I'd like to thank Counterplay Games, you guys absolutely smashed it. I really hope player numbers will continue to grow, please support the developers to keep adding additional content. I know I will.Come and join our Facebook fan group, we'll be hosting tournaments with awesome prizes.https://www.facebook.com/groups/2079880545571034/

content:
Posted: April 16
												Not going to lie, this game can be extremely fun to play. Yet I won't recommend this game because of its absurd pay-wall tactics. I get it, it is a free to play game, and I understand the system. I am perfectly fine with having a system where someone with a heavy wallet can shell out a few bucks (or a bunch) to buy cards/cosmetics/ect. Yet the way this game makes you think you are going to get a "reward" and then hide it behind a pay-wall is very deceptive.I just completed the special PVE boss event, which proclaims from the main menu that you get a unique reward upon completion. Spent at least an hour customizing my deck until I could defeat it. What reward do I get? A boss crate that can't even be opened unless I shell out an extra $4.99 for a boss crate key. This only adds to my collection of "rare" crates that I can't open because the only keys a free-to-play account can get are common crate keys (afaik).Basically, the "rewards" the game gives to their dedicated FTP playerbase can't even be opened without spending money. Just another fun game ruined by a bad business model.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												This is a very different game to other card games so those who are put off by what they assume it is should realise that it is a lot more focussed on tactical combat than it is on spamming cards onto a board. In fact the differing factions and units are so diverse that play can be almost chess-like at times. It also has an interesting back story in the codex but this does not appear to have any tangible effect other than telling a slightly confusing story. It isn't perfect but it is certainly accomplished. If, like me, you are not a fan of pixel graphics then it will take a little getting used to but what is more important is the depth of strategy and the way the ftp model is (currently) very fair. For these two reasons alone it is well worth a look and likely to be worth persevering with. Yet it is primarilly intended as a multiplayer game so anyone looking for a single player experience should look elsewhere.*edit* I should also mention that on the rare occurance of a technical fault it is fixed extremely quickly and matchmaking is always very quick with no dcs.

number of helpful: 14 of 19 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												I loved Final Fantasy Tactics. I loved Hearthstone. I used to play Magic: TG competitively.This, no matter what it is being called, is none of those things. It steals ideas from all of those things, sure, but as a cohesive package? It has no original identity of its own, just the cobbled together parts of other, better things. However, it does these things so well that I can't help but enjoy it as more than the sum of its (somewhat) stolen mechanics. It's greatly enjoyable. I don't know what is so compelling about it, but despite my initially negative impressions, I find myself wanting to dig in to it more. In today's flooded market that is saying something rather impressive.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												Duelyst is a card game and tactics hybrid where you create a deck of units and spells and then play them out against your opponent on a tile based board. What I especially liked about this game was the movement and positioning that are required for the tactics portion of the game. Due to this a number of my really good matches were won through careful choices, calculated risks and proper strategic positioning of units rather than luck of the draw. That isn't to say luck of the draw doesn't happen given the card game nature of the game, but I've felt less of my matches came down to this than it did my opponent or myself playing well. I really enjoyed my time with Duelyst and am quite glad I gave it a shot despite it being F2P.

 REVIEW UPDATED 5 MARCH 2017 This game is a big YES for all TCG + Strategy fans out there! Pros:  HUGE CARD SELECTION (6 Faction + 1 Neutral) 6 Faction with each 2 general and different playstyle which mean there is so many cards to collect and absolutely infinite possibilities of card combo that will hook you to create more decks to play! Easy Grinding For someone who afraid to get into this game because you guys think that its gonna be grindy to collect card without dropping some money, YOU GUYS ARE WRONG! Duelyst have a quest which give gold (currency to buy spirit orbs). 2 Quest each give 20G and 50G + First win of the day 20G + 3 Win 15G = 105 Gold each day. With that you can buy 1 spirit orb. Also Duelyst daily free card make it easier for you to collect cards. For new player they can finish Solo Challenges to get gold and for a boost you can use my REFFERAL code to get 100G: yeahjah Strategic Gameplay With the gameplay using card to summon your unit / cast a spell into the game board makes the gameplay more strategic. Using the combination of that and positioning you try to outplay your enemy and winning the game. Also there is mana system to limit the card summoning which make the user think twice about summoning the card, whether he/she should summon this or that card.  6 Gamemodes -Practice: Play versus AI to test your deck or train your skill.-Season Ladder: Compete against other player to climb up rank (monthly) and earn prizes at the end of season depending on your rank.-Solo Challenges: Learn gameplay mechanics and earn reward.-The Gauntlet: Draft mode. Get as many win as possible until you lose 3 times and earn reward based on how much you win.-Friendly Match: Play against your friend.-Boss Battle: Fight AI Boss with unique mechanic. Graphic This game has its own pixelart style which make its looks kinda unique than any other similar games. Good Community The community in this game is pretty good. They act and speak good, and eventually will help other players. Active Events Beside the good community, this game also have an active events. From tournament to other events that you can see here:  Duelyst Events [news.duelyst.com] Lore/Story included Its not just about the game! There is also story in it. Explore the amazing lore of Duelyst from beginning to upcoming lore to be explained. (10 Chapter + more to come) Cons: ----------------------- Closing Overall, this game is a must if you are TCG + Strategy fans!!Also, to get a head start of 100 Gold use my refferal code: yeahjahHope to see you in a match! :D

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												For those that love card cames like Magic and Hearthstone, this game is definitely for you. Whilst keeping with the traditional mana system and the easy to learn attack/defence mechanics, the new addition of a board to traverse, rather than just sides with cards, brings a huge new element of strategy into every game. Not only will you be trying set up card combos to try and take down the enemy, you must think about positioning and movement tactics to gain the upper hand in every battle, allowing for large amounts of variety in each match. This also allows decks to not be held up to one strategy, as simply moving a single minion can completely allow for a new strategy.This game is truly one of those, easy to learn, hard to master types of games, and with it being free, there is really no reason to try it out for yourself.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
Highly-polished collectable card game with a twist of Grid-based-Strategy-RPG, tons of cards to collect, and awesome pixel-art animated graphics.Tip for new players: Use my referral code losingstreak to get 100 free gold. Just click "Friends" on the bottom-right corner of the main menu, click on "claim a friend's referral code" and input losingstreak to get your 100 free gold. (only applicable if you have not yet played ranked/ladder)Pros and cons:Pros:+Not P2W: Gold is pretty easy to earn, making it fairly easy to advance and make a competitive deck without purchasing using real money+Six factions to play that each have their own unique strategies and skills +Lots of faction cards that are unique to their faction and tons of non-faction-specific neutral cards add a lot of variety and depth to deck-making+Draft mode that gives good rewards even if you don't get far (similar to Arena in Hearthstone, but less punishing)+Much less RNG than Hearthstone (if you hate Yogg, you'll like this one)+Good music and awesome pixel-art animated graphics+Can reconnect if you disconnect mid-match; just don't take too long or the game will automatically concede for youCons:-Games can drag on especially if the enemy is turtling or roping-Cannot chat with other players in a match, you can only use preset emotes and quotesBonus Tips for free stuff:~Duel with a friend to get a one-time-only free pack~Play with each faction atleast once to get a free random-faction legendary card

number of helpful: 43 of 77 people (56%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												Hopefully someone will see this and read it before spending money on the game.  On the surface it is a great game, there appear to be layers of strategy and mechanics that attempt to minimize RNG and coming from HS that is just huge.  After a few hours playing the game you begin to realize that is mostly just smoke and mirrors though.  The draw of the "board" and interaction between the different mechanics starts to fade into the background as you realize the designers for all of their apparent good intent don't have a terribly solid grasp of card game design.  As of now in the post expansion meta there are 4 different decks that can reliably put 14+ damage on your life total out of hand with no real way to counter it.  The worst offender is Songhia, the so called meld deck is just like playing against miracle rogue back in the early days of HS.  Not only can they just win without any input from you(no, positioning tricks and praying RNG puts the second boar in a bad spot does not count, at all) even if they don't win the match is incredibly boring.  There are other examples of poor design that is rapidly leading to a stale and boring meta devoid of any fun what so ever but I think the worst example is the best and will leave it at that.  I struggle to find positives about this game but for the sake of fairness I will say the art is great, really tickles that pixel itch you may or mat not get on occasion.I really wanted to like this game and I hope they will go back to the drawing board on at least most of these issues but I don't see that happening any time soon.  So for now it is a very sad thumbs down from me.Update 11/6/16So, they did a balance pass.  One of the big ones was they nerfed a card that everyone has access to and can be played around, and didn't touch the insane out of hand damage half the factions are capable of.  I have a theory the out of hand damage (ei, the damage you can not stop or interact with at all) was such a bedrock of the game core that altering it or taking it out would destroy any ability the devs have to push the game forward and as a result they aren't doing anything at all.  At this point any faith I had that things would be fixed or get better are gone.Note this review and update are here because at one point I thought the game had a lot of potential to be something special in the otherwise god awful electronic CCG market.  But turns out it isn't.  So please, avoid this thing and if you do decide to try it out (after all it starts out free) please do not spend a dime on it.  Learn from my mistake.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Oh man… What to say about Duelyst…Quick background/ context for this review. My ign is JuveyD, I’ve been playing for 5 months. I have casted several tournaments, achieved S-Rank three times, and my peak position on the ladder with 18th.I’ll start with the basic +/-‘s of the game, and then get in to what I think makes this game SO unique.+ Not pay to win. PLENTY of people have gotten to S-Rank (the top rank) with “budget decks.” Basically, decks that you can make with cards that are easy to acquire. You can get packs (also known as spirit orbs) pretty easily at the start to build up your collection.+ The artwork. If you enjoy pixel art, you’re about your mind. Even if you don’t, there is still a really good chance this will impress you. The expansion in a week will introduce 105 new cards to the 300+ collection. Every month the developers release four new cards as ladder rewards.+ Rewarding skill. A lot of card games (i.e. Hearthstone) seem to rely on a fair bit of RNG. There is nothing wrong with that to some people, but a lot of people want a game that is more reliant on skill. This is still a card game, so luck plays a part. But cycling through decks is easier because of the replace feature, my next +. + The replace feature. This is such a big deal to me, because I have never seen anything like it. At the start of every turn, you can replace one card from your hand to draw another card from your deck. This lowers the RNG factor, and increases the amount of skill/ thought that goes into each turn.+ The community. These are just good people. It isn’t hard to get to know people. There are dedicated Discord servers like Duelyst Official, the official tournament channel, and several other personal channels for streamers and other game-related events. I would HIGHLY encourage joining some of these and meeting the people who play the game. A ton of them (myself included) are willing to teach new players the ropes. ALSO, JOIN TOURNAMENTS! I think there are other positives to the game, but I don’t want to ramble/ overpraise the game. If anything above sounds appealing, then you should download it and give it a shot. If you want the negative side, here are the few things I’ll say:- You WILL lose at first. Whether it be the learning curve, or the fact that someone spent money and draws several legendary cards in a game against you. It is easy to blame this on RNG or the fact that it feels “pay to win.” But you CAN beat those expensive decks. The nature of this game is that most players float around a 40-60% win rate. This has to be something you’re okay with during your first week of playing.- After the first week, grinding for decks gets a little tiring, imo. The first week you unlock packs for doing things like challenging friends, leveling up factions, etc. After you get those 10ish packs, you need to save up gold and do gauntlet runs. This can be a bit daunting to some. I’d advise watching some streams or YouTube videos to help guide you through that process.Anyways, that’s my review. I’m bias because this is probably my favorite online game of all time and I’m very happy to see it come to Steam. I give it a 10/10 and HIGHLY recommend it. I hope you enjoy it. Here is a YouTube video I made awhile back for new players. Some info is a little dated, but it gives a pretty good overview of the factions/playstyles:

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												I don't usually write reviews but I have to for this game. Note that I have been playing this game for a month before Steam so my steam hours don't show my experience (granted I am still fairly new). Duelyst is an amazing mixture of card and board games. I think of it like combining hearthstone with chess. Its like hearthstone but with less rng and hence more skill based. You could play the best cards and still lose due to poor positioning so it brings another layer of strategy. I recommend trying this game, its free so why not? If you like hearthstone, you will like this game and if you like hearthstone and wish there was less rng, you will love this game. Things I like about this game are:  Quests require you to PLAY games not WIN games  You get 2 quests per day and can reroll them. You also get 15 gold per 2 wins. This and other little bonuses make Duelyst a really nice F2P game. (Of course you can still buy orbs [pack of cards]).  As I said before, positioning and less rng cards make this a less frustrating experience as playing more skillfully will give reward you.The only thing some may consider negative in this game is some pricing. The pricing for orbs are actually really fair (similar price to HS, maybe cheaper). And you get a ton more gold per day so you don't even need to spend money unless you want to (I haven't yet but that may change as I really like this game). However the pricing for cosmetic items like emotes is fairly high. You get crates randomly as you play and to open these crates you need a key. These keys can cost up to $10. This sounds expensive but remember you don't need to buy this as its only a cosmetic item which doesn't affect your game play at all.

												Don't let my playtime fool you.I've played this game for a lot of hours before it came to steam.While this may look like a hearthstone clone, it is actually much, much more.Duelyst is an incredible, gorgeous, well polished, competitive strategic board game based on card decks.Mastering this game is a real challenge since unlike other card games, this one requires good planning, positioning, complex strategies and an experienced knowledge of hundreds of difficult game mechanics.Compared to hearthstone you gain way more good cards from packs which helps you creating a good budget deck pretty early in the game, legendaries  are also way more common than HS, in other words less pay 2 win. number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												Preface: I have played this game for months on the native client before the Steam version came out. This is why I only have minimal time shown on the Steam version. :)I have been a Collectible Card Game enthusiast (and ex-pro) for years. I also appreciate a game with a high amount of polish and attention put into the experience and presentation. This is the reason I originally gravitated to Hearthstone. It was "easy to learn and difficult to master". Duelyst was clearly inspired by Hearthstone, but they have something that few other collectible card games offer - a game board. In Hearthstone, positioning your minions occasionally has implications, but most of the time it serves no purpose. Contrast this to Duelyst where positioning your minions is completely core to the experience and it adds a richness of tactical depth that games like Hearthstone will never achieve -- and it does so without complicating the mechanics. Duelyst is not like chess where every piece has its own movement rules. Every minion moves exactly the same - 2 squares (with a couple of exceptions based on very clear card text).The quest system is also amazing - there are quests like "Play 4 games with X faction" - doesn't even matter if you lose, you still get credit, and I find this has a huge emotional and psychological impact.At first I was put off by the gorgeous UI and background art combined with the odd 8-bit pixel style of the characters on the board. But it's definitley grown on me, and I've come to really enjoy it.As other reviewers have mentioned, Duelyst is extremely generous with gold and resources for a free-to-play game, better than Hearthstone as a comparison.TLDR: Duelyst is a collectible card game with a unique additional element of a game board, which adds a nice extra layer of tactical depth without being too complex. If you've ever played a CCG, you can instantly pick this game up and "get it". The art is beautiful, the rewards are more than fair, and I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys CCG's, board games, or tactics games like Fire Emblem.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Easily one of the best card-based TBS in the market right now. Pros:+ As an artist, this game has absolutely state of the art pixel art and animation.+ Devs actually trying to make factions different from each other with defined playstyle. + Devs taking advantage of this game being a digital card game, card balancing are plentiful, keeping the game balancing at a relatively healthy state. + Great F2P experience. Monthly rewards are generous as most players can make a budget deck and get the best time-for-effort reward available without much trouble. + Extremely good core gameplay mechanic, reminds me somewhat of FF Tactic or Fire Emblems. + Replace mechanic is extremely helpful on reducing the RNG nature of card game. Less dead draws more space for players to put in tech cards.Cons:- Competitive decks can be hard to craft as most of them runs 3-4 legendaries, each of them cost quite alot to craft as some might required 3 copies.- Tempo driven game that favors playing good minions on curve. - Early game can be very one-sided if you don't have good early drops to contest mana-tiles. Losing out on early game control can be quite hard to comeback. - Generals and their BBS (think hero power from HS) designs, while promote a playstyle and basically guide the designs of cards, can also limit what type of deck can be used for the faction. - Neutral minions (even commons) are VERY strong compared to game like Hearthstone. This can be a pro or con depends on players. Decks are cheaper because several decks use the same good neutral minions, but you will end up battling the same 5-6 minions that are staple for all decks (Think Blistering Skorn, Jaxi, Mystic healer etc..) - Expensive cosmetic. Overall great game, it has alot of protential to topple giants like Hearthstone, and it's coming to mobile market too. 8.5/10Source: I play this game for almost a year.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Duelyst is a tactical turn-based collectable card game with beautiful pixel art. It perfectly mixes the correct elements of different genres to make each and every game is different. Duelyst will keep you engaged and addicted after hundreds of hours. It is really easy to learn, but extremely hard to master.Duelyst is heavily focused on player verses player combat, using six different factions; each with there own unique keywords and abilities to stomp your opponents to victory. You can start off by crafting your deck and practicing against different faction AI's as well as completing a ton of challenges in order to learn the ins and outs of the game until you feel comfortable enough to join the ladder queue with 40 tactical cards of your choice. As of right now, there is only a ranked queue however the kind and active devs have hinted towards an unranked queue once the community has grown larger.However if you are looking to play a raw, bare boned game, then you can enter the gauntlet. The Gauntlet lets you choose 1 out of 3 cards randomly given to you until you have a complete 30 card deck. Gauntlet allows for amazing combos and unique gameplay situations that leaves you with a feeling of satisfaction if you win 12/0 in a gauntlet run, or even a 0/3 gauntlet run. Duelyst has a EXTREMELY nice community that loves to interact with each other through discord, twitch, twitter and other media outlets. Tournaments are constantly being organized and supported by the developers and community members hand and hand.  I have never seen a dev team so connected that they willingly have one on one chats with the members.I was accepted into the beta of this game in June of 2015. I hated turn-based games and I REALLY hated collectable card games. However, I promise you. You will not be disappointed with this game. If you see this game as "another bad Heartstone clone," I challenge you to play 3 games and tell me that this is a bad tactical game. Not only is the gameplay amazing, but Duelyst has the most beautiful pixel art you have ever seen. Some people may see this as a negative, but some people are stupid and wrong.Protip: Craft 3 Dancing Blades, 3 Primus Fists, and 3 Blaze Hounds to start your collection, and don’t disenchant anything. Build a collection, don’t try to specialize right away!

content:
Posted: April 9
												I will review an aspect of Duelyst that apparently has not been issued with enough depth in other reviews . For now I will not rate tha game itself - you have hundreds of other reviews explaining how the game works. I am reviewing the COSTS of this game as Duelyst caught my interest very quickly and I bought cards very fast too , making me aware of something I felt I needed to let other people interested in the game know. Apparently a lot of people get upset by free2play games being "pay2win" . free2play means you can play and enjoy the game for free. Now if a game is all based on a PvP rank system, it is just obvious that at some point you will have to spend money - or you won't have the required tools to allow you to compete on an equal basis ( unless of course youre extremely talented etc but this review is aimed at normal/average players ). Also , if the game is good I don't see why not spend some money on it ( even if very  little ) since people (  devs )  worked and keep working hard to develop it. Now let's take a closer look at how this plays out in Duelyst. Aside from a very small amount of solo tutorial / challenge missions there are ONLY ranked matches available. The ranking system is pretty similar to a lot of other games. Each win earns you a star / point , with winning streaks getting you an extra one. You start at rank 30 - Bronze League, which decreases initially by 1 every two starts / points .  When you reach Rank 20 , you are promoted to the Silver League - and won't fall back to Bronze not maatter how much you loose until the end of the season ( end of the month ).  Considering the winning streaks bonuses, you could reach Silver in like 18 matches. What happens when you hit Silver League ? You start running into better players with much better decks than Bronze, and it will be way harder to win if you only have a basic set of cards. With the need to purchase cards ( unless you do months of grinding ) and not being able to rank down , the game becomes effectively "PAY2PLAY" IMO. You either grind your way painfully and slowly with daily quests that do not require wins,  or you NEED to buy cards . Ok , pay2win is fine, but PAY2PLAY is the opposite of free2play. But let's suppose you are skilled and don't need to spend a single buck in the game. You can hit the top ranks without spending a single dollar. But you are a collector and want all the cards or just want to support the game developent buy buying all of them. Pretty muc the same as buying a game with all the DLCs.What if I tell you that after spending a little over USD300,00 ( that's correct three hundred dollars ) you will still not be able to have all the cards ( you can have a maximum of 3 copies per deck , but I am talking about not having a single copy of some of the rarer cards ) of the game? How does that sound? I definitively CANNOT RECOMMEND a game that so far has only 3 expansions and already requires you to spend like USD 500,00 to have all the cards.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												This is a cardgame with a strategic grid (5x9 cells). The game has 6 different factions each with a nicely varied gameplay and each faction has 2 heroes with a unique skill.Pros:-Strategic grid (5x9 cells)-Nicely aesthetic artstyle combines with pixelart for the units-Nice Gui-Ability to destroy cards and craft them like in Hearthstone (and looking at costs it also seems cheaper)-varied playstyle from the different factions AND even from the different heroes(2 each) inside the   factions-Has a replay function for your matches-Has an easy button to spectate high ranking matches so u can watch and learn better (i really wonder  why blizzard doesnt have this)-easy daily quests (for example u do NOT need to win the online matches. You only have to do some to finish the quest. The outcome doesnt matter so this makes it easy for beginners to finish the quests and gain the daily gold).-The RNG is lower than in other cardgames because of the grid and the ability to replace one card each turn.-Lots of the aoe is conditional meaning it depends on something (like for example minion power/position on the grid(on your side or not for example/adjecent or not/in column)-Orbs which are like booster packs have a higher rarity rate than if u compare it with hearthstoneThe F2P aspect seems good. I did not invest anything and I started playing one day after this game released here ( 3days of playing with 22 hours gametime) and already managed to climb up to rank 10 which is the gold rank. Orbs which are like boosters cost 100gold.In the beginning u can easily do all the challenges which are like one turn puzzles and give a nice one time boost of gold. There are also some other one time stuffs like achievments and of course for adding a referal before you do your first rank match gives u enough gold for one orb.As a normal gold income you get 2 daily quests which each atleast give 25 gold and your first daily win gives 20 gold. You also get a daily challenge puzzle which can be solved for an easy 5 gold. After this every 2nd online win gives u 15 gold (till some cap and then it lowers to just 5 gold).The game also has a drafting mode which is called gauntlet and can be compared with hearthstone arena. Like in hearthstone if u are good enough u can go infinite there.Like in heartstone there also seems to be a monthly reward chest which rewards depend on your online ranking.Cons:-No guildsystem ingame-Some ppl might not like the combination of pixel art with a different stylised artstyle-No openchat systemSo all in all the game is worth a tryout and looks like a nice alternative to hearthstone or other cardgames. The grid gives this cardgame a nice strategic placement depth.If you want to start and tryout the game and need a referal code here is mine:nyaamosYou can put this code in 3 places. Of course this can only be done once for every account and has to be done BEFORE the first rank match.    During signup.    In the settings under “Redeem referral/gift code”.    In the buddy list.My referal code:nyaamos

												I really like the style of Duelyst. I love the pixel art and the sound, the entire package just seems really well put together in my opinion. Gameplay consists of picking your faction and using your deck of units, spells and items in an arena. The goal being to defeat the enemy general. As of this Steam release there are six factions and a pretty good variety of "cards" to collect (cards being units, items, and spells).Now I am no expert one way or another but one of the big complaints I am seeing pop up here and there are calls for more balance. I don't know where I fall in that argument because I have only played a few hours, but I can say I feel like one or two of the factions has the upper hand as it stands now. I do not know if it evens out at higher level play, and we are all making newbie mistakes or if there really is a balance issue with the factions. What I can do however is recommend you try them all to see for your self what you will be most comfortable playing. I would recommend Duelyst to card game and strategy fans. Its pretty neat.

Many would say this is a card game. I disagree somewhat because this game is so much more than that.Duelyst is an online 1v1 strategy battle game which is extremely fun, addictive & mentally challenging! Pros: -Fun bugless online experience (This gets my thumbs up as the best game of its genre)-User Interface is solid and works exactly as it should-Fun interactive system for players-Creatures and spells are funCons:*-Unit graphics are pixel art which means that the battle is not visually attractive.(If the game developers make the graphics crisp and clear, this would easily make me want to play for much longer)*-Animations in general can be improved so that the game looks more smooth and cheerful-I feel like gold rewards for some quests are too low (The effort reward ratio is not rewarding enough)-Friends can be added but no notes can be taken down so it can be hard to remember everyoneThank you Counterplay Games for a very solid and fun experience but if you can improve on my cons (the creature graphics in particular and its animations), you will have a true masterpiece of a game!

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												It's a really fun game, but not really viable to play for free once you get silver ranking and start getting slapped around by players with much much better cards.  If you stick with it and play the long game grinding out gold, it may be viable to create a competitive deck. More realistically you are either going to get bored or pay up.Seems unfair to rate a 'f2p' game because of it's pay model, but if the 'pay options' give the payers a considerable advantage against the free players, the game has cancer. Gameplay wise the game is actually really well made and fun to play, and cost wise the random card packs are comparitively cheap compared to some games. So if you go in expecting to drop money to be able to compete it's not a bad game. Games that do F2P right- Path of Exile- League of Legends- DOTA 2- Team FortressMaybe a couple others?Point being monitary interaction should be based on cosmetics or advantages that could almost be considered trivial.  This is not that. I'm going to keep playing for awhile, Because it really is that fun, but if I find that I'm not able to create a fairly viable deck without investing money I'll inevitably give it up and play something else.

content:
Posted: April 19
												So I played Duelyst fairly early on in its inception. It was a godsend to me. It combines the tactical side of an actual grid/board game with generals and collectible cards. I started playing ranked competetively when the most broken thing was Song'Hai Lantern Fox OTKs. Ive only reached S-rank once using the top tier Spell Hai lists going around at that time. A deck that actually rewarded skill and resource management and ♥♥♥♥ing tactical gameplay (who wouldve thought). After that the game started changing dramatically. The powercreep was extremely obvious and way over the top. They added super RNG pets with either under costed stats or broken abilities. What the ♥♥♥♥ are pets??? Why?? The alternate heroes they added were cool as they all seemed to be the control counterpart of the original general. But, once the meta became more established the meta just seemed to brim with dump your hand, hope they dont kill your combo pieces to race to your win condition or smack your oppenent in the face to win. There was no thinking anymore. I stopped playing when Magmar was just running everybody down with face damage while still drawing their deck. That expansion made no ♥♥♥♥ing sense to me. This game could've been so much more, but Im not sure what happaned to it.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												Disregard the 20 minutes played (at the time of writing) I've been at this for several months prior to its steam launch.I can't praise Duelyst enough. It's the perfect mix of digital CCG and tactical turn based combat that manages to bring fresh life to both the genres. One of the most refreshing parts of Counter Play's entry to an increasingly crowded digital CCG market is how easy and fair it feels to be a F2P player. Quest rewards are generous and orbs (Duelyst's card packs) frequently dole out high rarity cards, especially when compared to Hearthstone's Psudo-RNG pack opening that requires you to open LOTS of packs before the odds eventually weight in your favor and you crack an epic/legendary.The game play itself is nothing to scoff at either. Each of the 6 factions boasts 2 generals, each with a unique Bloodborne Spell (think Hearthstone Hero Power) that greatly changes how you would go about building a deck for them. Matches are generally quick, but mindless aggression and "SMORC" (to borrow a Hearthstone term) decks won't get you far. Duelyst matches generally boil down to a desperate struggle between two armies for control of the battlefield via clever troop movement and spells. Sucuessful decks generally live somewhere between the extremes of traditional CCG 'agro' and 'control' archtypes but there's still a fair bit of latitude when it comes to picking a strategy of choice for your favorite faction. That said, a rather limited card pool can make a lot of decks feel rather samey as a lot of the really high quality neutral minions get recycled over and over. Hopefully the upcoming Denizens of Shim'zar expansion (out in a week!) will fix a lot of those issues.And on top of all this, the soundtrack is suprisingly pumping for a turn based game, the pixel art is beautiful, and the whole experience just oozes polish and care. Each faction has a strong visual identity and it's very tempting to pick your neutral minions based as much on their visual cohesion as their tactical value! There might be some growing pains as MTG, Hearthstone, and other CCG veterans get used to the tactical board, but overall it's a massively rewarding experience that I HIGHLY recommend.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												What to say about Duelyst. I have been playing for 7 months now and it still excites and entertains. The game is a CCG not unlike hearthstone, but the tactical element of the board makes it so much more interesting. If you are a fan of tactics games or card games it's definitely worth checking out.Card acquisition in these game is really quite reasonable. You get gold for doing quests, most of which ask you to play with a faction for 4 games or to kill x enemy units/do x damage. There are also daily challenges for 5 gold, and if you ever miss your quests they give a small amount of the gold into a welcome back quest to make up for it. If you do all your quests, you can easily open a pack a day for about 30-40 minutes of playing. The rarities of the cards in the pack are also pretty good with a legendary card in about 1 in 4 packs. Finally, once you know the game well you can do the gauntlet, a draft mode, and so long as you get 7 wins you can go infinite for tons of rewards.The devs are a small team that are very dedicated to their game and to the community. They push out an update with 4 new cards at the end of every month and they are constantly adding new things like cosmetics. They are supporting player run tournaments which can then feed in to their qualifiers for the Duelyst world championship. As for the relation with the community, they have done multiple rountables with popular streamers and prominent members of the community have been made into cards in the game.All in all Duelyst is one of the best CCGs out there. Whether you are looking for a fun card game to play in between classes or looking to compete with the best in weekly tournaments there is a place for you here. If you are looking for community interaction, the subreddit and the discord channel are where most people go and the devs are requlars in the discord channel as well. Here's hoping I see you on the battlefield.
