number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
												Duelyst is one of the best-designed games that I've played, and definitely the best card game.  The mixture of tactical depth and near-perfect balance among cards and factions is so satisfying, and I'm comparing to beautifully balanced games like Starcraft and DOTA.Pros:- The replace mechanic is amazing.  This is something that other card games are sorely lacking.  It gives you the option to replace one card in your hand each turn, which adds a lot to the skill ceiling and improves consistency of decks when players replace intelligently.- Game is on a grid so positioning matters.  I just hit S-rank for the first time (equivalent of "Legend" in Hearthstone) and I still feel like I make positioning errors in most games.  There is so much depth added from this; it is wonderful.- Counterplay Games is very proactive about balance.  If they feel that a card is too strong or weak, they change it quickly and re-evaluate.  This iterative approach is MUCH better than say, Hearthstone, where the devs refuse to change obviously broken cards for months until the screaming of anguished ladder players can be heard at Blizzard HQ.- The factions are unique and have interesting mechanics that reward good planning and decision making.  The asymmetric balance approach reminds me a lot of Starcraft, another beautiful strategy game (though obviously an RTS and not a card game).- The reward system (quests) are very generous (more than Hearthstone).  Epic/legendary drops are much more common even accounting for Duelyst allowing you to have 3x of each per deck.- Games are short and intense.- Client is well designed software-wise (netcode is good, very few crashes or surprise disconnections, client is highly responsive even on my $500 budget PC)- The tutorial system and solo challenges are great - my only complaint is that there aren't more challenges (I am spoiled)- They introduced weekly boss battles vs. AI which are lots of fun, and give a small free reward with an optional $5 larger paid reward.  This is Counterplay Games' way of covering continuing costs I believe; it's optional and you get to fight the boss either way, so I like the model.Cons:- Some people don't like the pixel art (though I personally like it)- A large portion, though not all, of the top-tier decks require quite a few epic and legendary cards.  HOWEVER, I personally hit Diamond in the first season (month) with a budget deck, and S-rank in second season after spending only $60.  I would hardly call that experience "pay to win"; just be aware that you won't be able to play some of the top-tier netdecks in your first month or two unless you are willing to pay some money (and a couple specific decks are very expensive, though most expensive != best).  Personally I thought $60 for this game was reasonable.- The daily quests do take a decent chunk of time to complete (at least 45 minutes for me)- There are microtransactions for cosmetics and weekly value offers and stuff like that.  None of it is required at all, but the very concept makes some people angry, so beware if you are one of those people.

number of helpful: 28 of 52 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 14
												I played the game through the Duelyst Launcher since its inital release and there's two aspects that is important to note:The GAME is possibly one of the best games I have ever played! But the developers, buisness model and new player experience is horrendous!I will state three things to back up this claim of mine:1. When Duelyst launched the game had a good deal where you paid like 7.50€ for 15 packs or more or something like that and it was a good deal at the time but... a few months later they had an event in which you could get something like 20 free packs! Amazing right?Well... it was time based. And not that it was for a limited amount of time but if your account was older than a month I believe it was, then you weren't eligable for these packs. To summarize it in a very clear cut way: it was more economically viable for you to just ignore your old account if you didn't have many cards on it or had put it down for an extended period of time after you had bought the release-bundle or just didn't play much on the account and didn't have it. It made more sense to ignore your account and make a new one.This alongside the absolutely insanely noob unfriendly quest system and that if you do well at a certain rank you can get locked to either Silver, Gold or Platinum rank and... Noobs belong in Bronze and Silver. Good players who have so called 'Battle Ribbons' that showcase they have won 100 ranked games with a faction show up in Gold. And usually you see people with 5-10 Ribbons if not even more at Gold. Where as you might see ONE Player with ONE Ribbon in Silver.You can get locked to gold and have to battle with these players and to complete a quest you need to do the following:a) Play a set number of minionsb) Play a set number of cards (yes, these two are different)c) Play a set number of turns into the game (conceding or taking lethal damage does not lower this requirement)Basically this means that if you are a new player or someone who just simply is not good enough ... in order to build a collection you have to be willing to just get slugged and unrelentlessly beaten down by people that just JUMP in terms of skill by a SIGNIFICANT margin!(Also you get gold after every win and every 3 win you get more gold but once again, you need to win to get this or be prepared to be beaten into a pulp if you are trying to complete quests.)2. Duelyst makes good use of that its a digital cardgame when dealing with mechanics and in-game by allowing you to essentially conjure up cards by having interesting effects that just add cards to your hand.However... from the buisness side, it is NOT understanding of the digital implications of a modern video game because the pricing of the individual packs (not gold price but that's already horrendous to try to get any amount of as I pointed out already) is insanely high! Since you need a playset of 3 cards of basically most cards in the game, you need to get a HUGE amount of cards! And the prices in regards to paying with actual money as opposed to gold is insanely high when you consider how many packs of cards you need to get from the base set and the expansion!If you are good at the Gauntlet you can mitigate some of these issues but... I will go into why this is not really the case because...3. The developers haven't made a casual mode or non-ranked place to play.Its either the Gauntlet or Ranked Ladder in regards to where you can play and complete quests. The gauntlet functions much like the same when compared to Hearthstone but ... the gold is once again, annoying beyond belief to get ANY amount of!And since there's no casual mode where non-competitive decks exists, you consistently have to try to complete the quests whilst playing against people with litterally thousands of games played, near complete if not complete collections of cards and since the playerbase is still relatively small for the game you basically ONLY encounter excellent-to-amazingly good players once you have gotten past Silver which can happen by mistake and you are now stuck in Gold.The game itself is AMAZING! So if you can get past that the buisness model is that of a regular cardgame in a digital format, that the developers genuinely do try to scam their players' accounts and the most horrendous F2P-system bar that of something like Magic Duels. Its not a Mobile-Phone level of "F2P"-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ but it is certainly horrendous and really, REALLY annoying for folks that doesn't want to put in 40-50€ into the game to even just get STARTED.I recommend the game if you are like me and have a cardgame-itch you need to scratch and you want another option than Hearthstone. But to anyone else who's basically not a cardgame-addict... AVOID THIS GAME!!!Oh and a few more things since I am posting this review only here on Steam:1. The fanbase is rabidly trying to defend the game because they are no longer victims of the horrendous new-player experience this game offers.2. The Steam version doesn't seem to have a working Steam-Overlay system so what's even the point of having it on Steam I don't know.3. It got essentially CS:GO lootboxes in the game so... yah', it tries to scam you in that regard as well being a Gambling-Simulator.4. Both Steam and non-Steam versions of the game can crash or just freeze up if you try to look through your collection quickly if you play in Windowed mode.5. The best way to summarize the community when asking for help is "I don't believe you" if you are experiencing something other angelic song when playing the game (they don't deal well with neither reality NOR with critique).

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												This is a really neat strategy game.Yes, it has cards and decks, and they do add some randomness to it. However, I see it more as a turn-based strategy game using cards to add randomness. And for those who don't tend to like card games because they find the RNG frustrating, this game helps mitigate the RNG (mitigate, not eliminate) by allowing you to trade out one card per turn.The board and units' placements upon it make it much more complicated than something like Hearthstone, or even Faeria, another turn based strategy game with card stuff going on. I'd actually place Faeria closer to Hearthstone and other CCGs than Duelyst is, by a pretty solid margin.

												Duelyst is a great game at times. Often it is a a chore cuz it forces you to play pvp no matter what. There are no big alternatives. Sooner or later you finished solo challenges and you will have not much options left to farm and enjoy the game in Pve aspects.Solo challenges are less rewarding the harder it gets. Why? Dont ask me.Lets talk about Gauntlet. Okay lets dont. Gauntlet is a chore. Still and since Beta.Boss encounters: After you managed to beat him you can get a single orb and 3 orbs you have to open with a pay and win key. Its not totally unfair but it feels false.Dont get me wrong. Races and diversity of cards are great. I even like the look of it. But... Duelyst is like a Topmodel. It looks amazing but after the date you want to meet a real Lady.^^All in all Duelyst is a mixed bag and the reason I cant recommend it is cuz the game has not developed very far since Beta. Sure there are some more "card-editions," (Tools to earn more money) But gamemodes? No!This could be so much more. Playing it I often thought about maybe to give Kings and Legends another try and that is no good sign at all.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												Not only one of the best free to play games on steam but probably one of the best games on steam all together. Incredibly deep yet incredibly simple turn based strategy game. Alot of people will try to compare this to hearthstone and they would he right to. Their are alot of similarities. How ever, using a grid system instead of 2 sides of a board to place your cards adds an unrivalled level of depth.The way they have balanced the cards has created a system where there is multiple win conditions, and multiple ways to achieve each win condition.Every faction (class) has 2 generals with different bloodline spells (your classes  spell) creating multiple play styles for each faction. Yet some how they have managed to get every playstyle for every faction to feel unique and compliment the lore and look of the faction. The ladders seasons reset at the end of every month giving substantial rewards, and the game seems to be very generous in terms of card packs, gold and spirit (dust) rewards. Because of these things, strategy plays a much more important role then draw or calibre of deck. Almost every game is challenging and rewarding. And unlike hearthstone where it was easy to play "optimally" and lost to either bad card draws or better decks, in Duelyst, every game I lose is because I make mistakes. And whats incredible is how often you can make mistakes and how you can actively see then cost you every game. TLDR; Incredible game, And there is no reason not to try it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												Where to begin? Here's another free-to-play game where purchases really aren't required, has addicting gameplay, solid design, and a competitive scene. The comparisons to Hearthstone are accurate, since it borrows most (if not all or more) of the same card mechanics that HS borrowed from MTG to begin with. If you're familiar with either of those games, you'll get the lay of the land pretty quick.But what's this? A positioning mechanic? This adds a whole new layer to your strategic thought. Also, you can replace a card once per turn (or twice with certain card effects), which is a big upgrade from Hearthstone where you can get locked very easily with your high-cost draws and can't do anything but use your hero power for a couple turns.PROS:* Highly strategic gameplay, with the CCG and tabletop elements blending seamlessly.* The tutorial and challenges are well-designed for familiarizing you with the mechanics. Daily challenges require a lot of meta-thinking. * For a free game there's surprisingly little pressure to buy any microtransactions unless you're really trying to get in on the competitive scene, or you just want that badass skin for your favorite general. You can get card packs just through playing relatively easily. Everything else in the cash shop is purely cosmetic: emotes, profile icons, card backs, and general skins, which admittedly are fairly cheap and look pretty cool. You can also grind the "spirit" currency you get from disenchanting cards, but that's a long road for little gain.* For low-bit pixelated graphics, everything's animated well.* Having the option to replace a card each turn with no penalties attached alleviates some of the inherent frustration in CCGs of getting an unfavorable draw.* Uniquely diverse deck generals, but only six base decks to choose from. On the upside, each deck has a second general you can unlock by leveling it up, though the only real difference between generals is their personal spell. Still, used wisely it could massively affect your card synergy.* The main menu has a direct link to all the currently active livestreams, as well as a plethora of replays, sorted by player rank. Pretty neat way to go about including a spectator mode.* There's an entire "Codex" accessible from the main menu that has lore on the characters, races and timeline of this game's universe, complete with narration and artwork. Not that there's much reason to be emotionally invested, but if you're into that sort of thing, it's there. Definitely shows a lot of heart on the developers' side, very nice touch.* Tons of default emotes to use in a match, and even more to buy/unlock. They even added replies from AI opponents when, say, you foil their next move, or if they think they've got the edge on you. Kinda cute.NEUTRAL:* With the amount of writing they put into a codex, you'd think they'd have included flavor text for the cards, even if it's just a blurb. Oh well. It's better than seeing those tongue-in-cheek one-liners in Hearthstone. (Looking especially at you, Nozdormu.)Can't really think of any cons; there may be some balance issues between the base decks that I'm not keen on, but it's a solid game overall, and you can't complain with free.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content: Posted: August 23, 2016 I was first introduced to Duelyst during its kickstarter campaign through another kickstarter success story's community forum. It looked beautiful and seemed like a fun concept. I didn't decide to back it at the time and instead promptly forgot about it.I was later reintroduced to Duelyst via a friend who DID back it, letting me know that it's been released for a bit now and that it was free to play. This was in late January, during the open beta. Hearing "free to play" triggered worries about what sort of exploitative ftp cash grab gimmicks that might have been implemented, but found it to be entirely devoid of impulse buy exploitation. With a big sigh of relief, I dove right in and was able to enjoy the game whole-heartedly.Then, as I raised up through the ranks and came to realize just how narrow the meta really was in high level play, a ray of light pierced through to the core of the game and changed everything. The developers recognized that one of their core mechanics was limiting high level play in a major way (drawing 2 cards per turn forced a need to play 2 cards per turn) and they COMPLETELY REWORKED that core system, changing everything about the pacing of the game. It really caught me off guard at first, but within a week I realized how much of an amazing thing they had just done.It's now been a half year that I've been playing this game. As a result of their show of forethought and willingness to adapt even the core systems to keep the game healthy and active, I have a lot of faith that Counterplay will keep Duelyst a game to enjoy for years to come. It's astoundingly easy to build cards up without spending a dime, essentially getting a booster pack per day within 4-8 games; and with such quick matches, it's easy to enjoy the game in short bursts or longer sessions alike. If you like tactical gameplay, creative deckbuilding, or even just get a boner over amazing animations like I do, play the game.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												What intrigued me the most is the art & music obviously. I'm a sucker for pixel art that's been done well. Reminded me a bit of Hyper Light Drifter's style.After playing through the tutorial (which was really well done by the way) I did a few online matches. Everything has been really well explained for a newbie to the game, but fun to master as one familiar with the idea behind gameplay.Playing online really showed me a lot of different tactics that other players have been using (I'm now Silver tier!). It's also very friendly as far as ranking is considered. I don't think you can rank down? You're just required to win a certain number of times to go up in the ranks.Even if you don't play online, there's a handful of challenges that are really good puzzles and even some very challenging Dailies that are fun to go at!I haven't spent a cent on the game yet and I still feel like I'm having an unhindered experience. This is awesome for a f2p TCG.One thing I don't quite understand yet is how crafting works. Maybe there's some tutorial I haven't looked at just yet. Not sure.TCG & Tactic Background: So in my teenage-youth I played Pokemon & Yu-Gi-Oh and enjoyed both thoroughly. I also played a lot of Final Fantasy Tactics Advanced, about ~6 hours of Fire Emblem (lost my saved game :(), and a bit of Advanced Wars.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Amazing  mix between a Collectible Card Game and a Turn Based Strategy game. Unlike a CCG like Hearthstone or MTG, fighting will take place in a grid, where you can use your cards to summon minions, cast spells and equip items which you will use to defeat the enemy general while keeping yours alive, just don't forget that generals can be as powerful as your best cards. Therefore, good positioning is extremely important to make the most of your resources. Unlike other CCGs you actually need to move your 10/10 next to the enemy general to deal damage, and there are plenty of ways to stop it from doing that. Combat is just great. Matches are relatively quick, maybe 10 minutes max. but they are action packed and with plenty of surprises. You might be completely surrounded by buffed enemies, the enemy General expecting you to concede, but then you draw a card that temporarily transforms al your enemiesl to tiny 1/1s, allowing your otherwise weaker creatures to turn the tide of battle. It's hard to know whether you're winning or losing, since, with good luck and good timing, the match could easily turn around. And then turn around again...Duelyst boasts of 6 different factions with their own unique cards (as well as neutral cards for all factions), each with two different generals, and each general with its own unique and powerful skill. This allows for lots of different decks and playstyles. However, starter decks are powerful and good enough to win even vs opponents with a bigger card variety, as skill is more relevant than the cards you have. The game itself is very newbie friendly while still having great depth and being hard to master. You can also play practice games and challenges to learn the game's mechanics and hone your skillsThe aesthetic of the game is gorgeous. Each creature and spell is beautifully animated in pixel art. It also has a great soundtrack.Duelyst is a true F2P game with a fair business model. You can unlock new card packs (5 cards each with at least one rare) either by paying real money or by using gold. Each pack costs 100 gold, and you can very easily earn it by completing daily quests, challenges, or simply by winning up to x amount of matches every day. You can also buy cosmetics like card backs, emotes and profile pictures with real money.If you want to check out the game, feel free to use my referral code: WaelderYou'll get 100 gold for using it, which is enough for an extra card pack, and I'll get a card pack if you progress enough in ranked.

												Very fun TCG/Turn-Based-Strategy game. Basically, it's a card game, except with turn-based strategy in the form of a board with movement tiles etc. I was very happy to see that the F2P elements of the game are pretty generous and that it's similar to hearthstone in terms of rewards. There are daily quests, challenges and all sorts of different activities that reward you with gold to buy packs. I've always liked TCG games like this better than the traditional because I feel like RNG is a lot less brutal. If you get a bad hand you'll be at a disadvantage, but you still have an opportunity to turn it around with clever play.I definitely see myself sinking at least 20+ hours into this game.

I definitely don't recommend anyone to spend any money on it, because it might suddenly become permanently unplayable.

												Both Duelyst and Faeria are free to play- the question isn't one of money, but of time- something that ideally you'll on spend on the better of the two, since they're pretty similar otherwise- low hardware requirements, microtransactions, internal friendlists and pregame deckbuilding etc. It wouldn't take long for anyone to try both out, honestly- neither take very long to fully access- a couple hours at most.If you want a second opinion though, Duelyst left me with a fairly bored first impression, whilst Faeria really grabbed me with both the aesthetic, the mechanics and the tutorial. content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												I can not in good faith reccomend this game. It's one of those f2p Card games where you have to pay real money to get the best cards. I will say that it is one of the best animated ones out there. For example when you play a card, it actually puts the unit on a grid based map and has attack animations. Very nice on that part. The strategy part of this game though is total bogus. You build a deck or use a deck made by the game depending on what faction you chose. I have put in about 80 hours and can tell you how un balanced they all are. But the main problem with the game is that every single match no matter how you build your deck with a certain playstyle in mind it is all random. Yes you can replace 2 cards befor ematch starts from your starting hand and you can replace 1 card each round - ou tof 40 cards. I fail to see how there is any strategy when your opponent can start with exactly what he/she has in mind and you start with no set up what -so -ever. In 80 hours almost every single match I have played has been over in about 7-8 rounds. it's usually just a snowball effect of who got to start with what they wanted. Now if they could fix that and you could at least pick your starting hand and leave the rest random I would keep playing. I would post this game everywhere and give it publicity to my friends and co-workers but in this current state I don't see many grown adults wasting the time to play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												Duelyst is a nice game, except that the near s-rank ladder is a bit too grindy.Duelyst is a Collectible Card Game on a 5x9 chessboard. It's similar to Hearthstone, but without the over-emphasis of RNG. Since it's on a chessboard, there are a lot of unique position-based mechanics, and that is the speciality of Duelyst. There are 6 factions/classes, and each faction has 2 generals, each with a unique Bloodborne Spell (Hero Power) which synergizes well with certain faction cards. Hence, there are at least 12 (in reality much more) playstyles and gameplans.New-player experience is okay. They are definitely more generous that Hearthstone. There are a lot of hidden "achievement quests" that gives you a decent amount of gold, so that you could expand your card collections quickly in the early phases.Most cards are well-designed and I seldom see cards that are outright bad (as opposed to the situation in Hearthstone). However, only a small pool of cards are used in high-ladder because those cards are simply too powerful. This case is more severe as the first expansion has rolled out - just like how Hearthstone was when Naxx and GvG came out. Quite an amount of potential deck archetypes are unviable because of the strength of some new cards. Ultimately, the game at a competitive level is grindy and somewhat stale - but I guess that happens in every CCG.The publicity department of this game is also not so good. Their outreach is bad - if you don't play the game yourself, you have nearly no channels to know that this game is holding up a promotion. If it wasn't that a friend referred you to this game, it would take a miracle for youto discover this game. It doesn't matter that they have released an expansion 2 months ago, it doesn't matter that they gave away packs to newcomers a month ago, it doesn't matter if they're planning to release another expansion in 2017 Q1 when they do nearly nothing to increase the publicity of the game and reach out to potential new players. A comparison would be Shadowverse. It's another Collectible Card Game. they paid Reynad and Kripparian to promote their new expansion.I reckon that this game's community is slowly dying as in this moment, even if the game is fun. There is nearly no one streaming this game. The relatively popular regular streamers of this game (none of them has more than 200 viewers) have recently stopped streaming as much. Forums are much quieter than anytime before (good thing is that ranting threads die as the forum is becoming less active).TL;DR: All in all, Duelyst is good and has a lot of potential. The game is fun and rewarding, and there is a lot for you to explore in this game. However, the community of Duelyst is too small and they have little, if not none, publicity and outreach, that they may not survive the other competitors, such as Hearthstone, GWENT, The Elder Scrolls: Legends, and Shadowverse. Go pay a visit if you have free time, and see you like it - they've added a lot of supports to "casual" players so you could expand your card collection in a good pace, even if you don't invest much time into it.

content:
Posted: January 12
												It's great . As a player currently ranked 15/30 in Duelyst, ranked 20/25 in hearthstone as well as a dabbler in the fates series the game feels even better than hearthstone. Duelyst has less reliance on luck and more in skill since it gives players the ability to decide on the unit placement in a 9 by 5 plane. For the freedom of more choices one must be given the difficulty of more complex scenearios. While the game is not nearly as complicated as a full on strategy game such as xcom or fire emblem but it feels far more advanced and free to do what you like then hearthstone. It's better than full on strategy games in the sense that your have more choice in your units with special effects. It's better than hearthstone in the sense that you can place units in a strategically adavtagous way where even if your cards are worse you could bait your enemy into a unescapable corner then flooding the spots where he could summon minnions with yours instead giving him no place to summon minnions. As you can see I'm not that adept in the art of strategy but what I do know is that this game is great even better than hearthstone in a strategical sense. Hearthstone is so popular yet their are hardly as many duelyst players. I wondered why then I realized that it was only logical since Hearthstone beings an easier/ easy to access game to new players of course their would be more players but hearthstone is also far older. In closing if you like hearthstone you will probably like this game even more.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
Duelyst is a highly stratiegic card collecting 1v1 summoning game where the aim is to defeat the enemy general by reducing their health from 25 to 0 without yours losing all of theirsIn Duelyst you take control of 1 of 6 factions to fight another player, choose from 12 different generals (there are two for each faction) and duke it out. Climb the season ladder to win rewards and brag about it to your friends. Suprisingly even though there has been 2.3 thousand reviews but only 400 seem to play everyday (in English time according to my English friend) and not too many more seem to play in US hours.  THIS GAME IS A DEFINITE MUST PLAY FOR CCG OR TACTIC GAMES LOVERSDuelyst has some really superb art and nice unit designs. Played Chess? Play Duelyst, its like Chess but instead has you control units who move in similar patterns with different Opening Gambits, Movement types and Dying Wishes. The game is very fun, and is like one of those 'Easy (sort of) to learn, Hard to master' games.  This game also has a lot of lore findable through the challenges chapters (once you complete one) that are put into the Codex on the main menu. NEEDS A BIGGER COMMUNITY Sadly, Duelyst has a small community and it would be amazing if you could make a good decision and get this game. Its a fun game,  this game was the first TBS game I ever invested time into and I love it

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Edit: So after a bunch of updates I can safely say I can't recommend this game to new players anymore. It's still a good game if you can get past how ♥♥♥♥ing grindy it is. First there was the nerf to the welcome back quest. Your only form of gold gain after not playing for... A SINGLE DAY. Yup, this game doesn't have quest slots like every other card game out there. You have to play every single day. Have fun wtih that! Then when the new expansion came out, they nerfed drop rates. The new orbs gave legendaries much less frequently. Obviously this is a huge deal, the game allows you to have 3 legendaries per deck... have fun collecting them all. And now, the quests are more grindy than ever and still no quest slots.Everything that I haven't crossed below still holds true, the game is still good, it's just the bussiness model that's bad but I cannot recommend it. _______________________________________________________________________________________With Elder Scrolls: Legends in open beta, Gwent just around the corner and Duelyst getting its first expansion, hearthstone FINALLY has some good competition and it was about ducking time.Yes it's a Collectible Card Game but it's like no other.I've been playing it for a few months before it came out on steam.First lets address the features of the game and I'll go into detail down below.Pros:Chess-like board that makes for very strategic gameplayExtremly F2P-friendly Not anymore it's not. Unless you have nothing else to do all day. Very good card / character designAmazing pixel art and fully animated minions and spellsEasy to learn with a very good tutorial, but hard to masterFour different modesOn-going lore which makes for an interesting readDaily challengeThey embrace the digital aspect of this game (frequent nerfs / buffs) Replay functionCons:UI could use a little workQuest system could be improved Oh they "improved" it by making more grindy.No casual mode as of yetNo spectate friends function Now there is!  Keep in mindDeck size is fourty cardsUp to three copies of each card including legendaries in your deckYou draw a card at the END of your turnYou can replace a card from your hand for a random one from your deck each turnWall of text:This game is like chess. The tutorial combined with the challenges are very thorough in this regard. Tutorial gives you a basic idea of how the game plays and the challenges put you in different situations that are set up for lethal. Basically designed to get you into the thought process of the game, which is something Hearthstone doesn't do (Although it's arguable that it doesn't need to, since it's much simpler). After that you can practice against the AI with your homebrewed decks honing your skills and later on you can venture on to the ranked mode or if you want the gauntlet which is identical to arena in hearthstone. You get offered to choose one of three random cards of the same rarity until you make a deck. Deck size is thirty cards in this mode.Game is pretty straight forward but really hard to master. During your first weeks you'll be making tons of misplays. Hell, I'm still making some but it's REALLY rewarding. Figuring out a way to make a comeback or putting together combos is extremely satisfying. It will make you feel GOOD. Meanwhile in hearthstone: Yes this random effect won me the game LOLZNow as I said, the game is extremely F2P-friendly. Tons of hidden one off challenges which really help you get started (rewards ranging from gold to actual legendaries). There are no "win" quests in this game, the game in that regard just rewards you for playing, which is something hearthstone does NOT do. The quests that give you the most gold in hearthstone require wins except a couple like watch n learn which doesn't even encourage you to play. This is SO healthy for the game, you can try whatever deck you like without feeling like you are not making progress. However for those who want to be rewarded for winning there's the first win of the day which grants 20 extra gold and you get 15 per 2 wins. Which is so much better than what hearthstone does. (10 gold per 3 wins). The end of the month chest gives you a pack as well again something hearthstone does NOT do. This all makes the game feel way less grindy in general.Moving on to the art of the game, it's simply beautiful and colorful. From the backgrounds to the pixel art of the cards. This with the wonderfuly written and narrated lore bring the game to life. I would strongly urge you to read the lore.The music isn't something to be sniffed at either, there's few but really good tracks in the game. Yes they do get repetitive but what CCG music doesn't? No game is without its faults sadly.Lets start off with the UI, it's not bad but it doesn't really suit the style of the game. It's really negligible but if you are like me, it's not going to go unnoticed and what's up with the game giving me a constant reminder in the main menu that I have unopened cosmetic chests? It makes it look ugly and its obvious its there to push you into buying cosmetics, again negligible, but still.Now onto more important things, the game doesn't have a casual mode yet. For some people it's not going to be a big deal but I know there are others out there who want to play without having to worry about their rank constantly. Here's what I would consider the biggest issue with the game however. I stressed how F2P-friendly the game is but it's not friendly towards people without loads of time. If you don't do your quests daily you don't get more, only one extra that adds 5 gold each day you haven't completed your quests and capping off at 50 gold. It's a nice gesture but you are falling behind 45~ gold per day not counting daily wins. This is something hearthstone does way better. You can always argue how we should be glad its free to play but I cannot look past this and this is coming from someone with a lot of time. Even I can see how bad this is for others. In the end though, this is the best CCG around in almost every regard. I hope this and the other CCG's get big enough because hearthstone is in dire need of competition. The game has been going downhill since the Old Gods expansion. I hope I convinced you to at least give it a try, have fun!Ps. i'll be updating the pros and cons as future updates happen.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												A very interesting game with all the problems of a Pay-To-Win game. Duelyst is a battle board card game where 2 players race to drop their opponent's generals hitpoints to 0. You spawn minions, cast spells and equip artifacts to try to control and/or burst the opponent to death. Conclusion, try this game, it's not bad. However, caveat emptor, do note the P2W business model. With the crafting system added in, it is possible to keep on getting repeat cards. That way they are basically selling you Spirit. Best price is $49.99 for 40 Orbs.Counterplay Games was set up by Keith Lee, Eric Lang etc01/10/16: The CONS kind of grinded me down after a while. Rare cards were easier to get before the Denizens patch but now it's kind of a negative feeling when you see Commons and repeats, so I'm taking a break from this game for now.06/12/16 : They stopped giving 100 gold per day and limited it at 90. The number of players have dwindled dramatically.01/02/17 : Boss Battles are included. Duelyst gives 1 free card just for logging in. They have a Bloodborn Orb business model. 300 gold for a Bloodborn Orb that has 3 unowned cards. It costs $2.99 per Orb and $19.99 for the whole Bloodborn set. I changed my review to "No". After looking at the Battle Pets, it's obvious that Duelyst has fallen into depravity and given up on the game. E.g. Slo, 0-cost 1/4 with Provoke.PROS1. Nice ArtI like the artwork a lot. Christophe Ha, former Blizzard Overwatch character concept artist, and Anton Nadeev, the environment concept artist, do pretty good work. 2. Strategic ElementPlacing your troops in different locations matter. Being 1 square away can make all the difference between losing and winning.3. Asymmetric FactionsDifferent cards, different abilities. 6 different factions, each with 2 different heroes for a total of 12 different strategies.4. PuzzlesVery fun and challenging to think about how to complete a puzzle. The daily challenge is fun to do.5. Lore on CardEach card has a tiny piece of a story. One card connects to another card. E.g. Scion's Wish to PyromancerCONS1. Pay To WinWant that specific combo deck? Pay. Best price is $49.99 for 40 Spirit Orbs. Orbs are what you call packs. Each pack has 5 "random" cards. 2. Repeat CardsIt is possible to get repeats in multiple packs as the solution is to disenchant them.3. Rarity CreepThe rare cards seriously have abilities that are far superior. One famous example used to be the Battle Sisters. For a low cost of 4, you could draw 2 Faction cards.https://i0.wp.com/cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/723013/16096031/09393fe4-32fc-11e6-9cb5-2e55deba1b32.jpg?ssl=1However, to get this card, you currently need to unlock 6 rares of the core set, which is really silly.4. No Trading SystemYou want that specific card? Pony up the cash. There is no way to trade that card.Have an excess card? You can't give/trade it away. It has no value except for disenchanting for crafting.5. Crafting SystemIt was recently implemented and did not exist in the alpha. If you want a card, you can grind your♥♥♥♥♥off getting enough spirit to craft that card. The cost for crafting is as follows.Common (White) - 40 SpiritRare (Blue) - 100 Spirit Epic (Purple) - 350 SpiritLegendary (Gold) - 900 Spirit5. GrindingTo get 1 Orb (1 pack of 5 "random" cards), you need 100 gold. It's much easier to farm than Hearthstone but it's still approximately, 1 pack per day. Normally, you would need to play at least 4 games with a specific Faction to earn 2Play 4 games with 1 Faction - 25 GoldPlay 4 games with 1 Faction - 25 GoldFirst Win of the Day - 20 GoldWelcome Back Play 3 Games - 20 GoldPuzzle Challenge - 5 Gold2 Wins Reward - 15 Gold This table should just about get you past the 100 gold limit. The crafting system mentioned earlier coupled with the ability to get repeats really dilutes the value of your cards.06/12/2016: The gold gain is no longer 100 gold per day. 01/02/2017: Gold gain is now possible with 100 gold and 1 free common card per day. 6. Imbalanced due to turn orderStarting first is usually worst, in my opinion. The system is similar to Hearthstone where you begin with 1 less mana crystal. Going first also means you are 1 step further away from the middle mana spring.7. No Neutral SpellsWhy are all the spells locked up based on faction? Why are there only neutral minions? Where are the neutral spells?8. Wasted first turnsSometimes, based on the Random Number Generator and turn order, you can't curve your cards, which means playing a 2, then a 3, then a 4 and so on and so forth. There are many times where you start out first and have no 2 cost card. Sure, you can change your strategy and wait for more mana but this feels forced instead of being a choice.9. Battle Pets [Expansion Pack]With the new expansion, Denizens of Shenizar, the RNG has been greatly increased with Battle Pets. Battle Pets attack opponents "randomly", which probably means they wrote an alogrithim for who they want to win the game.10. Mystery CratesThis is flat out gambling for skins. You get a key if you get ranked high enough or if you get buy it. It's the same thing with Team Fortress. I really dislike it.12. Super UnbalancedFirst player starts with 2 mana, second player starts with 3.After the first 3 turnsFirst player : 2+3+4 = 9 manaSecond player : 3+4+5 = 12 manaAfter the first 5 turnsFirst player : 2+3+4+5+6 = 20 manaSecond player : 3+4+5+6+7 = 25 manaAs you can see, the maths always favours the second player who also has a free mana well. What cards can be played is also limited. If you start with 2 mana, you can only ever play 2 mana cards.13. Overpowered Battle PetsThe math for the Battle Pets stats are ridiculous. It's so broken. E.g. Yun, a 3 mana 5/4 Battle Pet. Ion, a 3 mana 2/3 Battle Pet with Range, that does twice the damage to Generals. A normal 3 cost ranged unit is only 2/2 and adds 20% to summoning Mechazor.14. Hand DrawsThe game only allows you to redraw 2 out of the 5 cards. Why you can't redraw your entire hand? Just to prevent consistency? 15. Low Player PopulationIt started out with a large fanbase but it seems the fans are leaving due to issues like rarity creep.NEUTRAL1. Patch ChangesSometimes, the patches create major nerfs/buffs. E.g. Shadow Nova used to cost 7, with each Shadow Creep dealing damage equal to the number of Shadow Creep on the board. Now, it costs 4, with each Shadow Creep dealing 1 damage.I'm fine with this as games do need to be balanced but it is not a good thing.2. 2 Card to 1 Card draw per turnPersonally, I preferred the alpha version of drawing 2 cards per turn. The reason is that it is usually more difficult to do a comeback victory with just 1 card. Based on what I understand, they stopped it because the hand size limit is 6 and drawing 2 cards per turn would cause cards to overflow for certain races like Vetruvian.3. LorePersonally, I like reading it but the game doesn't emphasize the lore much.4. SkinsI like games where they sell skins instead of trying to affect the gameplay with a P2W system and rarity creep. However, in this one, there is a P2W model.SUGGESTIONS1. Price BarrierDo note that Duelyst has a paywall for competition. People who have no money can't play with a full set. They can only play with what they have grinded. 2. Final MoveIf Duelyst ever reaches a point where you realise that the paywall prevents new entrants from coming in and your player population drops to near zero, do consider this suggestion. Open up all the cards to everyone. No more rares, no more grinding, full everything. Then sell players fancy skins and animations at <$2 each to recoup. At no point must you consider creating a gameplay mechanic differential that is due to money. If you think the current business model is sustainable, then forget I ever said anything.

												Outside of the actual game, Duelyst is literally hearthstone. There's daily goals for gold, which you can spend on five-card packs or draft arena tickets. There's a constructed mode with a brutal meta. There's several different class archetypes with unique mechanics.Now, i'm a weirdo who would rather rub my face on a cheese grater than play a draft arena, so this game is absolutely not for me, and yet, i love the *idea* of it so much anyway. Duelyst looks gorgeous, sounds incredible, and the *game* part of it is genius. It's just a shame that all the parts of it that aren't gameplay are hearthstone.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												A longtime fan and player of Hearthstone, I've rejected nearly every other CCG-style strategy game on offer. Those that I chose to play, I was often met with disappointment. I'm a sucker for good pixel art, so Duelyst caught my interest. For once, I don't regret it. The gameplay is solid, the UI is wonderful, the strategy is deep. Offering a grid combat system a la Heroes of Might and Magic enables complexity of strategy while implementing tried-and-true CCG mechanics, with some twists. Give the game a shot, you have nothing to lose but a moment of your time.And if you find yourself in-game but not ready for a match, listen to the brilliantly narrated Codex. Such a treat.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												The creators put great care into making an innovative take on familiar formats. The matches are quick, and thanks to the addition of a countdown timer, fairly fast paced. The core elements of the game will be familiar to many, but Counterplay Games has interwoven familiar mechanics from previously disparate styles into a deep and challenging turn based strategy game. You may find, as you progress, that the starter cards don't hold up quite as well at the higher ranks, so expect to be buying packs if you want to become a really hardcore player. There are however, daily challenges to complete, and if you are dilligent, it is easy to earn a slow but steady stream of Spirit Orbs, the game's name for its card packs. The packs themselves seem reasonable and there is a starter pack discount if you are a new player- a good bargain and way to support the devs.All in all, Duelyst oozes with animated style, and is very tactically complex. A must play for any competitive strategy fans.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Review before 18 Feb 2017. (2nd entry)Score: 8.5/10 (+1)Commentary: 1. Its like Hearthstone, except you get to move your king and summons like a chess piece, and of course you whack your opponent's king hp to 0 to win the game.2. The game utilises movement of every units's mechanism as a core strategy, with 3 mana orb at the center of the map to be conquered or just left alone.3. Custom your card deck 40/404. Lots of hidden unlockable "Kings" with their own natural abilities that just seems OP in their own way, which is fun.5. Graphic is pixelated, spell effect makes your eye ♥♥♥♥♥♥.6. Card Abilities are creative, especially the "Range/Blast" and "Air Drop" summons excluding the classic mechanism/abilities from Hearthstone7. Paywall exists of course, content: card box & specific map access8. Comparing through the 5 card games i had played so far... this one requires the most in having more skills in strategy than RNG in drawing your cards. (partially thanks to the Card Replacement ability)9. You will start seeing an immense amount of experience differences starting rank 15, where lots of uncommon cards are involved and put into battle more frequently than you've ever seen, and the best part of the game you'd be in, is the unimaginable effects each and every card can be utilised to create the perfect destructive results.10. Fun but limited time events, including puzzle solving and reallly hard AI bosses to tackle for challenges.0. Cards are hard to grind :/

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												I've been looking for a MMO card game on PC and this is a good match! Gameplay is the usual per turn until finish pattern with mana points being the limiting factor for actions per turn. There are several sets of  cards with their unique sets of powers and abilities  chosen through different 'generals'. The cards can be mixed with other cards but limited to the generals' specific cards and neutral cards.All cards are earnable and more can be gained through IAPs in the game but it wouldn't overthrow non paying players as there's a limit to the cards one can bring to the match. So I would not call this pay-to-win. Other IAPs include emotes and skins.Duelyst gets a recommend from me but I have an initial feeling that the gameplay will become dull as the main tactic of the game is to overwhelm your opponent - not letting them have minions and the like.

												Just a side note, I've been playing since December 2015. Don't want the hours on Steam to throw anyone off, I've played this for ages and never bored of it.Everything about this game is just amazing. The artwork is incredible: every unit has a unique animation that really brings the game to life. I could try and talk about everything amazing about this game, the soundtrack, the monthly updates, the lore behind each card as well as the stories in the codex, the deck building tools, the endless combos and strategy, and most of all the ability to play competitvly with top tier decks without spending a dime, but in order to go into depth I would have to miss out on my daily quests. Just look at the other reviews. If they're saying good things about the game, (they will be) whatever they say is probably true. It's a great game, it's free, it's fun, just get it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Duelyst is THE collectible trading card video game to play right now. If you can compare it to anything, it's very similar to Hearthstone, except it comes in a nice a package that isn't packed with Blizzard ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.Positives-Cards are easy to collect. The community has proven statistically that you have a one ine four chance of getting a legendary in a pack, AKA Spirit Orbs. Spirit can also be collected to craft specific cards. Gauntlet runs (similar to Hearthstone arena) can bolster your card collection even further once you are good enough at the game.-In game gold is easy to collect. You do not have to win your daily quests, you just have to simply play the game. On top of that you earn more gold from winstreaks and simply returning from the game after a period of not playing.-A lot less RNG than Hearthstone. While there are some RNG cards, the game is mostly skill based.-The grid board, like chess rewards players with more skill. Players can also practice different kinds of board states with their daily 'Lethal Puzzle' quest, for example killing the enemy in one turn with only a certain amount of moves or cards.-Good balance design. The developers AKA Counterplay Games, aren't afraid to completely rehaul and balance the game properly. They are not stubborn unlike other video game developers. Their balance philosophy is close to Dota 2's Icefrog, where different patches and versions of the game more often than not feel like a completely new game, but not in a bad way. Each faction/class feels unique and overall viable.-The lore in this game is absolutely incredible. The writers are good enough to write their own book, as it's better than most I've read.Negatives-Even though legendary cards are easy to collect compared to other collect trading card games. You are allowed to run 3 copies of the same card in a deck you create. This means at the higher level decks will need a lot of legendaries or epics.-The community is currently relatively small to medium sized. But it is growing rapidly, and I'm sure it will with it's upcoming release on Steam. As the community is still growing, there is also no casual mode as it was removed due to dividing the already small community between casual and ranked. Howerver this mode will probably return in the future.-Graphics, if you are a fussy gamer and prefer higher quality graphics this is not your game. Though the actual artwork and animations within the game are good. The devs make the pixelated graphics work well with what they have if you're able to move pass the fact that the graphics aren't up to scratch compared to other games.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												My favorite current ccg and hopefully the new standard for other developers working in the genre.I just donwloaded the client for steam and my playtime is low here but I have actually been playing Duelyst since Beta. What your going to find here is a marriage of a chess-like tactical map and magic the gathering CCG combat. Faeria would be the closest comparision that I am aware of and while Faeria has a decent following Duelyst is easily my favorite of the two.FeaturesStrategic PostioningDeck-buildingStrong Roster of Generals and Factions to support different playstylesGenerous F2P model that allows new players to accumlate cards at a decent clipGood Player Base - quick matchmaking, decent community, support availble and advised for new players if you ask around on the forums (reddit)Active Updates - There is a constant push to make sure the game is balanced and steady influx of new cards and featuresPixel Art - Beatifully designed if you ask me and even if it's not your thing I find it hard to believe you cannot at least appreciate th amount of time and detail put in hereOn the other hand....Slow Paced Games - Can be time consuming to get through a few matches and the early learning curve can slow it down to crawl when your getting started.Tough Competition - I have seen more than a few complaints that the hardcore player base and there level of profeciency in the upper ranks makes for frustration when you are trying to climb the ladderNo Single Player - This is PVP based game and there's nothing planned as far as a campaignMonotone - At times your going to see alot of play from the same nuetral minions (as in the same 2 drop minions in  95 percent of the decks you will face) and it can get a little bit repetitive in that regard. This was my biggest gripe with the game a few months ago and seems to have improved after the last few big patches.Probably not a good fit for the casual playerIf you have played H-stone and want to graduate to a more advanced digital card game this would be high on my list of recommendations (Infinity Wars, Solforge, and few others are in the conversation as well). I am looking forward to the first major expansion at the end of the month witch may wind up pushing my score even higher.For now....8.5/10

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												So heres the deal. Ive played a lot of strategy games. Magic. - who hasnt.Yugioh. - my personal childhood favorite..hack//Enemy Trading Card Game.Gwent.Hearthstone.World of warcraft.Dragon Ball Z TCG.champions battle.Pokemon. Digimon.Dragon Dynasty TCG.Fallen Worlds TCG.HEX.D&D.Harry potter TCG. Inuyasha TCG.Naruto TCG.Yu Yu Hakusho TCG.....i might be missing some..idk... but anyways......Over the years ive aged...my gaming preferences have changed I love shooters..and RTS more than I ever have here recently, but my love for collectable card games will never die. I just so happen to barely catch a glimpse of Duelyst in the corner of my eye on the Steam store, i dont know how i havnt heard of it it yet...but this fu$*ing game is the best strategy game ive played in YEARS...years people..if you give even one ♥♥♥♥ about any of the games i listed above, you WILL download this game, Buy a couple packs of cards...they make it so easy so to even get a few free packs when youre fresh, but even a one time purchase for 10 bucks is worth it. I hope this helps somebody looking for a badass game to play casue this IS the one. Peace people.                                      -DW

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												I've been playing Duelyst for about 3 months now, ever since Scrolls closed.The game is great; one of the better digital card games I've played. Card design and art direction could use some work, but the sprite art is absolutely gorgeous. Gameplay is extremely well designed, although contains a decent amount of RNG (less than Hearthstone, thankfully). Matches unfold more like a strategy game than a card game.Progression could be better as the game is somewhat grindy, but rewards are plentiful. Crates are something of a shrug until a natural way of acquiring keys is added (the devs have stated this was planned).The most important part: the developers are constantly adjusting things, and introducing new cards. They have a full fledged streamer program, where you can register for streamer rewards (items for giveaways, and even fiscal rewards). One of the most interesting parts of the developer support is that each month they introduce four new cards. These are often fan cards, or based on media such as PennyArcade; some cards were named after popular streamers, such as The Scientist, or Grincher.If you're looking for a long-term card game, this is a great game to dive into.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												This game deserves far more credit than it gets. A very strong Hearthstone style free to play, fast paced card battler with a chess-like grid and the added depth that unit placement & movement brings to the formula. If you like card games, or turn based games you should really enjoy this one. It also has a pretty fair progression system that does not require you to spend money to be decent at the game (but of course it does not hurt to drop some cash at its feet to speed up progression). It is also worth noting that the game has very rewarding deckbuilding and tons of cards to choose from. The art and sound will not blow you away or anything but you can tell they did they best they could with the budget and time they had in making this one. They even added lots of voice acted lore and backstory to read through if you want to. Highly reccomended, just be ready to eventually hit a wall where you have to really plan, think and execute well or get your face stomped in.

												If your a hearthstone player whoA. Blames all losses on rng.B. Hates anything tempo or aggro.c. Gets easily stressed by ladder climbing.D. Cant take a break after a string of losses.Then this game is not for you. The rng is less then hearthstone yet a bit of luck can still sting you or save you in this game. This game has no casual mode to speak of. The main mode is ranked and the only other mode against players is arena. Tempo and aggro decks can feel pretty strong in this current expansion if you dont have a answer for keeping it under control. For every other lover of ccg and strategy games youll find something to love here. With small expansion sizes not taking away from the main set this game is still relatively cheap to get into.

												So I recently got myself into card games, it all started from Yu-Gi-Oh Duel Links on my phone, it was fun checking/collecting cards, winning duels, losing duels, creating personal decks or you can copy/innovate from those who post their decks online. content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Pros: good idea: MTG meets tacticle RPGGood Graphics: this looks great, I'm sure a lot of work went into designing and animating hundreds of unique sprites.It's free: I can theoretically play it and earn new cards without ever paying a cent.No chat function: The only thing worse than playing with a jerk is having them talk♥♥♥♥♥♥the whole time. This game has emotes instead which people can still use to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, but it's better.Cons:Imbalanced, Broken mana system: The first player to capture mana nodes has a exponential advantage. Also The second player ALWAYS starts in immediate reach of a node. It may be nice if the nodes were placed randomly, but I don't see that happining.Irritating f2p elements: "you got a rare chest, but you have to pay for a key to open it". I'd gladly pay full price and not have my progression hobbled. But instead the game has no price ceiling if you want to actually compete. Steep difficulty curve: I always feel underpowered when playing online because I know almost everyone I am matched up against wil just win because the put more time or money into it. When I win It always feels like luck.Frustrating: No matter how hard I try I can not seem to have any fun with this game. Even when I'm winning I am having no fun. I always seem to walk away from this game angry.I generally enjoy MTG and Yu-gi-oh. But this game seems to inherit the aspects that most turn me off of those games. It'd be nice to play a card game where you can have fun on a hobbyist level. A card game that rewards experimentation. And this is not it.Like any other TCG you're going to be stomped into paste by god monsters exploited by obsessive number crunchers. You don't get to be a novice, you're not allowed to grow in your own way, you google a build or you get wrecked.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												I've first played this in beta (~a year ago) and spent a decent amount of time and money on it playing through the standalone client.I can recommend this game if you're a casual gamer and just want to try something different, the spacial aspect of the game adds a super fun and interesting layer to deckbuilding (refreshingly non-RNG-y) and piloting, but I can not recommend this game if you don't enjoy hyper-aggressive cancer.When I last played the game, admittedly this was a couple of months ago (I did minor research for this review, nothing much at all seems changed in terms of top tier decks), I mostly played Tempo Lyonar (Argeon) and had great success with it, simply because it can outlast Burnhai and outtempo a lot of midrange decks, but sometimes due to the nature of movement and RNG, you just get burned down way too fast, you get slowed down immensely by insanely overbudgeted taunts, or other such joys. On the flipside of this, there is so much removal...games in Duelyst constructed often feel like a seesaw of tempo, massive swings in either direction all of the time. Personally, the absolutely mental stat budgets were the biggest dealbreaker, and made the game feel very poorly balanced. There are some nice archetypes in the game, but they're usually either ineffective or super cheesy. Gauntlet (arena) felt awful, for the stat budgets exacerbate the imbalance between classes in arena even more, I have both flown through virtually unopposed and been crushed like a bug, with little to no possible consistency, worse than in any other TCG I have played (HS, ES:L, Eternal, Magic Duels).If you'd like to play a game with a good ingame(!)-community, with a nice new spin on the genre but a TON of gimmicks, give this a try.Did I enjoy myself to a level that matches my spending? Not really, I found the experience hugely unpleasant overall.

												Get a crate containing cards as a reward for a mission or quest. Try to open it, don't have a key. Where to get a key? Buy one with real money. Its a typical mmo tgp. Unless you want to pay real money, the pro's and con's, goods and bads all these reviews are filled with, just smoke and mirrors. Sure you'll have fun playing matches in the lowest rank tier, but once you get into the next tier unless you want to pay money, you'll lose so much more than you'll win. content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Duelyst has great pixel art. Unfortunately that is about where the positives stop.The reward systems have forever been in constant flux, presumably with both new player retention and sustainable monetisation being the goal. Every change they make to these systems seems to have no impact on the former whilst also annoying existing players to no end.The gameplay seems to become less focussed on interactivity with every patch. It almost doesn't even matter that the game is played on a board at this point.In Duelyst, cards have effects that can be faction specific, affecting or not affecting cards within a certain faction. There are multiple factions in Duelyst. There are no indicators on the cards stating what faction they are from. Slightly less condemning, although condemning nonetheless, are that the cards have no indicator for what set/expansion they originate from. This is not as much of an issue within the deck builder, but it is an issue during gameplay.I feel I have given this game a good run and would not recommend it at all.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												LET'S TALK ABOUT PRICING. Duelyst has a lot of nice stuff to like about it. I know a lot of people are used to F2P games; I am not. These prices are silly. Let's look at them.Duelyst Micro-transaction Prices:40 card packs - $50Emote Packs - $13 eachGeneral Skins - $8 eachCard Backs - $4 each Profile Pictures - $3 eachLet's compare those prices to some full games. Steam is full of B2P (buy to play) games that are reasonably priced, get cheaper over time, and don't have hidden costs down the line. There are competitive multiplayer games in B2P that are very replayable too, not just short single player games. Entire Full Games (sale prices):AAA games 1-2 yrs old ~ $30Chaos Reborn - $7XCom EU Complete - $10 XCom 2 Digital Deluxe - $40. Also has an often overlooked VS MP mode.Disgaea 1 PC - $15Civ V Complete ~ $15100% Orange Juice with all DLC ~ $11Minecraft - $27 (Doesn't go on sale?)Misc Indie Stuff Everywhere - $3-$7 Duelyst has huge "microtransactions" that are each larger than many B2P games. If Duelyst was B2P, it would probably be $15, and maybe get one or two $10 optional DLC expansions. Both the base game and DLC would go on sale too. Because Duelyst is F2P, it costs $$$$$ to get everything. Please compare F2P games to B2P games you already own (free!) and B2P games you could buy instead.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												The starter pool of cards is decent and can carry you quite a ways. A lot of the achievements will give you legendaries and there are plenty of cards to unlock through leveling.It's a fun game, but honestly has the same problem all these games have.  There is no option to buy into what you want to play.  You have to go through this slot machine system, that is essentially gambling or wasting massive amounts of time. Basically if you're playing F2P, expect to spend >50 hours of top tier play to grind enough 'spirit' to craft a deck you want to play.  Or you can gamble your money away and break down pack after pack to craft what you want.  Still going to spend quite a lot of money to do so and at the mercy of RNG.  I'll put it to you like this.  If you're looking for a time waster, something fun and skillful, but still decided by RNG. This is a fun game to play for a few matches a day.However... it's designed so that you hit a barrier and want to spend money. Once you've got those 10 or so achievement legendaries, they get real scarce.  So you're stuck grinding out the randomness of draft so you can finally get a deck you want to play. I'm actually going to uninstall it now, because I don't appreciate being strung along and manipulated.  This monetization method lacks the base integrity to put a price on a product and thrives because there are so many fools who throw money at it.    The time to grind is needlessly inflated to extend in game time while a 'buy stuff' button is put in our face.  TL;DR: F2P needs infinite patience. P2P needs infinite money.

content:
Posted: February 1
												As both a turn-based strategist and card game lover Duelyst really does fuse both of these elements together in an extremely enjoyable fashion.Duelyst is a card game with a twist - instead of your monsters lining up akin to a game of dodgeball, Played on a 9 by 5 board the object (like most card games) is to reduce your opposing general's health to zero. However instead of just being a number, your general is a monster on the board, capable of moving and attacking (they begin with an attack value, something other card games don't offer).Starting play begins with you drawing 5 cards, and the option to exchange 2 of them immediately. The player going first begins with 2 mana crystals while the player going second begins with 3 (maximum of 9). You may play as many cards per turn as you can afford, as well as exchange 1 card per turn in an effort to find what you need. Cards are split into 3 types: Monsters, who are summoned next to either your general or another monster (so positional play is very important), Spells and Artifacts (items you equip to your general, up to a maximum of 3, that can be destroyed once your general is damaged 3 times while wearing it). You only play cards on your opponents turn, and card drawing is done at the end of the turn allowing you to strategise and plan your next turn more effectively. There are 8 factions, all who contain 2 different general options, that have differing playstyles depending on if you wish to brute force your opponent with creatures (Magmar) or sneakily sap their life force away (Songhai).The main reason I feel the game is excellent is the ability to exchange cards, both initial hand and each turn) as well as the grid allowing for a more in-depth strategy meaning a single misplaced monster at the wrong time will ruin your whole game!

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												Duelyst is a 1v1 card game that also utilizes a full map to add more strategy and planning. The learning curve is not that steep, after the tutorial I pretty much played about 3 practice games to learn a deck, then a few solo challenges to learn other aspects of the game like unit abilities, spells, buffs, and debuffs. After that I felt confident enough to dive right into ranked to play other people. The ingame visuals took me by surprise as your generals/minions/spells are all fully animated in gorgeous pixelated art. As a F2P it is forgiving to the player as you can earn a lot of the card packs and other in game content just by playing. As for what I think could be improved, it could use a difficulty setting in practicing against the computer. If I'm trying to build the perfect deck to play in ranked I would want harder AI to experiment on. Also it could use an ingame chat so you could talk to your opponent as all you can do right now is use emotes or phrases. But looking at how well recieved this title has been so far, I wouldn't be surprised if it rivals other up and coming card games like Elder Scrolls Legends or Gwent.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												One of the better online 'card' games out there. Great RNG mitigation mechanics built in to the system itself. Plays very creature/minion heavy (ie. Hearthstone) but with the addition of the tactical board there are a lot more interesting decisions to be made. Each faction feels unique and has different Generals that change playstyles. The addition of daily challenges (lethal puzzles), a solo challenge campaign, and tons of voiced lore round out the package. Speaking of lore, the pixel art is beautiful and brings out the character of the cards. Each card is uniquely animated. As a free to play game, there are many opportunities to gain currency for cards, as well as quests that give you rare and legendary cards for free. Compared to Hearthstone, the Gauntlet (Arena) is easier to go infinite as well (because of better rewards).

content:
Posted: February 1
												As both a turn-based strategist and card game lover Duelyst really does fuse both of these elements together in an extremely enjoyable fashion.Duelyst is a card game with a twist - instead of your monsters lining up akin to a game of dodgeball, Played on a 9 by 5 board the object (like most card games) is to reduce your opposing general's health to zero. However instead of just being a number, your general is a monster on the board, capable of moving and attacking (they begin with an attack value, something other card games don't offer).Starting play begins with you drawing 5 cards, and the option to exchange 2 of them immediately. The player going first begins with 2 mana crystals while the player going second begins with 3 (maximum of 9). You may play as many cards per turn as you can afford, as well as exchange 1 card per turn in an effort to find what you need. Cards are split into 3 types: Monsters, who are summoned next to either your general or another monster (so positional play is very important), Spells and Artifacts (items you equip to your general, up to a maximum of 3, that can be destroyed once your general is damaged 3 times while wearing it). You only play cards on your opponents turn, and card drawing is done at the end of the turn allowing you to strategise and plan your next turn more effectively. There are 8 factions, all who contain 2 different general options, that have differing playstyles depending on if you wish to brute force your opponent with creatures (Magmar) or sneakily sap their life force away (Songhai).The main reason I feel the game is excellent is the ability to exchange cards, both initial hand and each turn) as well as the grid allowing for a more in-depth strategy meaning a single misplaced monster at the wrong time will ruin your whole game!

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												Jedyna innowacyjna karcianka jaka kiedykolwiek powstała. Łączy mechanikę walki znaną z takich gier jak Heroes of Might and Magic (Popularni przecież u nas "Herosi 3") czy king's bounty z zaawansowaną karcianką. Naszą armią są po prostu karty, których używajac wstawiamy naszego podpoiecznego do gry lub używamy na nim czaru. Dzięki temu gre docenią zarówno fani karcianek, którzy lubią spędzać dziesiątki godzin na tworzeniu własnej, niepokonanej talii, ale również miłośnicy gier turowych czy wręcz gatunku RTS, którzy cenią rozgrywką opartą o pozycjonowanie i przewidywanie ruchów przeciwnika na polu bitwy. Gra jest warta spróbowania, a przepiękna, moim zdaniem, oprawa audiowizaulna łącząca pixel art, chiptune i "nowoczesny" szlif pomoże nam wsiąknąć do tej gry na wiele, wiele godzin. Dodatkowo wraz z jej wejściem na Steam, wykorzystuje ona od teraz portfel Steam, dzięki czemu za fundusze które uzyskamy poprzez rynek możemy dokonywać mikrotranskacji w grze. W grze która na rynku gier karcianych ma aktualnie najbardziej zdrowe podejście do tej sprawy. Oczywiście nie można stwierdzić, że mikrotranskajce nie istnieją, ponieważ znajdują się jak w każdej grze f2p, lecz ich uciążliwość w porównaniu do tego co serwuje Blizzard w Hearthstone jest znikoma. Brakuje tutaj dodatków dostępnych tylko za pieniądze, nie będziemy też płacić za żadne dodatkowe ekspansje, a kiedy tylko mamy ochotę możemy sprzedać naszego "kałacha", "czapeczkę" czy "itemek" z którejś inej gry wykorzystującej rynek i wykupić za nie dodatkowe rzeczy w Duelyst. Bardzo zdrowa, przepiękna i posiadająca miłe community gra, którą tworzy dość niezależne studio posiadające pasję w tym co robią. Nic tylko zasiadać do gry i ślinić się do pixelów, uśmieżających ból po tym jak przeciwnikowi siądą do ręki wszytskie karty które chciał. Bo przecież, chyba o to tutaj chodzi. O symulator frustrtacji okraszony przepiękną grafiką. Polecam z całego serca!(Moja liczba przegranych godzin może być bardzo niska, ponieważ gra jest dostępna w wersji non-steam i taka też była od czasu powstania. Miejmy nadzieję, że pokazanie się jej w tym serwisie tylko p
