number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Mix Fire Emblem with Hearthstone, and you'll get Duelyst, a fairly rewarding F2P tactics card game.You start with a series of basic tutorials aimed to ge you acquainted with to in-game interface, after which you'll be able to challenge the AI to unlock other factions in practice matches, and the solo  challenges. Solo challenges are puzzle like situations, each with a new twist to introduce you to the different game elements. I recommend prioritizing these challenges as they definitely provided me with the most fun as a new player.Pros:+Unlike traditional card games, Duelyst's board provides a new depth to the gameplay.+The ability to replace a card from your hand with another from your deck each turn, which helps providing some consistency to your deck and allows you to dig for answers, and not just be at the mercy of the draw.+Quests are completed by simply playing rather than forcing you to win, allowing you to learn.+Great soundtracks and gorgeous backgrounds.+The drop rates for high rarity cards is very generous, and you can easily get a pack/orb a day due to rewarding the gold system is.+/- Pixelated characters/units: I don't love nor hate pixel art, but I can say this to you if you hate it: The gameplay's suspense will make the pixels hardly matter.Cons:-A steep difficulty curve-Overpriced Cosmetics (They have no effect on the gameplay though)-Matches are sometimes mentally exhausting, rather than enjoyable.Overall, Duelyst is a fresh take on digital card games that is worth trying out, even if only just to complete the solo challenges.Side Note: Starting players can get a 100 extra gold when they sign-up by entering a referal code, so if you have a friend who plays Duelyst, ask them for their code. Alternatively, you can use mine: eyehaveyou

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												Duelyst is a game I discovered not long before it went into Open Beta.It caught me by surprise with how good it was in nearly all aspects.The pixel animations are amazing and the creature design, variety and spell effects are very well done. The game itself is very simple to understand using a combination of CCG mechanics to summon creatures onto the board and a grid based tactics system for combat. There's multiple character/factions to choose from each having different selections of cards and mechanics available. You unlock the basic cards for each of these but earning there first few levels and then get more cards from booster packs which can be bought using in game currency. The game features quests to earn currency based rewards and there's a section of puzzles for you to figure out which will really help you learn the game. These are done by being given a pre built hand, creatures on the board and enemies already in place. You are given a single turn to win the game. It's a very cool puzzle mode and it really helps you in the main game as maximising your plays. I highly recommend the game if you like CCG or tactic based games. There's a whole lotta game here. If you would like to see more of the basic gameplay I have a video available that will show the game just before it went into Open Beta before Steam launch. I hope you find this helpful.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												I've been playing this game since closed beta, having playing it almost for a year as of now...And all I can say is that it is the best CCG I have played in my entire life, by far. It combines chess elements with card game ones in order to become a tactical experience that is so immersive and deep. Despite the presence of some RNG elements that can make you feel really angry, skill plays the major role in this game, due to the presence of a living board. Positiniong means quite everything in Duelyst, so you have to think carefully about each of your steps. 												Meh... overall it is a good game, pure turn-based strategy! However there are a few things that can stress you out, for example:-it happened to me more than once that at the very start of the game I had only spells in my hand (with a default deck) and even the following cards where still spell type... it should have some rule sets to always give you at least 2 random minions at every start...-the starting hands should be more balanced for both players... each player should not have a better starting hand than the other...-when you replace a card it will often come back after you end your turn and draw...-the matchmaking is horrible, I've sprinted thru ranks 30 to 20 without a single loss! And now at rank 18 I'm facing against opponents with higher tier cards... me being a beginner I can't face against opponents who have grinded for god knows how many hours...-some cards could use some more balancing...-cash shop has an option for buying more cards which kinda makes the game pay-to-win... there is a thing called "spirit orb" which contains 5 random cards, from these 5 it guarantees a random rare card OR BETTER... for 50 bucks you cand get 40 of these so yeah...-crafting is forcing you to focus on a single faction and overuse it for hours...-art style is kinda weird at first, but I got used to it... also the sounds and music in this game are not that great...-note you can download this game outside of steam! You can't login with your steam account on the duelyst forums but others can login with their game account?!And I think thats all the negatives I can remember for now... despite all that I still like this game, its very competitive! I know I'll get some hate for saying this but I think Duelyst beats Hearthstone! So if you're wondering what to play then you should give this game a chance.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												Before I start, I'd like to say that I play a lot of TCGs, some of them work well on PC (as opposed to physical cards IRL), some don't...so far I've only ever played ONE other TCG that was designed specifically for PC (i.e. that wouldn't work as an IRL card game) that I really enjoyed, in its current state this game is exctremely good but without playing it for longer I'm unsure as to whether or not it'll get boring after extended play.Now for the actual Review:Duelyst is an excellent TCG-style strategy game which, unlike many other free-to-play games in this genre manages to handle microtransactions in a fair way.While there's a lot of cosmetic items such as emotes and re-skins available exclusively for cash, none of these give an advantage within the game.Card packs are available for cash but are simply a way to obtain cards slightly faster than through normal gameplay (and they're priced a little outside of the range of people with a "I'll just buy 1000 packs to get every card" mentallity), how quickly you can earn card packs through gameplay is dependant on how well you play, whether or not you decide to clear the single-player "puzzle" challenges, etc. Though you should be able to earn 2-4 packs per day if you play for 1-2 hours.after 2 hours of play I had enough "spare" cards to sell and buy any common or semi-common card I wanted.The game has a focus on player-vs-player matches as opposed to single player vs the AI (though this IS still an option), The matches are very strategic, though the escalating stats of higher-cost cards makes lower-cost cards near-useless after just a few turns, which makes matches more and more luck-based the longer they play out.Cards are split into 3 types: essentially these traditional TCG cards: units, equipment and spells.Matches take place on a grid, players summon units onto spaces within range of their hero or other units, each turn each unti may move up to 2 spaces and then attack an adjacent enemy.Equipment cards boost your hero in various ways, but have durabillity which is lost when your hero takes damage.Spell cards have various effects which directly affect the match, units, equipment, etc.Good bits:An retro graphical style with good animations and varied card designs.Not pay-to-win.Balanced starter decks and factions with unique strategies that give advantages to people that can plan and strategise as opposed to people with "better" cards.Bad bits:High-cost cards tend to be exponentially stronger than low-cost ones, making long matches lean in favor of whoever gets luckiest in drawing their highest cost cards.The cosmetic items in the cash shop are absurdly expensive for what they are.No "story" mode currently (the cards are filled with lore which seems wasted without a storyline to go with it)Overall 7/10 in its current state. Worth trying but many people will be put off by the lack of true single-player experience.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												Despite the only 1.2 hours put in this game on Steam, I played this game quite a bit before. Duelyst is a great all-around game. The graphics are very pleasing, with very nice character attacks and board a e s t h e t i c s. Additionally, there are more than enough cards to truly your deck your own, with more cards being added every update. The business model is great, as you don't need to purchase anything as gold for packs is given quite frequently, and you always get amazing pulls every pack. The crafting sysytem is also very fair, giving even new players the option to craft any deck no matter how early they are in the game. All around, this game is a very nice F2P, strategic card game.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												like turn based strategy games (fire emblem, ff tactics)? like card games (hearthstone, mtg)? like cool pixel art? then you will love this gameive played this a ton in the off steam beta after playing a fair amount if Hearthstone but ever since ive found this i stopped Hearthstone completely. this game is just so much nicer and more about skill than rng since you not onyl have to draw your cards and make your decks, but you also have to control where your monsters go and how they move/attack which is nice. the game is also SO generous with its card pulls and gold giving, like in hearthstone you could open 20 packs and get maybe 2 epics but in this game ive gotten multiple legendaries and epics from 10 packs. gold is also given out a lot and there are a bunch of one turn kill puzzles that teach you the game and give tons of gold for packs so buying packs isnt really nescessary but tbh i think this game is so great so i dont mind supporting the devs. the game overall is fantastic compared to other ccg games. like i am not that great at it but i still enjoy playing it, even when it gets frustrating (which it definitely does)

												Okay.  I'm recommending this game because I love BUT there is a thing that I have to say.  This game is an 8/10.  The only problem I have with it is like any card game: its P2W. 												I've never played any other card game growing up religiously except for Pokemon, I even bought the video game for Gameboy so I could play alone. Duelyst brings alot of that back to me. content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												Duelyst it is “free to play” and NOT "pay to win", which is a major advantage.It is one of the best card games I have played. Some cards and mechanics are similar to Hearthstone, but the "board" with units and generals gives another layer to the game. It makes this game much more versatile many different approaches are viable. Obviously you won't get the perfect deck with basic cards, but:- It is relatively easy to get booster packs finishing the daily challenges- Gauntlet (similar to Arena in Hearthstone) makes you draw a random deck each time and it doesn’t depend on your own collection. This rewards you with guaranteed boosterpack and more.- The paid items are either pure cosmetics or booster packs which you can earn playing daily. Last but not least, the game has a great "tutorial" section that learns you basic mechanics while solving the "one turn kill combos".Disclaimer: I have played a lot of Duelyst before the steam version was avaliable.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Duelyst is an interesting take on CCGs. It introduces a 9x5 grid, adding a new dimension of complexity onto the standard model. The resulting game is something like a blend of Hearthstone and Final Fantasy Tactics. Fans of both games will find comfort here. Units move across a board to combat other units, making positioning a key element to success. The units themselves have mechanics in accord with the standard CCG. As well as its unique gameplay, Duelyst features a distinctive art style. Hand-drawn portraits and landscapes are put alongside some of the most well-done pixel art I've seen. In terms of gameplay, Duelyst is quite accessible. Players spend in-game currency on card packs to build a deck. The gold acquisition rate is quite generous--players will find it fairly easy to earn a pack a day in about 45 minutes of play. Along with generous gold gain, the packs themselves are very charitable on drops. On average, a player can expect a Legendary (highest card rarity) in 1 of 4 packs. This alleviates the new player's problem of card scarcity, and encourages continuous play.

Posted: August 30, 2016
												Duelyst is new and exciting and I put this down to a number of things:It's extremely well ballanced with only 1 or 2 meta strats prevailing and even then, they can be beaten. Some of that comes down to luck of the draw in who you play and what cards you have on hand.OP isn't a thing and there's always a way to win. Even the rarest cards only help you slightly more, they're half about improving decks and part about rewarding yourself with cool cards for doing well.The design is amazing and cards don't let you down. In-game skins are pricey but can be won through hard work or cheaper purchases of keys if you find chests.I easily logged 16 hours with my brothers over the last week trying to beat each other's monthly rank. Overall the game has a friendly competitive nature to it and is great to play at any time. It feels family friendly but mature and I hope that it stays ballanced and fun. The PVP is great, losing a battle to a deck that counters yours is frustrating but the next match you might edge the next guy. It's like a big rock paper scissors mixed with custom chess.P.S. PLEASE DONT DO A CARDS AND CASTLES!!! For me this game is top of it's league at the moment, beats all it's rivals and those that came before.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Duelyst is an interesting take on CCGs. It introduces a 9x5 grid, adding a new dimension of complexity onto the standard model. The resulting game is something like a blend of Hearthstone and Final Fantasy Tactics. Fans of both games will find comfort here. Units move across a board to combat other units, making positioning a key element to success. The units themselves have mechanics in accord with the standard CCG. As well as its unique gameplay, Duelyst features a distinctive art style. Hand-drawn portraits and landscapes are put alongside some of the most well-done pixel art I've seen. In terms of gameplay, Duelyst is quite accessible. Players spend in-game currency on card packs to build a deck. The gold acquisition rate is quite generous--players will find it fairly easy to earn a pack a day in about 45 minutes of play. Along with generous gold gain, the packs themselves are very charitable on drops. On average, a player can expect a Legendary (highest card rarity) in 1 of 4 packs. This alleviates the new player's problem of card scarcity, and encourages continuous play.

content:
Posted: February 8
												I've played a lot of these online card games. Legend in Hearthstone, Rank 1 in Elder Scroll Legends, Diamond in Eternal; and despite how fun some of those games were, none of them have matched Duelyst for me.Duelyst is probably the most visually attractive of any of the current online card games, and, at a glance, has one of the better UIs (which, if you've been playing online card games like I have, you'll recognize as a rarity for the genre.)I will note, I haven't been good at Duelyst (or even really played it) for around a year, so I don't feel comfortable commenting on balance. When I was heavy into it however (S Rank for a couple seasons) it was reasonably well balanced compared to other offerings of the genre, and well supported by the developer. Additionally the grind isn't as bad as Hearthstone (in my opinion, anyways), nor is it as dull as Eternal's endless march of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ commons before you get to anything useful.All in all, I would say Duelyst is one of the best, if not the best online card games out there right now.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
A collectible tactics game whose rarefied mechanical design makes for fast-paced matches brimmed with strategic depth.Duelyst, Hearthstone and Scrolls (the Mojang game, not the Elder Scrolls one) would fight for a slot of my leisure time almost every other day. The battle is usually close but it is Duelyst that often comes out alive.The biggest problem with Hearthstone is that it is 70% deckbuilding and 30% actually playing. Once you build a deck, all you're doing in the match is following your deck's recipe. There are only a few meaningful decisions to make during a match. Most of the time you know within a few seconds what cards to play. Yes, predicting the composition of your opponent's deck and calculating the probabilities of your and your opponent's next card draw will increase the likelihood of you winning, but that much brain power yields diminishing returns. You could literally play the match drunk and still do reasonably well.Duelyst, on the other hand, makes playing the match as important as deckbuilding and the match itself is every bit as complex. Every turn in the match has many meaningful decisions, many options that actually changes the state of the game, many highly impactful choices that require proportionally high brain power for you to reveal them. Every turn is like a puzzle with a time-limit: Can you calculate the lethal before your turn ends? Was there even a lethal? Did you just allow your opponent to setup a lethal? The brain power you put into Duelyst matches does not yield diminishing returns as quickly as it does in Hearthstone. And what's even better is that the game is still easy to learn and the average match length hits the sweet-spot of 12 minutes (this statistic was taken from the dev and in my experience is true). Of course all this means you can't play Duelyst drunk the way you can play Hearthstone drunk and still do okay. So in that regard Hearthstone is better.Now on to Duelyst versus Scrolls. Duelyst's sweet-spot of 12 minutes is what makes it superior to Scrolls. Scrolls have positioning similar (ehh, somewhat) to Duelyst but also have a countdown based attack system where minions only attack after every X turn. Essentially this means there are two major indirect synergies, relative position and synchronized attacks, to worry about on top of the direct ones as defined on the cards themselves. Dude, this is a lot to take in! No wonder it takes 30 minutes to finish a Scrolls match. It would've been okay if the moment to moment happenings of those 30 minutes were interesting, but sometimes it feels like a drag. Duelyst, with positioning being the only major indirect synergy, does not feel this way. Despite this knock on Scrolls, its saving grace is that it has the greatest deckbuilding interface and feature set in a card game that I have ever seen. It makes deckbuilding an absolute joy. Duelyst unfortunately copied Hearthstone's terrible deckbuilding UX.To put all this in a nice equation: Duelyst > Scrolls >> Hearthstone.

Duelyst is a board game / collectible card game hybrid that combines the customizable aspects of CCGs with the strategy and movement of a board game.Key FeaturesPixel Graphics - Masterfully crafted pixaleted character sprites evoke a sense of nostalgia.Tons of Cards to Collect - Hundreds of cards will keep you collecting for a long time. Gotta catch 'em all!Factions - Significant level of variety in the way you play through a multiple general choices for each faction.Challenge Mode - Practice your skills in class-specific puzzles and master the tactics and gimmicks for each situation.Ranked Ladder - Climb over the bodies of hundreds of enemies to become the very best.ConsCosmetics are overpriced, especially the emotes but not buying them has no effect on gameplay, so just ignore them and you're good.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												All the addiction and strategy of YuGiOh or Magic, combined with a bit of chessboard.  Its fun and engrossing and you keep finding yourself wanting to play more to unlock more cards and develop a stronger army.  I'm reminded a tiny bit of Unholy War, one of my old time favorites, but it's not quite that.Its a game that does well everything it sets out to do... and its free!  Hard to argue with!I've clocked some 80 hours into the game in my first month of playing it.  Now, that's harder to judge time than most games, because that's not pure playing time, but also looking at all the cards available and editing your own decks... so its easy to sink a lot of casual reading time in.  Which is fine!I've seen some negative reviews complaining that the game is pay to win, and that's just not true.  Maybe if you want to be absolute top of the pack S+ tier pro level and compete with people that have been playing for two years, sure, but even the raw base cards are pretty good and dependable regulars that can carry you through the starting ranks of the game without much trouble.  The game is pretty generous with in-game currency and starter quests... it'll just give you a few free packs for playing through all the tutorial challenges and early easily achievable things.  After that, if you just play regularly, there's bonuses like first win of the day, win two games, welcome back bonus, and easy challenges like "destroy five minions" and "do 40 damage" that will very easily net you 100+ coins every two days or so, enough to easily buy another pack or attempt the gauntlet challenge.  And if you can get your skills up enough to participate and win in gauntlet mode, you earn even more cards and coins.  If you can make it to even the second game rank, you'll get free cards at the start of the month.  Plus, whatever cards you dont like you can grind up to make other cards.You can buy packs to speed things up, yes, but just playing will get you the same rewards in fairly short order.   After clocking in 40 hours on the game I tossed 10$ at it to get a few packs, but that was more to support the game I'd been enjoying  than anything else.... and the results of those packs were the same as what I'd been getting for free...  just a chunk of them all at once. I would have gotten the same rewards from just playing another two weeks.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
Highly-polished collectable card game with a twist of Grid-based-Strategy-RPG mechanics. Has tons of cards to collect, and awesome pixel-art animated graphics.Tip for new players: Use a referral code to get 100 free gold. My code is losingstreak - Just click "Friends" on the bottom-right corner of the main menu, click on "claim a friend's referral code" and input losingstreak to get your 100 free gold. (only applicable if you have not yet played ranked/ladder)Pros and cons:Pros:+Not P2W: Gold is fairly easy to earn - making it fairly easy to advance and make a competitive deck without having to buy packs using real money+Six factions to play that each have their own unique strategies and skills +Faction-specific cards and tons of non-faction-specific neutral cards add a lot of variety and depth to deck-making+Draft mode that gives good rewards (similar to Arena in Hearthstone)+Much less RNG than Hearthstone (if you hate Yogg, you'll like this one)+Good music and awesome pixel-art animated graphics+Can reconnect if you disconnect mid-match; just don't take too long or the game will automatically concede for youCons:-Games can drag on especially if the enemy is turtling or roping-Practice duels with friends do not give any reward or progression-Cannot chat with other players in a match, you can only use preset emotes and quotesBonus Tips for free stuff:~Duel with a friend to get a one-time-only free pack~Play with each faction atleast once to get a free random-faction legendary card

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Duelyst is definitely one of the strongest contenders in the wake of Hearthstone's invigoration of CCG video games. The addition of the positional component makes each game play out in more interesting ways (at least in the middle tiers). The ability to exchange a card every round and a fixed mana curve makes the game feel much more in your control. It also makes each match play out pretty quickly, making it easy to dip in for a quick game. The flip side is that it feels like the meta requires the decks to be very aggressively tuned to the curve in the higher ranks. The starter decks will quite easily carry you into silver rank, and you can craft many decent budget decks from wins, so there's no pay-to-win pressure like in some of the CCG clones popping up on mobile. Well worth checking out if you enjoy CCGs or customizable board games.

content:
Posted: January 29
												I LOVE what this game is trying to do, I love card games and I love tactical games so this should be great right?well, it is, each deck plays different and it even borrows heavely from hearthstone and relies on luck, but it also tries to minimize luck with some interesting redraw mechanics. Also, kind of like hearthstone, each deck plays a little bit different and that coupled ith the movement of the cards on the battlefield make from a very enjoyable game that it manages to feel fresh every time you switch decks.Did I mention it has card puzzles? I love puzzles, and this game has card puzzles, and they are pretty cool.So... why dont I recommend it? simple: like most collectible card games its nature is... 100% pay to win. The strategy side kind of balances things out at first, but not enough in my opinion. Also the way it tries to sell you things is pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥, I dont mind buying card packs but why are there limited time cardpacks? why are there free boxes that require premium keys to unlock? why do you give them to me and then tell me that if I dont buy the key in 48 hours it dissapears?Also, besides rare cards that have incredible value, the balance between factions and even between leaders of the same faction leaves a little to be desired, but I cant hold that much against it.TL;DR: This is a fun game and I WOULD recommend you to try it out, but I dont recommend giving it a penny in its current state

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24
												NOTICE: I only have 46.7 hours on the steam client but I have been playing since the beta before the steam release.With that out of the way let me say that I am utterly and completely in love with this game. Duelyst blends classic card game mechanics of hearthstone with an almost chess like board. The level of depth in this game will leave you speachless. An active community and active developers that listen to the community and try there best to make changes based off of voices from the player base creates for an adapting and always changing intense strategy game. I've played numerous card games (Hearthstone, MTG, and shadowverse to name a few) and Duelyst is by far my favorite. highly reccomend you try it if your not sure whether or not you will like it.

Posted: October 13, 2016
												Incredibly satisfying depth and gameplay in this "card" game. Takes elements from Hearthstone, MTG and others, but the tile based board really adds another layer of strategy.I don't know why people whinge about the F2P elements.. its fairly easy to grind out a deck that'll take you to silver tier or higher, at that point wouldn't it be perfectly reasonable to spend a few $ on some keys or packs to craft out the rarer cards?Can't please everyone I guess! If you want more depth than Hearthstone (which I found got boring and too much RNG), give this one a try!

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												Find this review useful? Would greatly appreciate it if you would refer me! This referral code will also give you 100 gold! My code is ngelicdark - just click "Friends" on the bottom-right corner of the main menu, click on "claim a friend's referral code" and type ngelicdark to get your 100 free gold. (Only applicable if you have not yet played ranked/ladder).And to keep this review honest, I kickstarted Duelyst back in 2014. I was hoping to get a Fire Emblem-esque game but PvP. And I was greatly impressed back then as I am now. Actually, even moreso now.Now for the review:Pros:-It's a wonderful iteration of tactics style rpg combat made for a MMO audience. That is pretty darn rare considering the best PvP scenario with this type of gameplay was Fire Emblem or Advance Wars, and that was uncommon outside of Japan.-Easy to get into. Harder to master. That's right, there's depth to the combat mechanics!-The art was as beautiful and charming. It's a blend of pixel and something akin to cellshading. The music is also soothing and I find that the summon blips, swings, grunts to be spot on.-The devs are faithful, the devs work hard, and the devs listen. It's come a long way since alpha and beta back in the day. The new factions are balanced and the additional heroes to the factions are different enough to twist a general gameplay style.-F2P? Casual? No problem. The game is very generous with giving out gold and thus, cards (and it was a lot easier getting legs here than it was in Hearthstone) -Legs are not as influential as they are in HS. Most of them are not as efficient in terms of value as are lower cards. Plus, they tend to be higher mana cost cards, meaning you won't see 2 drops giving a good chunk of momentum with effects you can't mirror unless you own those cards.-Once a day daily puzzles. Do you remember "checkmate in one turn" puzzles? I do. I loved them as a kid. Still do now. And if you don't have the patience for it, then someone can easily give you the solution. But where's the fun in that?-Tight knit community. I find this a plus: if you need help, you can easily find it on the official forums as well as the subreddit. -The game feels balanced compared to other TCGs I've mingled with, IRL and online.-Disenchanting a leg for much needed dust early in the game to make basic decks is not as painful as it is in Hearthstone. For most, it's actually recommended.Cons:-It's still a collectible card game. If you tire of collecting packs then it's not your cup of tea.-There's a crate system in the game. You'll have a random chance of finding said crates after a game but you'll have to pay money in order to open them. It's only for cosmetics though so you're not missing much by not being able to open them.-UI seems a little clunky at first. I'm being nitpicky, but it bugs me when I have to buy cards in a different window in order to open said packs.Tips:-The Duelyst subreddit has a list of the hidden achievements available. Google it, thank me later.-Get all the factions to level 10. Don't focus on one. When you'll need to branch out later, you'll be hard pressed to compete with others of your ranking since you didn't get the second general unlocked or the extra copies of the common (and usually necessary) cards of the typical budget deck.And of course, hope to see more people join the ranks! I hope you guys enjoyed this review!

												DO NOT THROW YOUR MONEY AND TIME INTO THIS GAME. Voice of experience here. I've played a tremendous amount of competitive card games in my time. Magic, Yu-Gi-Oh, Hearthstone, VS System, Pokemon, you name it.  NONE of them are as PAY TO WIN as this game.  I've climbed my way to about half way up the ranking system (by the way, EVERY pvp match in this game is ranked) and hit an absolute brick wall of people spamming hard to find super rares (purple and orange rares, think Mythic rares in Magic the Gathering) which there is little to nothing you can do about with a regular deck.  IF you can take out those creatures or counter the effects, it usually takes a 2-3 card combo to do so, which just puts you in a weaker position for next turn.  It's pathetic. I wish I had my time back.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												I thought I had left a review around 40 hours. My bad. Well this game can defintiely be time consuming, in a good way. There's many different ways to play and there's many different ways to build decks, even within the ways to play. The placement of your cards is also very important, which is usually looked over for many games from what I have seen. Since it's free to play, I'd just say download it and give it a whirl. It won't cost you anything except a bit of time, which you obviously have if you're reading reviews looking for a new game to play. The only downsides I really see are how expensive cards are to buy (in my opinion, based on the fact that it's a virtual card game with no real way to sale your assets back to cash), the fact that some opening hands are just unbeatable, no matter what you're playing or how many times you mulligan, and the balance issue of some cards. That last part is usually fixed my the dev's relatively quickly, which is another way of saying the dev's listen to the community and statistitcs of certain cards.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												In a nutshell duelyst is like chess played with cards.I'll make comparisons with hearthstone to better describe the main meat of the game. Please dont take this as "duelyst is better" or "hearthstone is better" , i think both games are very distinct and great experiences, while my point is that duelyst is really easy to get into and enjoy a wide variety of decks(gameplay). I wanted to emphasize on that fact, cause thinking of "another huge investment phase to gather/collect before actually enjoying the game" is what made me hesitate to try Duelyst.So, arena price and pack prices are the same as hearthstone, while;Legendary ratio is 1 on every 4 pack. Its 1 on 20 pack in hearthstone. (both numbers are taken from developer quotes)Cards are cheaper to craft, legendaries are like half the price relative to hs.You get 15 gold for every 2 wins, in hs you get 10 gold for every 3 wins.You get 2x 25 gold quest + a 5 gold puzzle everyday, in hs you get 1 quest worth 40 to 60 gold. (and 100 gold quest maybe once in a month)Arena is much more rewarding than hearthstone, like in 7 wins you get another free entry+2 cards+gold+dust+pack. I wont even explain hs counterpart, if youve ever played hearthstone you must be familiar with constant complains about arena rewards.You get more rewards at the end of seasons.You can get cosmetics/emotes/cardbacks/skins with ingame currency.With its non-existent "invest first" phase, cool different mechanics, basic decks that can actually rank up, Duelyst is a game that you can actually enjoy while mainly playing hearthstone or mtg etc. And one that you'll certainly love if you liked said games above.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3
												I wish I could give this somewhere between a yes and no. Because it's kind of close to being in the middle.On one hand, I really enjoy this game. It's fun. Tactical. Unique. No two games will play out the same. The community seems to be cool at least from the 3-4 people I actually added on this game after a match. There are a lot of cards. 6 factions, with every faction having two different 'generals' to use. Although, you don't get the alternate general until you reach level 10 with that specific faction. Which I've found is anywhere from 10-15 games, I think. The matches go fast. Maybe 10-15 minutes. The pixel art graphics are beautiful.On the other hand... This is, no joke, a straight up pay to win game. No different than things like Clash Royale, and I think Hearthstone did this too. I don't normally play p2w games, but I imagine it's all built off the same model. A system that is built to undermind the consumer with microtransactions for instant gratification. Basically there's no way to just dump a small sum of money into one specific thing to get what you want right then and there. It's completely built for the sole purpose of milking the living hell out of their players wallets. Your starting cards can MAYBE get you to rank 20 if you're patient enough, but beyond that in "Silver Class", it's full of people that have payed possibly hundreds of dollars for their insane decks. I won't lie, I got a little fed up facing people like this and bought a couple orb packs. Orbs are like "chests", you buy an orb for 100g, though 100g comes in very, very slowly. It's almost pointless. You can buy 1 orb for 2$, 3 for 5$, 7 for 10$, 15 for 20$ or 40 for 50$. Orbs are how you will grow your deck. When you open an orb, you'll be showed 5 floating gem/rock type things ranging from grey, blue, purple, and orange in color. Exactly what you would imagine them to be... Common, Rare, Epic, Legendary. Click on the floating thing and it reveals a card that's now yours. Most of the time you're getting commons and one rare. BUT HERE IS THE REAL KICKER!!! If you've grown fond of one specific faction (Like I have, Lyonar), all these cards are not for just your faction. They're for the other factions and sometimes neutral cards (Ones any faction can use). Trying to get cards for your specific faction is a nightmare and I've gone up to 9 (Yes, NINE) orbs without getting one single Lyonar card. Remember there's 6 factions, plus neutral. So at anytime 1-2 factions are guaranteed getting shisted when it comes to opening an orb. Which brings me to a bit of a tin-foil-hat theory.. I know games like this have algorhytims in them to drastically lower the chance-rate in which you actually get the items you need/want based off of what you already play. I know Clash Royale is guilty as all hell for it, and I'm pretty sure this one is too. The only custom deck I have is a Lyonar because it's all I play, but in the 70$ I've put into this game, Lyonar cards came in at such a noticeably low rate compared to every other faction that it really leaves a bad taste in my mouth about the developers. They just want you to spend more to TRY and get a couple of those cards you'd like for your deck.Bottom line/tl;dr - If you have a high amount of disposable income and can blow away hundreds to be able to actually compete, then try it out. It is fun.. If you don't want to put money into a game, but want to climb the ranks, look for another game. This is not the one for you. If you're at all on the fence about p2w (pay to win) games, look else where...I'll probably still play it from time to time, but the p2w aspect of it all really just kills the game for me.

												This game looks cool and its promissing, but when you get Silver rank 15 its starts to be pure PAY TO WIN.Everything in the game is expensive. Posted: November 4, 2016
												Most pay-to-win game I've ever played - it's nearly impossible lategame to counter the slew of rare cards players threw money at to acquire, and the common-quality cards acquired through grinding incur an urge to buy rarer sets to keep up with the competition. The price for each card pack is pure greed; I'm not even guaranteed the normal cards I need to complete a competitive deck since each pack is random, which makes paying $50 for a 40 even more ridiculous. Unbalanced cards are supposedly randomly dropped, but the chances are incredibly slim. Don't give money to these guys. They don't deserve it after failing to balance gameplay with monetary gains.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												The long and short of it - I've tried this game on two different occasions and it's not balanced at high level play. Or maybe it is, but everyone has to either play the same amount of time or buy in the same amount. When everyone is using the starter decks, it's fine. On several occasions, people pull these low cost cards that are absolutely devastating (one was a summon 4 random faction minions - they each were 4-5 cost cards for the price of one 4 cost card. The other is a 3 cost card that gives a general +2 attack whenever anyone on their side takes damage. That should be like a 6-7 cost card, as it is game ending.) I never got into crafting, as to do it efficiently, you would need to dump money into the game.I feel like the deck drawing phases have some awful RNG to them, as well. You can have 25 unique cards in your deck and fairly consistenly draw the same cards without ever seeing some of what you put in your deck. How hard is it to randomly assign all deck cards a number and order them for true randomness? Or would that break the faulty design of the game?All in all, I like the effort, but balance is poor which really impinges on the fun factor. It's free, though, so you'll probably get around 10-15 hours of enjoyment out of it at no cost.

												Disapointing game offering no hook at the start. the tutorial (if you can call it that) is horrible featuring little insight into the way the game actually plays and even forcing you to make plays that suggests certain mechanics don't work the way they do. When you unlock a new faction their cards are just splashed across the screen with no way to ready them there. I receive one orb (card pack) in my time play that I wasn't even awere of. The gameplay itself is so simplistic for the first few games that playing anymore to see if fun mechanics appear is a chore I won't bother with even if you could gaureentee a great result. The most off putting part is the art deciesons. The minions themselves are pixel, and not very good pixel art at that. The backgrounds and characte art is very one drawn and not pixel-ly in the least. The contrast of these two styles does help it the game, it just makes it into a visually jumbled mess.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												BASE ON MY EXPERIENCES WHICH MIGHT NOT BE LIKE YOURS...  I know this won't get treated fairly either, but it's the truth and how I felt...The game can be fun, but without spending money you lack the competitive edge needed to win, even if you are really good.  I created a couple accounts and asked around to test some theories on this & that and found that after 5 wins in a row things changed drastically, the matches went from starter deck vs starter deck to me (starter deck) vs a full Epic and legendary decks (money spent well)  So I would say DUELYST can be tons of fun, but more for the very non-competitive-casual style of player for F2P.  True buying spirit orbs still grant rewards by random rolls, but spend enough and anything is possible.I can't totally claim 100% P2W, due mainly that I was able to beat a little more than half of the impossible money decks and also that is it possible to advance otherwise, but at a very grindy-slow speed.The pixel graphics didn't bother me and the horrible RNG didn't either, what did bother me is the support team.  They make it torture to delete your account and they send you newsletters even when you have it setup to not send notifications and other information + ads.  They were allowing to change email and have a free Name Change, but the change email poofed and this led to me wanting to delete account.  I should not have to be forced to make another  email just so they don't use  my email.  I am leaving a bit of conversations back and forth out of this, but I am sure you get the point.The Game & Mechanics = 7/10  :steamhappy:  "It is a fun concept"The Support Team rating = 1/10 :steamsad:   "without a good support team lost trust"I decided it was best to uninstall at this time...  Combat monsters is an other silly version of this same genre setup, has more PvE and is way easier, but the PvP is almost non-existant.  For now I will promote how the support is horrible.FINAL NOTE:    SUGGESTIONAllow account deletion in settings--Thanks!--

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I cannot recommend this game anymore.Over the last few month the developer has gradually made the game less and less player friendly by nerfing the in-game currency rewards multiple times and also the drop rates from booster packs. Unless one is willing to sink a large amount of either time or money into the game, advancing the card collection is painfully slow and one is hardly able to keep up with the release of new cards resulting in an infinite grind treadmill for casual players.Due to this player numbers over the last months have been on a constant decline, at the time of this review a measly 300-500 concurrent player, and unless the developer turns things around quickly this game is bound to vanish into obscurity.There are better F2P card games out there like Shadowverse that actually value your play time and have a larger chance of still being around in a couple of years.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												I have been playing this game for about two months now and wow i am blown away by it. It is extremely addictive and rewarding.Gameplay: Perfectly balanced between easy to learn but hard to master, i found mysdelf climbing high up the ladder with a budget deck but as i got higher and i was playing against better people i really needed to start learning some strategies and gradually replace cards in my deck with better ones.Each game feels different and requires a certain amount of thinking and strategy.The tile system is very easy to learn and every general and deck type are very different to eachother, each are unique and their core cards are also very unique.Pay to win?: no this game is no where near pay as hearthstone is, i found myself spending minimal and still being able to be competetivivce, i have heard countless stories of people reaching the highest rank with just a budget 0$ cost deck. People in the reviews that are claiming this game is pay to win are most likely players who keep losing and are blaming their own shortcomings on the opponents" better cards". People will complain about anything instead of blaming themselves.If you would like to start up this game which i would highly recomened, use my refer code "Trebs" and you can add me on my buddy list and i can teach you.10/10

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												Duelyst is the best digital CCG I have played. It isn't quite perfect, but it makes Hearthstone look like the highly polished turd that it is.The Good:+ Pixel art with killer animations!+ Six very different factions with interesting playstyles. Balance isn't quite there yet, but there isn't just one strategy that outright shatters everything else.+ Tactics! Having a grid makes strategy all the more important to play efficiently and intelligently. Place one card in the wrong spot or make the wrong move and boom! You're in hot water and either losing tempo or the match.+ Definitely not P2W. Sorry salt farmers, you can play a reasonable amount every day and amass a good collection. You can easily earn a pack a day, maybe more if you are dedicated. And if you look on Reddit, you can get help building low dust (currency to create cards) cost decks that can totally flex with the expensive ones.+ If you do start paying, you get rare cards at an elevated rate compared to Hearthstone. Add in a more favorable disenchant rate and lots of high quality staples at common and you won't break the bank on this game by any means.+ The playerbase and community (I played a ton in February-March approximately, so I'm not as up to date) is very friendly and helpful. I'm pretty sure most of us just want to see Duelyst grow and improve.+ Finally, replacing. Once per turn you can throw a card back into your deck and draw a new one. It adds that subtle amount of consistency that makes the game less of a variance fest. There are way fewer games where you just don't see your deck's key components.+ Daily challenges! Little bites of brain-teasing single player. Worst case scenario, The Meh:~ Crates are sorta lame. I mean, what is this? TF2?~ RNG additions lately are a little worriesome, but thus far it's nowhere near as offensive as Hearthstone. Fingers crossed it stays under control.The Bad:-NothingAll in all, if you like CCGs and strategy games you need to give this sucker a shot. After all, what's to lose? Oh, right... your social life.9/10

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												I fully reccommend this game.It is a tactical, turn-based game and a card game. You use the cards to place units to the board, cast spells and equip your general with artifacts. Mechanics - The objective of the game is to kill the enemy general. Each round you have an increasing amount of mana to play your cards. There are 3 game modes: Practice against a basic AI, Season Ladder which is the ranked PVP and the Gauntlet, where you build a deck from scratch. There are endless possibilities of combinations with the cards and the board positioning. You can choose among 6 factions, each one having 2 generals with different playstyles.Matches last around 10 minutes.Aesthetics - The quality of the artwork is AAA. Unit design and animation are superbly well done in a pixel art style, backgrounds are beautiful paintings. The soundtrack is great and the interface is beautiful, functional and responsive.Dynamics - I found the game very noob-friendly (even having zero experience on card games), the tutorial covers the basics and gets you up and running very fast. There are dozens of challenges that show combos and the basic mechanics from every faction.You have so many cards to unlock and so much to rise on ladder that it guarantees endless, high quality entertainment for free.Community - So far, incredibly good. People tend to be nice and helpful. There are several great streamers that help with insights and tips, also, lots of content across different platforms - wiki, reddit, twitter.Conclusion - Definitely worth a try if you are into tactical, cards or both. A very well crafted game, with constant challenges, endless room to grow, healthy playerbase and friendly community.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												Duelyst is a beautiful amalgamation of classic card games like Magic: The Gathering and Hearthstone and hex-based strategy games such as Final Fantasy Tactics and less specifically, the newer XCOM games. Developed by Counterplay games, smooth animations and a crisp and pleasing pixel art style give Duelyst a level of polish that very few free-to-play games have. The game has been available through an individual launcher up until yesterday when it was released on Steam, hopefully giving this game a much deserved boost in the player base. Being free-to-play hopefully won't turn off many collectible card game players because, well, most digital CCG's are free-to-play. Unlike most, however, Duelyst is very generous with its booster packs, called Spirit Orbs. I received tons of them when I started playing that gave me a great collection of cards to build off of. Single Orbs will cost you 100 gold, which is plentiful as like as you complete all of your daily quests and can win a couple of games against real players every now and then.You have your traditional Hearthstone style mana system, gaining one permanent mana every turn. Combat is as smooth as a whistle. After your summoned minions, that can be summoned within a few tiles of your general (think as if your Hearthstone hero was a 2/20 card itself), are rid of their summoning sickness, they can attack in any direction within a certain tile radius. minions who are attacked, counter attack just like almost any other CCG out there. Duelyst truly sets itself apart from these other CCG's with the added strategy and almost puzzle like layer. Ranged minions, who can attack anything from any spot on the board, are just one of the ways the game uses the play field in an effective and fun way. Provoke is another mechanic that does such a thing, adding a taunt-like mechanic in which no minions in the minion with provoke's radius can move or attack without first destroying said minion. Teleporting minions to any spot on the board is yet another way Duelyst creates fun and different ways to use it's mechanics.I mentioned earlier a puzzle aspect that Duelyst presents. While regular PVP games don't seem to give you the feeling of a puzzle game, the daily challenge, as well as Solo Challenge mode, is absolutely, in and of itself, a puzzle. The board is set the same every time you retry the challenge and your goal is to move minions and use mechanics in a certain way and order to kill the opposing general in one turn. Solo Challenge mode includes 6 sets of 5 challenges, each one more difficult than the last. This mode is sure to give even the sharpest of players at least a few hours of gameplay. Card rarity will look familiar to any CCG player: Common, Rare, Epic, and Legendary. With each orb containing 5 cards, with at least one rare, you will find yourself with more rare or better cards than normal. Epic cards tend to show up every two orbs and legendaries one in every four. This may seem high, but when you can have 3 copies of a legendary in a deck, along with 3 copies of any other card, it's easy to see why Duelyst is so generous with its rare cards. Deckbuilding is very fun with tons of mechanics you can build around. A Golem based deck built around Golem Vanquisher, which gives your other golems provoke, ranged decks that buff your ranged minions to ping down the opposing general, or a deck that is designed to try and OTK (one turn kill) your opponent, are just a few of the near infinite decks you can build, provided you have the cards for it.With 10% of the proceeds of all pre-orders of the upcoming expansion Denizens of Shim'zar, which will add more than 90 new cards to the collection, going towards the prize pool for the Duelyst World Championship, I'm sure the pro scene is about to bustle and explode.While I just spent the last 700 words or so gushing over the game, I struggle to play more than 4 or 5 games at a time. I would love to lose an entire day or weekend to this game as I do to other CCG's, grinding out gold and wins on the ladder, I just can't. The game is mentally exhausting, which is absolutely not a bad thing. It makes you think more than most games which is a definite plus to most people. It's my weak mind that's the problem. With it's recent release on Steam, coupled with the fact that it is free-to-play, I would be on the look out for this game to explode in popularity very soon. Counterplay Games seem to have their priorities set straight and have content lined up for a while, including a second expansion in the works and four new cards added to the core set every month. Give Duelyst a try. You will not be disappointed. Plus, its free, so why not give it a chance?http://www.blaiseplays.com/blaise-plays/duelyst/

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												In-depth game that requires skill and tactics. Pretty much Hearthstone chess, but without the bull of Hearthstone. Cards are easy to obtain. You can quickly build a deck in the timespan of a week or two. Thats about the time it takes to learn the ins and outs of the game.Also unlike Hearthstone, there is a movement system, which allows for much greater usage of tactics and diversity. Even halfway decks can compare to the stronger decks, as long as good strategy is used. Also very different to Hearthstone, which is full of RNG bull and meta decks. There are so many ways to play this game. Every faction has two Generals (similar to HS classes, but with TWO :D ). Each has their own ability to help their minions or themselves. Or hurt the enemy. Factions have specific cards and abilities unique to them, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. There are also neutral cards that anyone can use.Deck building is very creative. You can do anything (mostly) and get away with it. Do you wanna make a deck focusing on taking out the enemy general with the pure brute force of yours? Maybe you want to play dirty and lure enemies into well placed traps. Or you could just make a giant army of 1/1 minions. Possibilities are endless. Unlike Hearthstone...

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												I put up with the clashing artstyle for a long while for the sake of the gameplay, but many of the most recent additions added towards making the game a case of Rock-Paper-Scissors between the decks instead of duels of wit and outmanouvering your opponent. If you are playing a Magmar deck with rebirth minions and go up against an Abyssian with all the new cheap Shadow Creep you might as well concede. A Magmar that casts the four mana RNG fiesta that gives you four random eggs in random spots of the map either demands an immediate cheap AOE that few decks run in your deck or spells an immediate concede. The limited hand size initially encouraged players to play to their deck's strengths while also allowing some choice tech cards thanks to the 2-draw mechanic but it has since been replaced with single draw, removing much of the consistency and what made the game fun - you are no longer rewarded for adding a few tech cards to rapidly cycle into and rather punished for not having three of every important card in your deck. What was initially a game of limited RNG reached the point where the newest expansion Denizens of Shim'zar is full of pets that will choose randomly who to attack between two adjacent foes - which can be either game-winning or crippling. It hit me that this is just no longer the game I was having fun with when I downloaded it off steam one full year ago.

Or you lose in a way that makes you question God (he has answered, Its not him).Yes, you do get the balanced games that are exceptionally fun, But those only happen about 30% of the time, Which is just not worth it in my opinion. If it is not the system, Then this game has managed to deliver impossible odds time and time again. I am packing away my decks.Continuing my search for a fun skill based game..

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												If you're looking for a great strategy game or card game, this is your best bet. I played a lot of HS but ultimately got burned out between the grind, legendary requirements, RNG, and lack of skill depth.Duelyst delivers all of the above and more. A great mix of cards and chess like strategy means that a good deck helps, but even as a new player, I've beaten "better" decks (legendaries, etc) just because of good positioning and maneuvering. The strategy requirements often make a loss feel better, too, where you really get why you lost as opposed to feeling like you lost due to RNG like in other games.This game really is F2P, and a generous one at that. Just by doing the daily challenges, quests, and so on you can easily net a few packs a day to quickly build up your deck.As a whole, I've spent way more than 6 hours in the game and haven't regretted any of it. Awesome community, too! Worth trying it out.

Plz reel in some of the strenth of his cards, so that people playing with him can focus more on his strengths, also people playing against him can focus on a weakness he might have..edit: After a lot more games I have come to the conclusion that this system is way too obvious in what it does.You either win so easily that you cant possibly gain any enjoyment from the game. Or you lose in a way that makes you question God (he has answered, Its not him).Yes, you do get the balanced games that are exceptionally fun, But those only happen about 30% of the time, Which is just not worth it in my opinion. If it is not the system, Then this game has managed to deliver impossible odds time and time again. I am packing away my decks.Continuing my search for a fun skill based game..

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												I'm not at all a fan of "the chase" portion of card games, where you spend time acquiring cards to improve your decks. This leaves the draft or other game modes in terms of holding my intersest. Having a board on which to move and place your units allows Duelyst to have a cool puzzle mode where the player is given a board and they need to find out how to win in 1 turn, however most cards are designed with a very narrow set of situations in which they are powerful making these puzzles mostly about reading the cards and sequencing plays optimally as opposed to thinking about different ways to use the cards. The draft mode isn't amazing either because this same situationalness makes it so that it's very rare to see much broad synergy between cards making it feel mostly like an exercise in picking the most valuable card weighted for the curve you've already picked. Even in constructed, the situationalness means that punishes and advantage swings are extreme making the overall game more about tempo than anything else.However, for those who like that extreme feel to a game, it's pretty successful at being a game of skill expression. The reason I have decided not to recommend this game is because I perceive that cohort that would enjoy this game to be a fairly small niche of players.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												I thoroughly love Duelyst.  From the art, to the strategy, to the expertly crafted balance between RNG and skill, this is perhaps the game I've been waiting for since I first started playing Magic 20 years ago.  Allow me, for a moment, to take you through a journey of why I love this game.Skip this paragraph if you don't care to stroll through memory lane and just want to hear about Duelyst.  I love card games and I love board games.  Years ago there was a game called Culdcept that came out for the PS2 that was a hybrid between CCGs and Monopoly.  I played the hell out of that game.  It was a great concept that allowed a bit of strategy, but still tempered by dice rolls and luck draws.  There were still plety of times that you just couldn't draw the right card even though you have several of them in your deck, or you rolled the dice poorly and ended up on your opponent's equivalent to Boardwalk, but it was fun.  Duelyst reminds me a lot of Culdcept, only more positives and fewer negatives.In Duelyst, you start with your general and a handful of cards.  Those cards could be creature or spells.  Your general is effectively just like any other creature, only s/he has a whole lot of life.  The concept is simple: kill the opposing general before yours is killed.  The generals move and attack like creatures on a rectangular board.  You can summon creatures to any space next to any space you already control (ie, next to your general or one of your creatures), and creatures start with summoning sickness.  You draw one card at the end of your turn, and you can replace a card in your hand with a card off the top of your deck at the beginning of your turn.  Resources are handled like Hearthstone: +1 resource every turn.  And that, in a nutshell, are the rules.My favourite aspect of Duelyst is your ability to manipulate the board and your own hand.  For me, there's just enough RNG mixed with skill to keep me interested and not frustrated.  It feels pretty awesome to lure your opponent into a false sense of security by letting your health run low, then when they're one turn from the kill, you turn it around and burn them down from full health to 0 because they overextended.  Or when you take a look at your hand, knowing that you have one, maybe two turns left in the game and making that risky replace that pays off and gives you the win.  In Duelyst, I almost always feel like I had to earn my victory or my opponent simply outplayed me.  I can almost always look back at games I lost and see where I could have played better.  That sense of frustration that the cards weren't there for me rarely occurs, just that I should have played the cards I was given differently.  Easy to play, hard to master.P2W  Lots of people worry and argue about whether or not a F2P game is P2W.  It's a stupid argument for a CCG.  More cards equals more options when building your deck.  Some of those options are going to be powerful, some are not, but it's invariably better to have a variety of options than no options, and when you pay money you will have more options.  Does that make it P2W?  Well, here's what I can say about my experience so far with Duelyst.  I haven't put in any money whatsoever.  I've done daily quests and little more, however I played a LOT of Duelyst in the Alpha so I have a very strong understanding of the game mechanics, as well as different deck ideas that work and are relatively easy to make that rely on commons and rares and few to zero epics or legendaries.  I am currently rank 9 (gold, relatively high) and am starting to see the barrier where having more cards to choose from would help.  Keep in mind, there are a ton of common and rare cards that I don't even have yet due to my relatively small amount of playtime since the release.  I haven't even crafted any cards because I feel like carfting commons and rares would be a waste for later, so I'm just trudging along at a steady pace.  That being said, I am beating a lot of players that have much larger collections than I do.  I know this since several of them have a ton of ribbons (100+ wins with that faction), as well as cards that only unlock based on how many other cards you've collected (I have none of these), but that is not preventing me from playing and winning.  So is Duelyst P2W?  When you start getting higher up in the rankings, you won't be able to beat the players that have access to all the cards AND are skillful players.  But being a skillful player with few cards is more important than having all the cards and not being a skilled player.  So no, that legendary that stomped your face last game is probably not the only reason you lost.  You probably have more learning to do.I am going to be putting money into Duelyst because I love this game and I want to support the developers, but even if you don't put any money into it, there is a lot of enjoyment to be had here.  I would recommend everyone to at least try it because you have nothing to lose and there is an amazing game here with a lot of depth.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Before reading this, just take into consideration that I suck at card games. Deck building is something I've never been able to get the grasp of. That being said, Duelyst is a fantastic card / tactics game. It has a beautiful pixel aesthetic (not dissimilar to Dungeon of the Endless) with a lot of style and great animations. But how does it play? Well, it plays great. You choose one of 6 factions, all of which have 2 generals (one default and one alternate one that you have to unlock). The general is you. If the general dies, you lose. After you choose your faction, you can either choose a default deck or create your own. You can unlock individual cards from leveling up or you can buy booster packs with in game currency as well as real life currency if you want.The cards are where the game gets quite interesting. Each faction has its own unique set of cards as well as a 7th neutral set of cards that all factions can use. The cards are divided into minions, spells, and artifacts. Minions are summons that you can place on the battlefield. The minions themselves have TONS of variation. There are the average tanks, melee damage dealers, and ranged minions, but there is so much more to it than that. Many minions have abilities. Some have abilities that proc when you play the card. Some have abilities that proc when the minion dies or when other minions die. Some have abilities that proc at the end of your turn. I think you get the point. There's a lot of abilities.Spells are one time use cards that create some effect. Like minions, quite a lot of variation here. You have spells that heal or do damage, spells that buff, and a lot of other random stuff. Artifacts are similar to spells, except they usually just buff your general in some way. The artifacts are mostly unique to each faction with each faction basically serving as this game's version of a class. Each faction focuses on different styles of play.When you have built your own deck of 40 cards or decide to use the default deck, you go into a 1v1 battle. The battlefield is a grid, with each general automatically placed at either end. The battlefield is big enough to allow evasive maneuvers, but small enough to prevent people from totally running away from battle.Each player takes turns casting their cards and moving their generals and minions around. Each card has a mana cost which leads to deep strategy. You have to do your math or your turns may not end up as planned. The person who starts second has 1 extra mana point to make up for the fact that they move second. This is the game. You take turns going back and forth, casting your cards until one of you kills the other's general. One thing I absolutely adore is how attacking works. Unless the minion or general is ranged or some other buff/debuff comes into play, your melee attacks are met with counter attacks. That's right, you cannot melee attack without the enemy hitting you right back! This creates tension that leads to high strategy.The real fun in this game is learning the intricacies of each faction. The variation in playstyles is quite impressive considering there are only 6 factions to choose from. Each faction feels very unique. Test them all out and i guarantee you will fall in love with one of them. They're all very clever and have advantages and disadvantages. Although, you can sort of disregard the faction system altogether by using a lot of neutral cards instead.This game is very strategic and A LOT of fun. It's free to play, but I would gladly pay to play this if it weren't. If you like card games or tactics games, you've got nothing to lose! Give it a try. I hope you'll enjoy it as much as I do.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												TL;DR- I would strongly suggest anyone to give this game a try. Even more so if you enjoy games which require strategy and tactical positioning. A free game which is not P2W, and starts you with a viable cardbase for early levels. Relatively easy to get the cards you want through grinding.For a bonus 100 gold, which is worth a pack, (and to help me out, if you found my review helpful), make sure to use my Steam username as your referral code under the settings menu before you enter any ranked match!The long:I've been playing Magic: The Gathering for years. Tried out other games with moderate amusement.Even the Magic Duels game here on Steam has been kind of mediocre. I haven't picked it up since I stopped playing it. Tried out Hearthstone briefly and could not stand it at all, even if it did have some good gameplay elements.This game takes the good gameplay elements that Hearthstone employs and does it better, and puts it on a board. The board is always the same, so you always know what you're getting into, starting as first player or second player randomly. Where it really shines is in the emergent tactical development of each game which could only be possible with a board. There are also game mechanics which are only possible with a board. Deck building may be king, but positioning is god. You will win or lose a game sometimes purely based on how you move around the board or where you position things. Attack order is also important. Your moves should be planned, and sometimes a situation is so delicate that you will either win that turn or kill yourself by trying, that same turn, or lose immediately the next turn. And it's always your fault.Finally, they did a good job of reducing the effect RNG has on your options in your hand by allowing you to re-draw two cards from your starting hand before the match begins, and then every one of your turns allowing you to re-draw one card. It doesn't sound like much, but this is a game-changer and game-saver. It would be a very different game if you couldn't do this. Also, there are some cards which change this mechanic (like giving you an extra replace each turn) or activate based on it (do something every time you replace a card).Additionally, its gold-for-packs system and gold generation rate, as well as the rate for disenchanting and enchanting for card creation is much more generous than other games which use a similar system, such as Hearthstone. It's fairly easy to get most cards you want. I recommend creating commons and rares to fill out your neutral cards and faction you want to play to start with, before you try crafting epics or legendaries.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												Have you been trying to scratch an itch that only card games with the depth of MTG could scratch?  Look no more.  Duelyst is a competitve card-game with tactical-RPG elements similar to Final Fantasy Tactics.  The pixel art is great to look at, and the animations are fluid and good-looking.But perhaps what I enjoy most about Duelyst is that it's one of the first F2P games that's not forcefully shoving micro-transactions down your throat.  A lot of the micro-transactions are cosmetics: different skins, emotes, and in-game messages.  And yes, you can buy Spirit Orbs (Duelyst's booster packs) without using real money.The Practice and Challenge mode do a fantastic job at getting the player familiar with different skills and playstyles of all the generals.  The online mode is strictly competitve, and has a ranking system similar to League of Legends or Dota 2.There are a few things I would urge the developers to change.  Certain playstyles require the summoning of many minions, and the online game mode is set with a fixed timer.  I've found myself running out of time much more frequently than other similar games, which is definitely a problem for a game that relies so heavily upon strategy and placement.All in all, Duelyst is a fantasticly challenging game with a wonderfully unobtrusive F2P model.  I have yet to purchase anything, and have sunk over 20 hours so far.  However, I can easily see myself putting some money into the game, especially with the release of the new expansion set.  If more games would adopt a similar model, I would be much more willing to spend more time and resources on them.I'd urge anyone fond of MTG or tactical-RPGs to give Duelyst a try.  It's free, so you really have nothing to lose.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												I find chess complicated - and I kid you not. I never was a fan and I don't think I will ever get a hang of playing it. Ever.And yet here I am giving a thumbs-up to a game that's basically an evolution of that game. Or maybe it's chess on steroids. I don't know why I am hooked on it.Maybe it's because you play out of a hand - which is more liberating and more variable than chess. It takes inspiration from a lot of games both old and even new, and makes it better. I am not limited to diagonal, straight-line, or L-shape movements - I have six factions to build my army from, offering a load of uniquely designed minions and spells in colorful 8-bit artworks. A pawn can victoriously become your knight or queen with the right combination of cards. (and a little bit of luck on the draw)Or maybe it's the fact that matches are short and sweet (and brutally satisfying) yet always different in every way due to the multitude of options the game throws at you. Or perhaps it's the fact that it made me think of chess out of the blue - maybe getting a grip of "two steps ahead" will help me ladder. How it makes me wish that I knew the age old game better.It's colorful. It's complex. It's addicting. It's Duelyst.Post Season Review - here are additional thing you should know before getting into it. I still like the game but it is turning out to be a love-hate relationship.1) The kickstarter rewards - well the most basic at least - doesn't give you a big advantage. It would have if I started playing as soon as it was F2P but I didn't. So any duplicate cards that I have really didn't prove any much help. People starting just now will have to work hard into building their decks.2) You will eventually fight the same deck designs during the duration of the season. Either you will be tempted to fight a mirror match to see who uses the current flavor or just have a not so good win ratio with your original or not-so-hot deck at the moment. 3) The temptation of spending real money is high. If you're new and did not back up the kickstarter project, there will be a lot of catching up. At the very least you will have to get the 10 Pack Starter. I don't know how much of an advantage the new Division Packs will bring, knowing that the players who have been at it for a very long time would have access to both the Bronze and Silver packs at the very least. The willingness to put out cash is equal to game veterans and starters. (and all will still bow to RNG-esus)P.S. For a Trading Card Game, there's no trading involved. I hope there was some way that people can actually exchange cards to build that sense of community with the likes of Magic The Gathering.
