content:
Posted: January 11
												I didn't get caught up in Hearthstone. I've played M:tG competitively for something like 20 years now, and the F2P digital CCG was a phenomenon I just wasn't interested in. Duelyst, though, does have my attention. By combining the strategic element (deckbuilding) and the tactical element (sequencing) of a CCG with the movement and positioning of a tabletop wargame, Duelyst manages to be more than the sum of its parts. This strange alchemical concoction of disparate game types scratches an itch I didn't know I had. The presentation, too, is nothing to sneeze at: the pixel art style is executed as well here as I've ever seen it.I want to find something negative to say here that will temper my enthusiasm, but I can't. This game is great.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												By far and large my favorite online CCG. It's pretty much everything I want in a card game: Tactics, beautiful animation with it's 2D artstyle, and very rewarding free to play options. Yes you can dole out real money on this to get: extra card packs, skins for your generals, cosmetics, etc, but you can always acquire those with gold and spirit with some time invested. Thank you Counterplay games for bringing this beauty out.The rundown: You play this game with another player on a 5x9 grid. You summon creatures, cast spells, etc. The fact that the grid is there allows for more tactical gameplay as you have to plan your moves ahead dependent on your opponent. There's 6 factions in game, each with 2 generals for a total of 12 unique generals and gameplay elements to those factions. I recommend more players to try this out, the community is pretty good.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2016
												I played this in beta but quit shortly before launch. I decided to try it again and it still leaves a bad taste in my mouth. It's very hard to put a finger on what doesn't feel right about Duelyst. The /idea/ of the game is great, the tile-based combat and all that is wonderful. Problem is the cards... Balance doesn't seem to be a thing and games are usually about highly uninteractive, massive swing plays. To "counter" this, there is hard removal, lots and lots of removals. There is just way too much hard removal in Duelyst -- which leads to many games being a race to see who fails to draw into their hard removal first... In the end, whatever it is, the game just isn't enjoyable. Perhaps if I spend a whole bunch of money it'd feel less unfair? Dunno if the P2W complainers are right, but they might be... In summary, not a fun game. It ought to be, but it's not. Try it yourself. But if you don't like it... if it feels like you can't get ANYWHERE on ladder no matter how many guides you read or videos you watch or netdecks you learn from or the number of times you build and rebuild your decks... It's not just you. Something's rotten in the state of Duelyst. Go try The Elder Scrolls Legends. Finish the campaign then invest some time in it. Then compare the experience to that of Duelyst. You'll see what I am talking about -- then you'll go back to Legends...

content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												If Fire Emblem and Hearthstone had a child game, this would be it. That's all I really need to say, as that alone made me like it.For any friends that try it: BEFORE YOU DO A LADDER MATCH USE THE CODE "lugarugan" for +100g and added to my list of referrals. This will afford you a spirit orb or part of a gauntlet run based on what you spend it on ingame. Oh, and gold is more common than in hearthstone. That's a plus.I repeat, do it BEFORE a ladder match. The moment you've gotten into your first ladder match, it is too late to use referral codes. Settings > Code redemption or whatever > input just 'lugarugan' as that is my Duelyst nickname. Even if you input my name on sign-up or whatever, you will likely need to do this to be considered one in the system it uses.Note: I also gain 1 spirit orb and 200 gold if you reach silver and gold divisions respectively. I can tip you after friendly matches if I have spare gold I believe though, as on average I'll be affording 1 gauntlet run a day. So in a way, I can give you some of that 200g in return if you get that far based on how many matches we play and such.However I will not start tipping gold until I am gaining more rewards per run on average than I'd get from just buying orbs. Since only one win gives me an orb and Spirit, I'm already dropping buying orbs on their own entirely, as this will also let me learn about new cards as I earn the orbs. And maybe I'll even get enough Spirit to craft some of the cards I learn about on the way! I do recommend you try the mode after reaching Silver and trying a few decks with your current cards beforehand. As learning some of the cards you get before you start trying it will go a long way in learning if they are good to pick during runs. Gauntlet deckss are made of 30 cards plus one general, picked from sets of 3 cards. You also pick your faction from a set of 3 of the 6 factions, so you won't always get your favorite faction.(I hope to get a Songhai run soon so I can do a Ranged deck in there!)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												[TL;DR] Duelyst is a great game. It has a charming community, a challenging and fast paced gameplay, nice soundtracks and gorgeous visuals. It is the perfect blend of Turn Based Strategy and CCGs like Hearthstone, fair and rewarding but still cheaper than the likes of MTG or HS.What is Duelyst ? Duelyst is a CCG at heart. You will collect cards, craft cards and assemble them in decks. Every card has unique properties that can change the course of a game. If at first it sounds very Hearthstone-ish, and not without reasons, in practice, the game is very different because of the board element.How's the Gameplay ? In Duelyst, you will play on a board similar to a chess board. The gameplay actually is very reminescent of chess. You have a General ( a King ) and minions ( Pawns, Rooks etc ). In addition to this, you've also got spells. All of those elements come in various sorts, buffs, debuffs, miscellaneous effects and such and their use is balanced with a cost in mana. The goal of the game is simple and straightforward : kill the enemy General. Is the game P2W ? Absolutely not. Everything, including cosmetics, can be obtained through playing and each and every expansion is free. There are some lootcrates though you can not open without paying, but I can assure you that this game is the cheapest CCG you've ever seen. Drop rates are quite generous when opening orbs and not as hard to obtain as in HS. I like to call this game the Path of Exile of CCGs. Of course, you can still buy card packs by purchasing them if you want to.What about the graphics ? If pixel art is your thing, welcome to heaven. The art in this game is beautiful. Easily the best looking pixel art around.Okay, what about the story ? The lore in this game is incredibly deeper than you'd think. More is coming soon. If you like to speculate and go treasure hunting for every tiny piece of lore you can find, this game fits the bill. You actually can see me and others speculate about it on the forums. Speaking of which.Is the community good ? Easily one of the best communities you will ever be given to see. Rarely have I seen such a friendly and open community, especially in a competitive game. EVERYONE is here to help you.Here are some links.Forums : https://forums.duelyst.com/Discord : https://discordapp.com/invite/0WbpmyLbu52aphybAdd me in-game if you want to practice some friendly matches. I guess I can also try to give you advices. Here's my IGN : deWize .

												One of those collectible card game strategy things that was released recently, which is trying most probably to the Hearthstone's child. And you can see the similarities everywhere, from the start menu and the buttons displayed, including the layout and the models of minion abilities and hero powers. However, this one is a what i can call an hybrid that combines the Hearthstone mechanics and add some new twists to it, like a real positioning or a different attack style for every minion. The thing is, I don't know why they really wanted to apply that bright retro aesthetic. Visually seems nice, but it fails to leave any impression, and for some, pixel art it's as bad as oldish things. Overall, it's nice, short, and good to waste your time with from time to time. Nor bad nor good.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												+It's a fun game, easy to learn, difficult to master. +Quick matches+Can only communicate with emotes (no mouthy people swearing at you when they're losing)+Stunningly animated sprites+Fantastic music+Challenges (both fixed and daily) help you learn game mechanics+Plethora of beautifully illustrated texts really flush out the world+Earn in game currency to buy new cards (albeit slowly)The only real negative is that match making is rough, you rapidly get paired with people that have won 100+ matches with certain races and/or whose decks consist of mostly rare, epic, and legendary cards: If you don't spend money on buying additional cards you will get DESTROYED.Still, definitely worth checking out!

Its crazy to know a game this good and cool is free?! Its rare to find a free to play game this well made free. Tho it does have a few pay to win aspects to it. But other than that i am happy with this game and the results. and i wish the community was a bit more active on this game. Two thumbs up to the devs and the game! Play it, you will not regret itand its free!

content:
Posted: January 7
												One of those collectible card game strategy things that was released recently, which is trying most probably to the Hearthstone's child. And you can see the similarities everywhere, from the start menu and the buttons displayed, including the layout and the models of minion abilities and hero powers. However, this one is a what i can call an hybrid that combines the Hearthstone mechanics and add some new twists to it, like a real positioning or a different attack style for every minion. The thing is, I don't know why they really wanted to apply that bright retro aesthetic. Visually seems nice, but it fails to leave any impression, and for some, pixel art it's as bad as oldish things. Overall, it's nice, short, and good to waste your time with from time to time. Nor bad nor good.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												+It's a fun game, easy to learn, difficult to master. +Quick matches+Can only communicate with emotes (no mouthy people swearing at you when they're losing)+Stunningly animated sprites+Fantastic music+Challenges (both fixed and daily) help you learn game mechanics+Plethora of beautifully illustrated texts really flush out the world+Earn in game currency to buy new cards (albeit slowly)The only real negative is that match making is rough, you rapidly get paired with people that have won 100+ matches with certain races and/or whose decks consist of mostly rare, epic, and legendary cards: If you don't spend money on buying additional cards you will get DESTROYED.Still, definitely worth checking out!

												Just wanna drop a thumbs up for my favourite card game which I've played at least 600 games of :)-the balance is pretty decent but far from perfect although the devs are showing the will to slowly change the worst offenders-good news is the tactical board and the replace mechanic makes for some very important play decisions apart from just playing the best card(s) for your mana and lets good players really pull ahead-the free to play rewards are the best I've seen so far in a card game-fun single player puzzles to learn the game mechanics and a new quest puzzle each day to shake things up a bit-wasn't super excited about the graphics at first but now I've grown to love a lot of the pixels, there is also an option for a community made graphics upgrade which makes a comic style black border around the models

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Just ignore most of the negative reviews. They either hate it because the keep losing to a faction due to their own ignorance on how to play or they haven't played enough to really know anything about the game. I am writing this review after having played for 37 hours without paying any money on this game and I'm still addicted and win more than half of my games as a f2p player.(I do plan on buying the preorder to the expansion because I think the game designers deserve to make some money)Before I begin this next statement I should say that I don't mean to bash Blizzard, I think they make amazing games but IMO Hearthstone is increadibly unbalanced for beginners. I came to this game from Hearthstone and haven't gone back since. This game is so much more fair to beginners. I started Hearthstone about a year ago and I can't win but once ever 5 games or so because about half way through a game someone pulls out a legendary and♥♥♥♥♥♥stomps my basic little $20 deck. The great thing about Duelyst is that no matter what faction you play, they all have removal cards so even if someone has a legendary or two you can still remove it from the field and have a fighting chance. Not to mention most legendaries aren't much more powerful than regular cards.Keep up the good work Counterplay Games! Can't wait for the mobile release!!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												I backed this on Kickstarter and have been playing since alpha.  It's changed quite a bit but the core mechanics have always been fantastic.  Making a good deck is only half of the challenge as you need to learn about positioning for your minions.  It's a nice extra and welcome layer of depth in a CCG.  The company is much more hands-on in terms of balancing and they're not afraid to make changes to cards and factions.  They've done a very good job in that aspect, far more than other companies.Every faction is unique and there's multiple heroes for each with their own ability and expands into their own style of play.  The first expansion comes out at the end of August and it looks promising.  There's many things they have laid out in terms of what they plan to release in the near and distant future.  I'm excited to see how it turns out but playing this for over a year now I know it's in pretty good hands.  If you're in the market for a good card game that offers more than just casual play this is something you should definitely consider.  They do a good job of introducing the game and how it plays through their tutorial.  They have challenges that can earn you free stuff as well that are like puzzles.  They've even developed a story and lore you can listen to learn about the factions and world they all come from.  Give it a try.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												I honestly cannot stop playing this amazing game.What is it:  Imagine hearthstone mixed with chess!  It adds a whole new dimension of mechanics and they pull it off exceptionally well.  Be prepared to have a few sleepless nights playing this game. It's addictive, it's deep, and it's easy to learn, hard to master.I just joined a novice tournament, and I'm going to be coached by an s-rank player. I'm excited.I left Hearthstone because it got WAY too RNG, and the packs got way too stingy.Meta kept changing so rapidly and I couldn't possibly keep up with it with how stingy the legendary releases were.I opened an orb today and got two legendaries. ♥♥♥♥in yes.  1 in 4 orbs has a legendary, every 2 wins you get 15 gold, every day you get about 75 gold in challenges.  Most people get about 2 orbs a day, so that's about 15 legendaries a month just playing completely free.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												I've been playing this game a couple of months but it came out on Steam today. Highly recommended to anyone. I absolutely love it. I never really fancied other card games because of the lack of a physical presence but this game involves turn based strategy on a grid - kinda like that chess game Chewbacca plays in Star Wars. It's absolutely fantastic and highly addictive.The only issue I have is that I don't like their transaction system. Although you can get spirit orbs by playing you can also purchase them and they're completely random. So paying X amount of money for a product that's quality is generated at random is a bit of a joke to me, I don't dig it. People say it's the same as Hearthstone but fairer. Well, I don't really care, I didn't play Hearthstone, it's still a bad system.That said, it IS, possible to build competitive budget decks with Vanar (Kara) and Magmar (Vaath) then save up you spirit/gold for other decks - so you can go down that route if you don't want to pay.In spite of that one gripe I still highly recommend it. Give it a try and see for yourself.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												♥♥♥♥ing loved it , its like heartstone but with a chessboard! First 4 hrs and i have already gotten myself 4 legendaries. unique gameplay with interestingly animated 2D sprites.It is easy to play , very noob friendly too :).It is sad to say like , Heartstone , a popular tcg made by "blizzard" ,this game can be paid to win as you can use real money to buy packs which are used to unlock newer cards.Ladder division is rather simple , classed into 3 groups , bronze , silver and gold. Crafting is rather simple , enchanting cards and crafting better ones , those who has played online TCG would definitely know how the crafting system works.Right now , it is a little buggy , crashes when i try to make a new deck or edit my old ones. Apart from that , gameplay is smooth and fluent.Quest system is defintiely nice , has a unique "Daily Challenge" which challenges your mind with better tatics to destroy your opponents with.Overall , really like the game , and it might garner my support in the near future too. Further improvements can made , for example a more intricate ranking system etc.Update , 7hrs of playtime , game have been crashing every. single. match. Would not reccomend this to anyone who has a low tolerance of crashes until they fix this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												Man this game is so *good.* LooksI wasn't sure about the sci-fi fantasy thing they've got going on but quickly began to fall in love with it. The animations are excellent and bouncy and the character and unit design are incredibly unique and diverse. The soundtrack does a great job of tying it all together and the sound effects are just icing on the cake. Very visually pleasing game.GameplayTHIS GAME IS NOT PAY-TO-WIN. Like all smart people looking at the F2P section of Steam that's probably what you were looking for above everything else. Anyways, to continue:Turn-based summoning tactics. It feels almost like the table-top game Warmachine but if you took a faction deck and randomly drew spells/units and used whatever you got (But like, really well balanced because of Duelyst's mana system). You get a whole plethora of cards which you can use to populate your own custom decks and tailor them as much as you please.And talk about tactical depth: The abilities and stats of the units are somehow more diverse than their looks. There are some wild and winning combos (Though no clear meta builds which is good, anything seems to work it's just how smart you are going about combining unit abilities and spells), nothing seems bad. What I really like about playing online or against AI is that when you lose it doesn't feel like you got cheesed with a bad hand or the enemy used some OP combo: Really and truly it just feels like you were outplayed, (Which you were). The tutorial is incredibly helpful and they have a whole plethora of interesting custom challenges that not only earn you currency for spheres (Which poop out 5 random cards to add to your collection) but also challenge you to play out some more unique strategies which will improve your playing in normal games. I honestly appreciate it a lot, it's helped me grasp the logic this game plays best with.A Word on the In-Game TransactionsAs it is a free to play game, I figured I should address this as well. Like I said earlier, Duelyst certainly isn't a Pay-2-Win kind of game. Honestly the transactions are almost entirely for asthetic: It's stuff like emoticons for your generals, alternate skins, card-backs, and player icons. You can also use money to purchase spheres which, as I said before, give you random assortments of cards. I myself have not bought any nor felt the temptation too: The challenges and daily challenges reward you with coins upon completion and the spheres aren't terribly expensive. Will I buy some in the future after I've completed the 50 challenges that come with the game? I'll probably end up doing that but in-game purchases definitely are not a difference between winning and losing in this game, which is really fantastic.So yeah, Duelyst comes highly recommended and if you're a fan of any kind of turn-based game you owe it to yourself to try it out. The fact that it's free and a tiny install also helps. Great, great game.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												As one of the people lucky enough to stumble across this game in Beta i've had a good chance to jump on and see how it progressed... I played hearthstone for a good amount of time before starting duelyst and wondered how different it would be. It took me by surprise the level of strategy the board required of a player to progress anywhere in ranked despite the fact that I was only playing for fun, which brings me to one of the few problems i personally have with this game: the lack of a casual mode. I jumped back into the game after seeing an email mentioning that it had moved to steam and played a few rounds... there were some unbalanced card effects but the update on the 30th fixed some of them such as slithar elder being a 7 drop 8/8 that could potentially return to the field at the end of it's owners next turn and potentially (depending on the opponents plays) replicate every 2 turns and swarm the field, it was weakened to a much more reasonable 6/6. another notable change was shadow creeps deal a set 1 damage instead of doing more the more shadow creeps the controller has, is abyssian still an easier win that most other factions? yes. Will it be rebalanced more in the future? hopefully. If you fear not knowing the mechanics, there are solo challenges which are there to act as tutorials for beginners and daily challenges that can hold a challenge for experienced players. It has a draft format called gauntlet which is easily comparable to the arena in hearthstone for those who like more luck of the draw. The devs of this game don't unbalance the game with new updates that effect cards which means the only updates that might ruin the balance of the game is the release of a new set which will be balanced out quickly if they maintain their good work. Overall a great game and in time it will only get better.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Speaking as someone with a casual interest in real-life card games at best, and as someone who hasn't really gotten into digital card games at all, I'm actually really digging this game.Several of the game's basic mechanics work to reduce the effect that random chance has on your game, such as the ability to redraw two cards at the start and another on every turn, or influencing RNG through the placement of your units.  Matchmaking feels well-balanced as well, and even building decks is easy enough to get into.  The majority of the matches I've lost, I felt it was not because my cards were outmatched or because RNG was against me, but because I was making poor decisions.The game also includes a lengthy series of single-player challenges that build a puzzle around specific game mechanics for you to solve; if you enjoy solving puzzles, you'll find a few hours of entertainment in that alone, and learn how the different mechanics work in the process, which will guide you in how you'll build your decks.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
												I've been playing this game a couple of months but it came out on Steam today. Highly recommended to anyone. I absolutely love it. I never really fancied other card games because of the lack of a physical presence but this game involves turn based strategy on a grid - kinda like that chess game Chewbacca plays in Star Wars. It's absolutely fantastic and highly addictive.The only issue I have is that I don't like their transaction system. Although you can get spirit orbs by playing you can also purchase them and they're completely random. So paying X amount of money for a product that's quality is generated at random is a bit of a joke to me, I don't dig it. People say it's the same as Hearthstone but fairer. Well, I don't really care, I didn't play Hearthstone, it's still a bad system.That said, it IS, possible to build competitive budget decks with Vanar (Kara) and Magmar (Vaath) then save up you spirit/gold for other decks - so you can go down that route if you don't want to pay.In spite of that one gripe I still highly recommend it. Give it a try and see for yourself.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												♥♥♥♥ing loved it , its like heartstone but with a chessboard! First 4 hrs and i have already gotten myself 4 legendaries. unique gameplay with interestingly animated 2D sprites.It is easy to play , very noob friendly too :).It is sad to say like , Heartstone , a popular tcg made by "blizzard" ,this game can be paid to win as you can use real money to buy packs which are used to unlock newer cards.Ladder division is rather simple , classed into 3 groups , bronze , silver and gold. Crafting is rather simple , enchanting cards and crafting better ones , those who has played online TCG would definitely know how the crafting system works.Right now , it is a little buggy , crashes when i try to make a new deck or edit my old ones. Apart from that , gameplay is smooth and fluent.Quest system is defintiely nice , has a unique "Daily Challenge" which challenges your mind with better tatics to destroy your opponents with.Overall , really like the game , and it might garner my support in the near future too. Further improvements can made , for example a more intricate ranking system etc.Update , 7hrs of playtime , game have been crashing every. single. match. Would not reccomend this to anyone who has a low tolerance of crashes until they fix this.

We fight for our honor, as Lyonar Kingdom, as Space Lyonars, and we fight in the name of the General Demigod Argeon! If we die this day, we die in glory. We die heroes' deaths! But we shall not die, no, it is the enemy who will taste death and defeat! As You Know, most of our battle-Lyonars are stationed in space, prepared to deep strike! Our perimeter has been prepared in the event that our enemy should be so bold and so foolish! We have placed numerous beacons, allowing for multiple, simultaneous and devastating defensive deep strikes. The Codex Astartes names this maneuver "Steel Rain". We will descend upon the foe, we will overwhelm them, we will leave none alive! Meanwhile, our ground forces will ensure the full defense of our General... We are the Space Lyonars! We are the General's fury!

content:

												A tactical card game that many people compare to Hearthstone... The board alone makes it better than HS, at least in my opinion. The legendary drop rates are much better than other CCGs, the gold here to buy packs is super easy to get (you can get 2 packs a day if you win 14 games. 1 pack if you just do the dailies that consist of "play" [not win] as some factions and dealing certain ammounts of damage).All the factions are relatively balanced. Of course some are stronger than others but every faction is capable of reaching S-Rank, the highest.Even the most budget decks can reach S-Rank too since this game values positioning so much. It's not P2W at all, and anyone who says otherwise is clearly tilted because they suck or has no knowledge whatsoever about the game.

Whether you want to delve deep into (Yes, this game has lore, and its epic), or just need something to pass the time Duelyst has something for you. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												Pretty much the only online cardgame I enjoyed playing for more than 15min, which is saying something. The cards have ample strategic assets to them which make every game an unique one within just a few turns, and I'm not talking about rare cards you'll have to buy. Even with the starter packs there are already a huge amount of easily comprehendable spells and skills that make every game about strategy rather than raw stats or who has the shiniest cards. Most impressing about this is that none of the factions appear rediculously OP while they each have their own cards and gimmick.And there are a bunch of strategy challenges to defeat an AI opponent within one turn that will really help to understand all the skills and their potentials, which are also really enjoyable if you like puzzle games.But what I appreciate most about this game is that you can do what you want even if your previous move is still being executed. If you move a minion to a different tile, you can click on that tile and tell the minion to attack, drag a new card onto the field and end your turn while that minion walks to the tile. And everything will be executed as you ordered in correct order, rather than you having to wait until the moving sequence ends before you can do anything else.All in all a very enjoyable game.

content:

												A tactical card game that many people compare to Hearthstone... The board alone makes it better than HS, at least in my opinion. The legendary drop rates are much better than other CCGs, the gold here to buy packs is super easy to get (you can get 2 packs a day if you win 14 games. 1 pack if you just do the dailies that consist of "play" [not win] as some factions and dealing certain ammounts of damage).All the factions are relatively balanced. Of course some are stronger than others but every faction is capable of reaching S-Rank, the highest.Even the most budget decks can reach S-Rank too since this game values positioning so much. It's not P2W at all, and anyone who says otherwise is clearly tilted because they suck or has no knowledge whatsoever about the game.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												A TCG in which you collect cards and use them to battle your opponent. The battles work in a fashion similar to Final Fantasy Tactics games - you have to place your units strategically to claim victory. There are several factions that all have several leaders - if he dies, the game is over, so killing him is your goal. The factions are all different and focus on different strengths and weaknesses - there is no faction canceling another out completely, though, so you always have some tactical room.Overall the game is very nice, looks good (very appealing pixel art on 2D-backgrounds - takes some time getting used to but is certainly an interesting style), is balanced, !NOT P2W! and is all around fun.Recommended!

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Speaking as someone with a casual interest in real-life card games at best, and as someone who hasn't really gotten into digital card games at all, I'm actually really digging this game.Several of the game's basic mechanics work to reduce the effect that random chance has on your game, such as the ability to redraw two cards at the start and another on every turn, or influencing RNG through the placement of your units.  Matchmaking feels well-balanced as well, and even building decks is easy enough to get into.  The majority of the matches I've lost, I felt it was not because my cards were outmatched or because RNG was against me, but because I was making poor decisions.The game also includes a lengthy series of single-player challenges that build a puzzle around specific game mechanics for you to solve; if you enjoy solving puzzles, you'll find a few hours of entertainment in that alone, and learn how the different mechanics work in the process, which will guide you in how you'll build your decks.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												A deck-based game, similar to Hearthstone or Magic: The Gathering, with the caveat that there is a board-- space is an important dimension here, and it really adds a lot to the strategy element.  While many matches can have good luck or bad luck of the draw, it feels like most often, the better player will tend to come out on top (though not always!).Duelyst features a pretty cool aesthetic, kickass music, sound strategy, and a business model that (so far) doesn't feel like pay-walling.  The starter decks are actually pretty effective, and the most uncommon cards generally have the most complicated and obscure effects, without being straight upgrades.The combos you can chain up quickly reach the point of ridicule, where virtually every deck can have that "Oh wow, that's such incredible BS" reaction.  But the fun thing is the BS often can go both ways.Games are short (usually <5 minutes a match).  Comebacks are frequent.  Streaks, win or lose, usually no more than 4 or 5 games.  Pretty addictive game, in general.  I would consider this a solid, reasonably balanced, turn-based strategy, but sometimes heavily luck-influenced.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												It's turn based tactics meets Hearthstone. But unlike HS, Duelyst actually offers a little more depth and way less RNG. It's way less grind as well. Legendaries are way easier to get, and cheaper to craft. The only downside is that it seems to be a little unbalanced. Ranged minions can attack from anywhere in the battlefield, so the usual strategy to them seems to be: put them in a remote corner and buff them as you watch your opponent wastes prime removal to destroy your 3 mana creature. Same thing with blast minions, that does damage to every single minion in a line from affar. Why can't ranged minions work the same way they do in fire emblem or advance wars? And wouldn't it be better if blast minion did damage to their own cretures as well? Wouldn't it be a little more balanced this way?But overral, it's a good game. Way better than Hearthstone, I say.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Great combination of CCG and tactical game play. The whole game is generally very well produced, the cards are generally well balanced, and there are plenty of opportunities to obtain gold to get new cards. One can complete quests without actually winning games, so that makes it easier to complete your card collection.   Gameplay is tense and interesting, and positioning and other board decisions are just as important as deck building and choice of card play. The opportunity to swap a card out of your hand for a fresh one each turn is great, and helps you feel less at the whim of random luck.   There have been some growing pains, as the steam release (and now a week later, the release of the first major expansion (including 105 new cards)) has been pretty hard on the servers. But representatives of Counterplay have been active on the forums here on steam, on the Discord chat, and on Reddit, and have been very helpful. Customer support was great and prompt when I had an issue. I'm looking forward to playing this one a lot.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
Since the day I downloaded this game, there is not a day that goes by that I don't play this game.Duelyst is a game developed and published by Counterplay Games[duelyst.com]. A competitive game focused on tactical combat, squad building, and ranked ladder play.Duelyst is a perfect mix between CCG and chess. The matches are played out on a five-by-nine board that starts with just you and your opponent’s general. Each general has a unique Spell. Like most other CCGs, you draw cards from a custom built deck, play spells, and summon minions until you’ve killed the opposing general. The card pool is split into six factions, each with their own unique style, along with a large group of neutral cards. Right now, I'm starting to like the playstyle of Vanar and Songhai. All six factions feel unique and expressive, in both their playstyles and their art.And speaking of art. This is a major high point of Duelyst. Pixel art has become a popular option among indie developers, and is associated by some skeptics with a lack of resources to make something ‘better.’ But Duelyst’s sprites feature some of the greatest pixel art animation I’ve ever seen. Only the units and card effects are pixelated, but the extreme level of detail that goes into each one is stunning. And thanks to Duelyst’s dynamic lighting system, the sprites don’t feel out of place in its non-pixelated battlefields and UI.  Alough the game offers you in-game purchases where you could buy Spirit Orbs—Duelyst's version of pack of cards. It turns out to be really rewarding since you get gold for winning games and completing daily quests.The Verdict: 9 out of 10. My new favorite card game! ♥ But I'm still waiting for Gwent[www.playgwent.com] to come out.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												A deck-based game, similar to Hearthstone or Magic: The Gathering, with the caveat that there is a board-- space is an important dimension here, and it really adds a lot to the strategy element.  While many matches can have good luck or bad luck of the draw, it feels like most often, the better player will tend to come out on top (though not always!).Duelyst features a pretty cool aesthetic, kickass music, sound strategy, and a business model that (so far) doesn't feel like pay-walling.  The starter decks are actually pretty effective, and the most uncommon cards generally have the most complicated and obscure effects, without being straight upgrades.The combos you can chain up quickly reach the point of ridicule, where virtually every deck can have that "Oh wow, that's such incredible BS" reaction.  But the fun thing is the BS often can go both ways.Games are short (usually <5 minutes a match).  Comebacks are frequent.  Streaks, win or lose, usually no more than 4 or 5 games.  Pretty addictive game, in general.  I would consider this a solid, reasonably balanced, turn-based strategy, but sometimes heavily luck-influenced.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												It's turn based tactics meets Hearthstone. But unlike HS, Duelyst actually offers a little more depth and way less RNG. It's way less grind as well. Legendaries are way easier to get, and cheaper to craft. The only downside is that it seems to be a little unbalanced. Ranged minions can attack from anywhere in the battlefield, so the usual strategy to them seems to be: put them in a remote corner and buff them as you watch your opponent wastes prime removal to destroy your 3 mana creature. Same thing with blast minions, that does damage to every single minion in a line from affar. Why can't ranged minions work the same way they do in fire emblem or advance wars? And wouldn't it be better if blast minion did damage to their own cretures as well? Wouldn't it be a little more balanced this way?But overral, it's a good game. Way better than Hearthstone, I say.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												Great combination of CCG and tactical game play. The whole game is generally very well produced, the cards are generally well balanced, and there are plenty of opportunities to obtain gold to get new cards. One can complete quests without actually winning games, so that makes it easier to complete your card collection.   Gameplay is tense and interesting, and positioning and other board decisions are just as important as deck building and choice of card play. The opportunity to swap a card out of your hand for a fresh one each turn is great, and helps you feel less at the whim of random luck.   There have been some growing pains, as the steam release (and now a week later, the release of the first major expansion (including 105 new cards)) has been pretty hard on the servers. But representatives of Counterplay have been active on the forums here on steam, on the Discord chat, and on Reddit, and have been very helpful. Customer support was great and prompt when I had an issue. I'm looking forward to playing this one a lot.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
Since the day I downloaded this game, there is not a day that goes by that I don't play this game.Duelyst is a game developed and published by Counterplay Games[duelyst.com]. A competitive game focused on tactical combat, squad building, and ranked ladder play.Duelyst is a perfect mix between CCG and chess. The matches are played out on a five-by-nine board that starts with just you and your opponent’s general. Each general has a unique Spell. Like most other CCGs, you draw cards from a custom built deck, play spells, and summon minions until you’ve killed the opposing general. The card pool is split into six factions, each with their own unique style, along with a large group of neutral cards. Right now, I'm starting to like the playstyle of Vanar and Songhai. All six factions feel unique and expressive, in both their playstyles and their art.And speaking of art. This is a major high point of Duelyst. Pixel art has become a popular option among indie developers, and is associated by some skeptics with a lack of resources to make something ‘better.’ But Duelyst’s sprites feature some of the greatest pixel art animation I’ve ever seen. Only the units and card effects are pixelated, but the extreme level of detail that goes into each one is stunning. And thanks to Duelyst’s dynamic lighting system, the sprites don’t feel out of place in its non-pixelated battlefields and UI.  Alough the game offers you in-game purchases where you could buy Spirit Orbs—Duelyst's version of pack of cards. It turns out to be really rewarding since you get gold for winning games and completing daily quests.The Verdict: 9 out of 10. My new favorite card game! ♥ But I'm still waiting for Gwent[www.playgwent.com] to come out.

Love the extra dimension of decisionmaking the 9x5 grid brings, love the consistency that being able to replace a card in your hand every turn brings (essentially discard then draw), and overall it feels like you're less of a victim to variance than in most games of its nature.The game uses digital design space well, has a healthy amount of randomness without being sickeningly forced like in HS, and I'm overall excited for the future of this game.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												I was a player of Duelyst before it even came out to Steam, and from the moment I started playing I already knew that I would recommend it.Firstly, if you think the game is a Hearthstone ripoff, it is not.The game does clearly have core elements of Hearthstone, such as mana costs, health and attack statistics, as well as summoning minions and trying to reduce the opponent's character to zero health. While that may seem so similar, there is one aspect that makes the game completely different- the 9 x 5 board.Adding a tiled board space to move around in instantly makes the game much more intriguing than it already may have been. Matches play out differently, you're forced to think differently, and, there are more chances to win.However, that's all besides the point.You should get this game already because its just awesome. Heartstone is great, but Duelyst brings it up another notch. If you like Hearthstone, you'll love this just as much or more. (and even more if chess is another one of your things)Duelyst's art style and character design are absolutely jaw-dropping. Even if the graphics are pixel based... Each unit or general are so well crafted and each look unique. Each unit also has individual attack animations which usually look stunning for pixel graphics.Battles are fast and end usually under 10 minutes. The only bad things I have to say is that the art style, while great and unique, isn't very cohesive (sleek, sci-fi to pixels), and there is of course some minor balancing issues (but what game doesn't have those).Tl:dr- get this game plz

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I've been playing this for a long time before it hit Steam. I had been on the lookout for a nice CCG for a while, as I really enjoyed Hearthstone, but found it way too grindy. For me, this is the one. The gameplay is fairly simple and easy to get into. The tactical grid is nice, it allows for positioning to come into play, and increases the skill beyond just drawing and playing the right cards. Many good players have in fact reached high ranks playing supposedly weak factions or decks just because they are skilled at the game, so while there are always some slight imbalances, all factions are represented at high levels (and at lower levels too).Card acquisition is a lot more generous than Hearthstone, you get gold pretty easily from doing daily quests, enough to easily buy a pack of cards every day. The base set also has a fairly high legendary drop rate, although they tuned this down a bit in the expansion.The art style is an acquired taste, the pixel art is great, but the mixture of arts styles is a bit odd. You get used to it.For me, this is the best online CCG I have tried by far, and it's free, so I would highly recommend giving it a go.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												Having come with a background in both TCGs and CCGs, I can honestly say that Duelyst is among the top of my list. Forget traditional games such as Yu-Gi-Oh or Magic; Duelyst takes a different approach by presenting players with a tactical board in which they are free to move, summon, and battle upon. Put in simpler terms, imagine a better Hearthstone — albeit not completely ridding itself of the microtransaction aspect. Without further adue, I'll dive into the comparisons. Pros: — Extreme replayability.— A plethora of cards to obtain and use.— Dynamic battle system and well-scripted animations.— A faction system in which each "General" possesses his/her own unique ability.— Ability to play against friends or against randoms.— Ranking system is relatively easy to climb without punishing you too hard for losing.— Uh guys.... this game is free!?Cons: — Can be considered a semi pay-to-win game. — If you're willing to invest money, then you have a higher chance at getting better cards as opposed to those who didn't.— Doesn't have Harambe as a character.— Simple to pick up but hard to master. Anyone is welcome to message me more if you'd like more insight! Peace~

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												+It's a fun game, easy to learn, difficult to master. +Quick matches+Can only communicate with emotes (no mouthy people swearing at you when they're losing)+Stunningly animated sprites+Fantastic music+Challenges (both fixed and daily) help you learn game mechanics+Plethora of beautifully illustrated texts really flush out the world+Earn in game currency to buy new cards (albeit slowly)The only real negative is that match making is rough, you rapidly get paired with people that have won 100+ matches with certain races and/or whose decks consist of mostly rare, epic, and legendary cards: If you don't spend money on buying additional cards you will get DESTROYED.Still, definitely worth checking out!

content:
Posted: January 6
												Wizard Chess at it's finest. You won't find a F2P CCG that matches the quality you can find in Duelyst. A generous Quest system allows for many ways for F2P players to gather or craft cards and effluvia, and buying in isn't painful with entire sets for sale.I've been wanting a game just like this since I played Archon epochs ago, a fantasy strategy game played on a board. The card aspect makes building decks so much fun, because you have to take in effect how they will synergize on the board, adding a whole tactical layer I find intoxicating. It's a really tight, crunchy, fast and brutal game. The sound design, sprite animations, the entire package. . . it's just so damn good. The best in it's genre even.Magmar for life.

												That moment when you cover almost entire map by your wrathlings and the enemy uses one spell to wipe them all out...but now seriously (tru story tho)   + love the art style and soundtrack   + after one day of playing i already got legendary   + really often patched (2 per month)   + new cards every day just for completing 3 dailies   + it's mix of HOMAM and CCG !   + referral system   + you can chat with your ingame friends while playing ranked games...so they know you got deleted when you suddenly stop replying   + free gold for completing challenges (they are really easy)   - i got wiped in practise   - cosmetic crates with emotes and shiny units (with the exact same stats as the non-shining) are rather expensive, but you get shiny units of the faction you play just by leveling it up..so.. in the end the - is, that you'll have only 1 laughing emote when you outplay    ° so far no casual mode, but given its concept, i have my hopes even for coop someday, since developers listen to the communityThere are 6 factions so far, but each has 2 heroes (you unlock the second one by playing for the faction) which in the end allows us a lot of different kinds of playstyle, whether it's summonning undeads everywhere or backstabbing everyone and everything using teleport. So in the end, i love the concept, I´m a huge fan of both turn based strategies and CCG, so the mix of both is just awesome, 10/10 one of the best f2p CCG turned based games. Even if it's the only one. Still the best. I don't make sense anymore do I. ° Referral code (gives you 100 gold) - aquillacz °

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												I’ve long been a fan of turn-based tactics games. From playing chess against my dad at a young age, through to the perfection of Advance Wars and the bizarre depths of Disgaeia, i’m a sucker for ponderous battles. I’ve recently acquired a taste for card games too, thanks to the likes of Netrunner and Hearthstone, so when Deulyst – a fusion of turn-based tactics and card game – popped up on my radar, my eyes lit up.Deulyst is essentially Hero Academy mashed together with Hearthstone – a mix of ever-increasing-mana-fuelled card play and unit movement where two opposing General’s battle to the death, calling upon warriors and spells for help. Deciding which card to play also comes with the choice of where to play it, and how to move your existing warriors too. It’s the strategy of chess merged with the customisable depths of a modern card game, borrowing from its peers to make a beautifully designed and balanced game.It’s also surprisingly fast paced – a combination of quickly escalating powers, tight strategy and the combo potential of a customised deck. With a mix of painterly, vibrant sci-fi backgrounds and glowing, gorgeously animated pixel art monsters, Deulyst backs its robust gameplay with stunning visuals too.Each faction brings differing abilities and deck building options, and although you’ll probably have to spend some money on extra cards to get the most out of it, Deulyst is generous enough as it is, offering a sublime blend of pace, visuals and depth for nothing.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												I have not played long BUT in my personal opinion it is way better than hearthstone!Reasons why? Well these are based off of the few games i have played.Every situation can be changed with just a single card.You can replace one card each turn which makes it more likely to get the card you want just by replacing it with a useless one at the time being (No card is useless)Cons???? NOTHINGMORE PROThere is balance, If there is an OP combo then there is a simple way to disarm it, such as sun bloom (Dispels in a 2x2 radius) It can take away a really good spell combo in an instantTIP ~ But i have found a really OP combo. The youngflame wing and the Bastion with the Lyonar faction is really a scary combo if you have the cards named, Bastion, Youngflame wing, and a couple of divine bonds, Ofcourse there is a way to delete this whole combo, Have the youngflame wing and bastion out, do what you can to protect the youngflame wing while it gains health (If you can beat them before the combo is there than do it) and finally when the young flame wing reaches 10 health put 2 divine bonds on that baby and ta-da you have a 25 attack damage monster that can be anywhere on the board, If you happen to have 3 Divine bonds, Well then say hello to a 35 attack damage one hitting monsterBut like i said, There is balance so this combo can be undone in an instant if they know what you are up to. Nothing is possible here without it not having an easy counter. Good game I recommend it 100%

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
												Played this quite a while before it got to steam. It's by far the best digital CCG on the market. Where Hearthstone depends on RNG to differentiate matches that would otherwise be similar, duelyst's tactical grid leads to vastly different games based on subtle positioning changes- meaning every loss and victory owes significantly more to player skill, proper positioning, etc. The art (both large scale and the pixellated animated characters) is gorgeous, and the monetization system is fair. Just play it.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												A more in-depth review here along with gameplay vid: https://nohkgaming.wordpress.com/2016/08/03/now-playing-duelyst/TL;DR:Mechanics introduced by earlier card games like MtG are present with various awesome mixes of its own features. A card game with strategy built not solely on the cards alone but on where you place your minions, the timing of your spells, and the effective trading of your own HP and your minions to clear off your opponent's threats.Battle Pets still are unpredictable, and that's a healthy dose of randomness for the game.If you're tired of just playing a card game where you just /play your cards/, why not give this a try? Movement, placement, timing. All these come together to create a wonderful game!Plus, if you think card games like this are pay-to-win, you're dead wrong! I haven't spent a dime, and I've only started playing June 30, and I've gotten to Gold Division two times already with budget decks that can compete with even the fully-built archetype decks!

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												I have to say this fit's the genera very well. I was engrossed with the overall look and feel of the game; however, there was a distinct lack of things to do. For myself, endlessly grinding away in PvP dueling decks against other players was well done in Magic Online or another card games ad nausium. The game has a few annoyances as well, but let’s touch on the overall look and fee.The interface was intuitive and well designed, I felt like I could easily navigate throughout the game UI with a little critical reading and some of that age old common sense exploration. The Art and Sound of this game is amazing, I would have to say that the digital and concept art for this did nothing to prepare me for the absolute breathtaking beauty of the actual game content itself. I will have this in my "go to" list for years to come along side Minecraft and Terraria.Now with a few of the problems with these types of games that is more player than developer in some cases. First I took issue with the progression system. In many cases people were exploiting the progression by auto queuing and idle timing out, or using lag code to prevent the client from establishing a connection during the initial connection phase. This exploit takes advantage of the "double win" scenario as well as help keep unskilled players higher in the ranks. Another exploit I was noticing is the play bots that we saw in Magic the Gathering Online. I do believe that in any competitive game the absence of these bots may never be possible with the way privacy and national policy provide. SO play as you wish but do not dig in and pretend you will never encounter issues, bots or bugs.As always play on, report bots and do your best to keep the community sassy!Best,Illian Amerond

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												Duelyst is a excellently crafted game, if Hearthstone had a baby with Fire Emblem, Duelyst would be born.Duelyst has the core gameplay of Hearthstone and they got the board mechanic of Fire Emblem, shoved them together with tinkering, threw in badass pixel art and said: "This is gonna be good", for now though, lets get into the core elements.User InterfaceRating - 7/10Similair to: Hearthstone, OverwatchThe interface has sleek elements from overwatch and that cursed gaussian blur (It lags out my Laptop D:) feature, It gives you core elements that you need to know without obscuring the main board in which you play, your hand is neatly placed and elements are where you want them. It loses points for losing certain important details and lag.CommunicationRating - 3/10Similair to: HearthstoneCommunication is bare bones, you have cute little emoticons and quotes which can be accessed from your icon, its not really practical and insulting those 1000 ping wimps is harder. Let alone valued conversations are hard to get, Imagine a post office where you can only say 15 things and add certain images or its filtered, its that bad.GameplayRating - 9/10Similair to: Fire EmblemThe gameplay is very intunuitive, with various card types dragged from hearthstone and put into the beatiful Fire Emblem style, encounters occur the same as FE, with hit-counter-end. Provoke cards tarap opponents who dare step near it and death wish cards do something when they die, archers are infinity range units, with all these card types and mana costs, its really deep and makes you revise.OnlineRating - 5/10Similair to: CSGOYou have to pass a certain point to go Online, like CSGO, thats all I know, I haven't got there.GraphicsRating - 10/10Similair to: None, its uniqueIts mixture of high quality imagery for portraits and card backs to the lovely little dudes you move across the board, each bit is polished and refined to its best ability, I can stare at the main menu for hours, its beautiful.Overall Rating 8/10Little to touch up except variety but this is lacking a bit of elements, but not so much that you should dismiss this great game, its also graphics moddable apparently.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												I've played since shortly after open beta, long before it was available on Steam, to get away from Hearthstone for a bit. It was a breathe of fresh air from the folks at Counter Play Games. Grid based card game. Say if Magic and Fire Emblem had a child, wrapped up into one cool sprited based draw fest. To keep this short, as there are many other reviews that would be better suited if you wanted an  overview, I've recently been pulled away from it to a recent change they did in the last patch with the gold progression/quest system. It is no longer casual friendly, and you will have to play more games each day to maximize your gold gain. Shame really. It was something Blizzard never did with Hearthstone, and now Counter Play went down the same road. This doesn't competely kill, what already is, a fantastic game, and a game that actually gets balance changes monthly, even bi-weekly, unlike already said card game. Play it. The sprites are amazing, the music and boards are great to look at, and the random number generator is very very minimmal.

												Great game with nice use of positioning along with position-based mechanics and spells. Just wish for the following: Less of: - One-click AoE board clears (frost burn, enfeeble, plasma storm etc.)- Lessen impact on do-or-die threats the moment they hit the board (all CCGs have this stupid gimmick)More of: - Positional spells/minions, particularly AoE spells that punish bad positioning.- Revolve the game around value minion trades (or face) instead of crap like Meltdown/JuggernautsOverall, I will still highly recommend this game over other CCGs.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13
												Let's keep it simple: Give this game a try if you like to use your brain and be rewarded for good tactics. It's also free, tested with Norton for pesky viruses ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)Superficial Pros:Beautiful (and unique) art-styleLiking the Minimalistic "tablet-friendly" design; it sounds weird but I like the minimalismThe animations of the units are beyond satisfying to watchPros:Addictive (maybe a pro?)Very flexible but not spared from metas; I didn't feel the meta influence as heavily as in HearthStoneCan perform okay with the starter deckYou need to actually use tactics! WOW! What a feature! Each faction represents a unique playstyle (veree nais)Superficial cons: The menu UI design is case of form over functionSomewhat eggregious microtransactions (yes, I know it's a F2P title, they're still bad)Seriously, (worthless) Boss Cases drop from fun Boss Battles, locking rewards away through a paywall. Classic.Cons:Buggier than the Beta Crashes or gets stuck on certain menus/pages (most often in the crafting menu, happens everywhere else though)No Steam Overlay support - you need to login seperately to give them microtransaction money (I put this here because it's really frickity frick fricking frustrating)Abyssian Cancer Host <3This game is unique, I hate the microtransactions, feels like style is focused on while substance takes second , or even third place. Try it out and don't be a frugal ♥♥♥♥♥ like me, you won't be disappointed <3

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												If you like CCG + strategy games this is a must! Made by a small team, Counterplay Games managed to create an amazing and involving game, with rich mechanics, cool art style and rich lore. Don't be fooled thinking this is a copy of Hearthstone, besides some UI similarities, the addition of the board make the position aspect of the game very important and create some interesting situations. The game play is way more dense and skill related. Every factions and general (yes, generals, even being from the same faction, have different abilities called Bloodbourne Spells) feels very unique, not only for their looks and lore but also their playstyle. Its common to spend hours just creating and tweaking decks based on different cards, strategies and generals. The game is also very generous with card drops, and the usual chance to get a Legendary is 1 for 4 packs. And its not uncommon to get even 2 Legs per pack. Give it a chance, you wont regret!

content:
Posted: March 20
												First of all I really hope the devs read my review because I'll be super sincere. Sorry for the long post.Second, I play this game on my secondary account not this one.---Quick review for player in the end---For me there are only three online CCG that are worth to play: Hearthstone, Faeria and Duelyst.I played Hearthstone since beta and now I'm quitting because of the P2W fator. Even playing ever day I never pass rank 10, I belive this is the limit of F2P player on Hearthstone.So I tested Faeria and Duelyst, both are great game, much less P2W then Hearthstone once the games also make money with cosmetics. Don't get me wrong, I understand the devs must earn money so I see no problem in selling card packs for money, even though I believe Faeria and Duelyst can be a little bit generous. So, for me, the optimum point could be able have like 80% of a card expansion (without spending money) 4 or 6 weeks before the relaese of the next expansion. I'll test Duelyst until the next expansion comes to see if I'm able to do so, same goes to Faeria.Now talking about only Duelyst: It's a solid game, original, even being original you'll feel that you already now everything you must know. The matches are quick and there aren't those 2 or 3 turns where the players just pass to each other waiting to reach 3 mana cuz your starting hand is too heavy. Talking about hand you can replace one card of your hand every turn! The lore idea is super nice. Okay now we are entering the bad side: Duelyst have few problems and one big situation that isn't its fault. Duelyst doesn't have a casual mode where you can test your new decks and I'd really want to know why. Most of the game is in pixel art (some people don't like it) which I personally love. Besides that there is nothing more to complain, maybe the solo mode is too short? Or they could have introduce a coop mode (I really want it) ? But these are not negative side, the game just don't have it yet (please coop mode!!). The major problem of Duelyst is not Duelyst but the CCG genre, because of the fact you must farm gold to buy the card packs you can't play two CCG, you must choose one, it's not like playing Zelda and Horizon where you can alternate to progress in both games. For example my gf don't like hearthstone anymore, but she also don't quit to start anothe CCG cuz she don't want to lose her progress. So with this in mind I can see that on PC the CCG genre is dominated by Hearthstone and Faeria is slowly rising with new good ideas.I must say that for me Duelyst is more fun than Faeria but due to the fact of the coop anouncment I'll be forced to play Faeria on PC. NOW PAY ATTENTION: Duelyst will totally dominate the CCG mobile market when it release for Android and iOS. So, that's why I'll keep playing Duelyst too, because as a mobile experience it'll humiliate Hearthstone.More than card I belive Duelyst just need three things for now, which should not prevent you to play it: a casual mode, a coop mode and add a mobile version.--- Quick player review ---1) Pros:- Original- Easier to get ingame gold than Hearthstone- Tactical (so epic/legend cards doesnt have that impact on gameplay)- You can literally move your General on battlefield.- Lore (a lot of)- Nice art and fantasy world.- Solo mode (short, but there is one)- Factions Instead of classes- You can unlock all characters just playing- Minions create life when you play (full body and stuff)- You can buy card pack more easy than Hearstone- Expansions have less cards, so more easy to "catch'em all"- There is some cosmetics, if you want to spend some real money to look cool- If you eventually buy the $49,99 card pack they refund you with the ingame gold that you spent previously2) Neutral- Pixel art (I love it in fact, but some don't)- Generals have no voice lines (I really don't care about it)3) Cons- Without spending money for cosmetics you must get a box of cosmetics + a key, this is a little anouying.- No casual mode so far- For me, ranged minions are a little OP.4) Veredic: If you are tired of Hearthstone or you like tactical and CCG game you must play it. Duelyst is underrated, it worth a check.Score: 9.0/10.0 (I'll give 11/10 when it has a casual and coop mode, wait for it)All the best

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												If you want a really good card game, with great strategy and community, where you can play the best decks, go play Android: Netrunner on Jinteki.net (seriously, fantastic game and using jinteki you get access to every card in the game). If you want rankings, join an online league. (A:NR is a Live Card Game, a LCG. So no randomisation of card packs)However, if you want a really good card game that's also a grind, this is is better. Playing a reasonable amount - a few hours a day after work, a few more than that on the weekends - you get to open about 1 booster a day of play. It's fun to slowly (very slowly, to be fair) build up your collection. Dismantling a few cards to craft new ones you need to improve your decks to make it easily to win games and get the gold you need to buy more boosters and get more packs.I focus on this last point becuase I thinks it's the only thing that makes me play it over A:NR, the working towards a collection.However, I play it over other CCGs such as Magic and HS because it is a superior game. The mechanics are more fun, it's less pay to win, a budget deck can perform well against decks with legendary cards. It's a mix between card game and board game. It reminds me of the board game Summoner Wars, but you can't play that online with the same sort of development support.Overall, I think this game is good fun, I really enjoy it! But it's a huge time sink - beware before you play. I also believe the cost to buy 'orbs', the game's booster packs are too expensive for what you get. If you want to play everything, and not drop loads of money/time before you can, please go check out Netrunner on Jinteki.net first.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												Duelyst is a pretty interesting game. It plays very similarly to Magic The Gathering and Hearthstone in that it uses the Cost/Health/Damage formula for it's units, but adds a neat little twist. Units placed on the board can be moved around like chess pieces (and in most cases must be next to an opponent's unit to attack it). It's a nice change of pace for a card game that holds your interest very early on, but one problem I find is that it gradually loses the hold on your attention span, especially if you're a long term player of Magic or Hearthstone.

												This is my first strategy-card game and I was amazed at how easy it was to fall into the tactics, decks, and community. The models have the an attracitve minimalistic style which does not at all exemplify the depth and complexity the game exhibits. Coming from a Civilization 5 background, I found this game to have all the fun qualities of Civ 5's combat system (Positioning, Damage/health, special attributes), but condensed into a more competitive, short-term strategy game (compared to civ). Kk gotta git gud and build my Aggro Magmar Deck.Overall, Chess on ecstasy, 9.5/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												Pay no heed to how much time i have in this game. I just downloaded it on steam, but i've been playing it for awhile now if you go take a look at my achivements.  I just thought i should give it a review cause it deserves one. Duelysts is a Card Game where you bring your characters to life on a board. My first time playing duelysts i found that it was a very easy concept that was actually rather diffucult once you got into it. My experience with other games like hearthstone was that they were more complicated then this one is, and once you got the hang of it, rather the same more or less. You start out with a basic tutorial that will show you how to move your minions and general, and it will show you how to use your cards. After that you're basically more or less on your own if you go into online games. They have solo challenges that are diffucult enough that it takes some time to figure some of them out until you get the hang of the game a bit more, and the challenges themselves open you up to game mechanics that you probably wouldn't know that were there in the first place. Further more they have what they call the Daily Challenge in which they give you a hard puzzle to solve. Some are easier then others, but most of the time they will give you a run for your money. You get about 4 quests each day which give you gold, which you use to buy spirit orbs which give you cards. The quests are rather repetivitve, but sometimes you get a different one. as for the gameplay itself, you will lose. In this game alot of the way you win is about placement, and how you clear the board and such. When starting out you will lose, when making your way up the ranks you will lose. But you will also get better each time you do lose. You will be able to realize the mistakes that you're making, and fix them before they become too bad for you to fix, as well as recognize when your opponent makes a mistake that you can take advantage of. Basically this game to me is a 10/10 game. Free to play, and fun to play as well, with the promise of always getting better each time you press the find match button, I'd seriously reccomend this to people. Even if you don't like card games, I'd reccomend to try this one out before writing it off. Awesome game.

content:
Posted: March 20
												First of all I really hope the devs read my review because I'll be super sincere. Sorry for the long post.Second, I play this game on my secondary account not this one.---Quick review for player in the end---For me there are only three online CCG that are worth to play: Hearthstone, Faeria and Duelyst.I played Hearthstone since beta and now I'm quitting because of the P2W fator. Even playing ever day I never pass rank 10, I belive this is the limit of F2P player on Hearthstone.So I tested Faeria and Duelyst, both are great game, much less P2W then Hearthstone once the games also make money with cosmetics. Don't get me wrong, I understand the devs must earn money so I see no problem in selling card packs for money, even though I believe Faeria and Duelyst can be a little bit generous. So, for me, the optimum point could be able have like 80% of a card expansion (without spending money) 4 or 6 weeks before the relaese of the next expansion. I'll test Duelyst until the next expansion comes to see if I'm able to do so, same goes to Faeria.Now talking about only Duelyst: It's a solid game, original, even being original you'll feel that you already now everything you must know. The matches are quick and there aren't those 2 or 3 turns where the players just pass to each other waiting to reach 3 mana cuz your starting hand is too heavy. Talking about hand you can replace one card of your hand every turn! The lore idea is super nice. Okay now we are entering the bad side: Duelyst have few problems and one big situation that isn't its fault. Duelyst doesn't have a casual mode where you can test your new decks and I'd really want to know why. Most of the game is in pixel art (some people don't like it) which I personally love. Besides that there is nothing more to complain, maybe the solo mode is too short? Or they could have introduce a coop mode (I really want it) ? But these are not negative side, the game just don't have it yet (please coop mode!!). The major problem of Duelyst is not Duelyst but the CCG genre, because of the fact you must farm gold to buy the card packs you can't play two CCG, you must choose one, it's not like playing Zelda and Horizon where you can alternate to progress in both games. For example my gf don't like hearthstone anymore, but she also don't quit to start anothe CCG cuz she don't want to lose her progress. So with this in mind I can see that on PC the CCG genre is dominated by Hearthstone and Faeria is slowly rising with new good ideas.I must say that for me Duelyst is more fun than Faeria but due to the fact of the coop anouncment I'll be forced to play Faeria on PC. NOW PAY ATTENTION: Duelyst will totally dominate the CCG mobile market when it release for Android and iOS. So, that's why I'll keep playing Duelyst too, because as a mobile experience it'll humiliate Hearthstone.More than card I belive Duelyst just need three things for now, which should not prevent you to play it: a casual mode, a coop mode and add a mobile version.--- Quick player review ---1) Pros:- Original- Easier to get ingame gold than Hearthstone- Tactical (so epic/legend cards doesnt have that impact on gameplay)- You can literally move your General on battlefield.- Lore (a lot of)- Nice art and fantasy world.- Solo mode (short, but there is one)- Factions Instead of classes- You can unlock all characters just playing- Minions create life when you play (full body and stuff)- You can buy card pack more easy than Hearstone- Expansions have less cards, so more easy to "catch'em all"- There is some cosmetics, if you want to spend some real money to look cool- If you eventually buy the $49,99 card pack they refund you with the ingame gold that you spent previously2) Neutral- Pixel art (I love it in fact, but some don't)- Generals have no voice lines (I really don't care about it)3) Cons- Without spending money for cosmetics you must get a box of cosmetics + a key, this is a little anouying.- No casual mode so far- For me, ranged minions are a little OP.4) Veredic: If you are tired of Hearthstone or you like tactical and CCG game you must play it. Duelyst is underrated, it worth a check.Score: 9.0/10.0 (I'll give 11/10 when it has a casual and coop mode, wait for it)All the best

												Duelyst is the kind of game I've been waiting for. Deck building strategy tied with grid based combat and sweet ANIMATED pizel art! Pros-Great unit variety between factions-extremely easy to earn booster packs without spending money. (I only play a couple hours a day and can easy get 2 or 3 a day based off my wins)-Beautiful, animated art.-Interesting Lore WITH AUDIO for those who don't want to read.-A large number of quick to complete solo challenges to help you learn mechanics that also reqard in game currency with each completed one.Cons- You don't draw a new card until the end of your turn which is really confusing at first.- Maps are always the same size grid, no elevation or anything like you'd see in say Final Fantasy tactics-With the option to spend money on it, there will inevitably be people with better stuff just because they dropped $20 on to a 'free' game BUT I really haven't ntoiced much disparity so far adn Devs need money to keep making cool stuff.-No "Story" mode which with the boat load of Lore they've developed is shocking and saddening.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												              Basically its hearthstone but where you have to do a little more work.  Your 'creatures' you summon are put on the map, each with various abilities.  You move them around tactics style, and try to just beat up your enemy.  Sounds fun, but I didn't enjoy it.  Felt too basic, much like hearthstone.  There are other games that do a much better job.  If you are trying to play casually, I recommend hearthstone over this.  If you are looking for something to sink your teeth into, Hex would be the way to go.  Hex blows almost all the other card games out of the water in my opinion (although I havn't been playing much, so it could have changed negatively)                  Unfortunately, with each of these games, there is a 'play to win' model in effect.  You can grind to where you want to go, but if you bring fat stacks and basic research to any of these online card games, you will find yourself 'pro' in no time.  Remember, this game is free, so if you are on the fence, the best way is to play it for an hour or two and decide for yourself.
