number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												My credentials:-Made it into S-rank, the top tier on the ladder.-12 win run in Gauntlet (the max).-Been playing about 8 months-Spent about $50 on the game.So what is Duelyst? Duelyst is a free-to-play CCG that uses a 5x9 board top play cards on. Each player has a general with 25HP and 2 ATK. Each unit can move 2 squares, and then attack (this includes generals, as they are units too). Each general belongs to a faction and has a unique "Bloodborne Spell", which refreshes at set intervals and doesn't cost a card. Your deck will consist of cards that are exclusive to your faction and the "Neutral" cards, which everyone can run. To get cards, you buy "Orbs" (aka packs of cards) with gold, the ingame currency. The resource system consists of a mana pool that grows each turn, and tiles on the board that act as "get +1 mana this turn" if you have a friendly unit walk over them. You draw one card each turn, and have the option to replace one card you dont want from your hand each turn, and you are guaranteed to not get the same card back.Why do I mention the replace mechanic specifically? Because the replace mechanic, along with the board, really set Duelyst apart from other CCGs. Since card games rely on Random Number Generators (or RNG) to create variance and make games play out differently, there will be times that you flat out lose due to simple chance. That is the nature of RNG. Duelyst's replace mechanic helps to minimize this as much as possible- if a card doesn't help you, throw it away and get a new one! Top-decking is less frustrating just because of that feature.As for the gameplay, it's awesome.-Games are relatively fast-paced-Every faction is viable at the highest levels (some generals are not as much, but you get the choice of 2 generals per faction)-Several different viable deck types-New players can, with enough skill, make it surprisingly high on the ladder without any investment.-Three copies of any given card, combined with a deck size of 40 and the replace mechanic, make decks consistent enough to feel like you can find the cards you need when you need them.-Daily challenges force you to think about unit interactions, and reward you for completing them.-Gauntlet allows you to draft a deck by choosing 1 of three randomly chosen cards of a given rarity, 30 times. You play until you either get 12 wins (the max) or 3 losses. You only need 7 wins to get a ticket for a free Gauntlet run, so going infinite is fairly easy once you have experience.However, not every game is perfect.-Devs have not been as transparent as they should have been. The past few updates have had changes that negatively impacted players gold income as well as nerfed rarity rates in the expansion orbs.-Newly added cards are "raising the bar" and causing some power creep. When playing against optimized decks in higher ranks, you can find yourself in "Answer this or die" situations several turns in a row.-Cosmetics are fairly expensive in real-world currency. Thankfully, they are ONLY cosmetic and do not affect the game. On top of that, you can craft the cosmetics you want by destroying cards you don't want for in-game currency.-Game is laggy on old rigs. Even some newer rigs can struggle at times.-Managing decklists is painful. There is no officially supported API, and no official way to import/export decklists. One player has created scripts to do this, but this should be officially supported and not require the community to fix.Overall, there is too much to say in one post. The game is great and well worth giving a try. For a short time, Humble Bundle is giving out free codes to brand new players for 20 free orbs and a free legendary. So there's no better time than now to give it a shot. There are some things that need to be addressed, but few games are perfect. This one comes pretty close to it though.Overall: 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Perhaps the most important thing to say about Duelyst is that it is NOT just a card game.Duelyst does something that very few other games do with the CCG genre: it mixes it with other genres. It takes as a base the core mechanics of card games such as Hearthstone, but combines them with that of Turn-Based Strategy; in the end, it plays as a hybrid of a game like Hearthstone and Fire Emblem.It is also a consistent card game. Each deck has 40 cards, but every single turn you can choose to replace one card in your hand, challenging you to more accurately know your deck and what could be useful in the situation you are in. It also helps to reduce the chances of not being able to play something, such as mulliganing high-cost cards in Hearthstone or being manastarved/manaflooded in Magic: The Gathering. Random effects are few and far between, with most of them being very predictable.Due to the nature of the playing field and how minions and your General move, the game also has open to it many unique keywords as well as more impactful iterations of keywords devised in other games - many of which place great importance on proper positioning. For example, there is Frenzy, which causes a minion to deal its damage to all enemies around it when it attacks - alongside Provoke (All enemy minions around this cannot move or attack anything but this minion) it is perfect for punishing your opponent when he bunches up his minions. There are also keywords that offer greater mobility - such as Airdrop, which allows you to summon a minion anywhere on the map, or Flying, which lets a minion move anywhere before attacking - as well as ones that have no real analogues to other card games, like the faction-specific Zeal (The minion gains a special effect, such as +2 attack or self-healing, when it is next to your General) or Backstab (Deals extra damage equal to the backstab number and takes no counterattack damage - but only if it attacks from behind).Duelyst is also surprisingly easy to play on a budget; it is entirely possible (and surprisingly common) to be able to get past Silver division (Ranks 20-10) using only what you first start the game with, though once in Gold (Ranks 10-5), most players begin to grind to a halt. This is because, in Duelyst, you may have 3 copies of any one card in your deck - including legendary spells, artifacts and minions. This is balanced out by the fact that Legendaries are only worth 900 Spirit (Think Dust from Hearthstone), which is a paltry sum compared to those of other card games. Regardless, once in Gold and beyond, it becomes incredibly hard to progress without certain Epics and Legendaries; how many will be required depends on your own skill as well as the faction you play as. Thankfully, however, the game is very generous with the in-game currency, and as such, by the time you get to Gold, you should have enough of a card collection to be able to adjust your deck to survive in higher ranks.All in all, Duelyst is a card game that is more than a card game and hinges greatly on one's skill in positioning and knowledge of what your enemy can bring to the field, rather than luck. It has a kind community, diligent developers and great skill ceiling. If you enjoy card games such as Hearthstone, but end up frustrated with them due to their lack of depth and poor game balance, I would suggest trying Duelyst.Oh yeah, and if you didn't look at the images and videos of it, the art and animations are gorgeous and the soundtrack is really good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												                       Duelyst is a digital CCG with more tiny, important decisions than any card game I’ve played before. Matches play out on a five-by-nine board that starts with just you and your opponent’s general. Each general has 2 attack, 25 health, and a unique Bloodborn Spell. Like most other CCGs that take their inspiration from Magic: The Gathering, you draw cards from a custom built deck, play spells, and summon minions until you’ve killed the opposing general.                         The bones of the game feel comfortable and familiar, but adding a board and movement makes a staggering difference. Because you can only summon minions in squares adjacent to friendly units, and most units only move two squares per turn, small choices on the first turn of the game—where to step or where to summon—will affect turns all the way to the end of the match.                          Simple to get into for both Veteran and new players, Personaly I've recomended this game to seasonal hearthstone players and friends alike. A whole lot of fun.-10/10 TheRealMuertitos

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Duelyst is a free-to-play collectible card game and turn-based strategy hybrid developed by Counterplay games. Pros:1) Nicely done pixel art, animations are fluid2) Tactical gameplay makes minion positioning just as important as what card to play.3) Generous giving of Epics and Legendaries. You can open 1 legendary in 2 packs in a row even if you just open 1 pack per day. Allows for lots of Spirit for crafting the better cards. 4) Quest allow even beginning players to get gold just by playing and not requiring you to always win. Gold is gained faster if you win of course. 5) Has decent Basic removal, dispel and displacement cards for the neutral and Faction set meaning even if your opponent has a better card you can still have some chance to save yourself. 6) 6 Factions each with a unique playstyle and mechanics. Each faction has a General with an ability called a bloodborn spell that that has a 2 turn cooldown after use until the late game where its reduced to every turn. Each faction has 2 general each with their own bloodborn spell allowing for a preferred playstyle.7) All consmetics can be crafted from spirit. Cons: 1) Lack of a casual mode means that you can only play ladder which can be bad after a certain point for new players as you can get matched up with more experianced players who have more effective and synergistic cards. 2) Keys for Crates can only be bought with real money luckily these contain mostly cosmetics that you can craft with Spirit. Conclusion: Duelyst is a free to play tactical turn based collecting card game with lots of depth and strategy. A decent chance to get higher rarity cards such as legendaries (around every 4 packs or so from the core set and every 6 packs from the expansion) allow even one pack opening per day to yield a decent collection after about 2 wks to a month. I recommend this game to anyone looking for a different take in the CCG genre.

												I have enjoyed this game very much so far. The pixel art is absolutley amazing and the animation is very fluid. The game is similar to hearthstone and magic this is actually a good point. Meaning the game is easy to pick up. There is also a mechanic which enables the player to replace a card in your hand with another random card in your deck, this helps combat the RNG mechanics of virtually every card game. Also the blend of cards and a board is very well done in this game. Finally card packs are easy to gather through minor play time. P2W aspects are still there but someone who hasent payed a dollar can easily compete with someone who has. For a free game it is amazing and gives you that satisfying feeling when you outsmart your opponent and snag the win. 9/10 would play again.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												This is my favorite strategy game for a good few years, probably a decade. It's also the best DTCG i've ever played, and i've played nearly all of them. I played paper MTG from Ice Age til about 2010, and played MTGO, hearthstone, Infinity Wars, Scrolls, and more others than I can remember. I've also played lots of 4X, and as many tactical RPG's as I could find.NOTHING, repeat NOTHING has ever came close to scratching the itch of deck building AND grid based tactcs as this game.This game, so rich, such depth of tactical aproaches. Yes there's a meta, but there is a constant stream of new cards, not to mention expansions, and there are so many cards and factions that you can quite easily construct your own viable decklists and concepts, even based around strange concepts. The game in play is a lot like a game of chess, albeit one with 900 possible pieces. Order of play, piece / card placement is paramount, and you can, once get good at the game, go toe to toe with most decks.This is a keeper.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Fantastic game. Basically chess where everyone (collects and) chooses a custom set of pieces. Faster than chess though and with much more variety.I've been quite obsessed with this game. Pro and cons:+ Matches are challenging; a lot of tactical considerations need to be made constantly. A replay function helps to review and learn from mistakes.+ Six factions with many many possible styles and archetypes to play.+ Little randomness.+ Deck building is challenging and fun, can also be skipped by simply copying a deck from the internet.+ Very fair free-to-play model (to be honest I actually invested money. 10$). You can get quite far without investing any money. By doing quests you can get about one card pack each day with good drop rates of rare cards.+ Very helpful community, close to zero abusive behavior.+ The match-making system works very well, matches are found quickly.+ Well-done tutorial.+ Gorgeous pixel art and sound/music.+ The developers maintain the game actively and listen to community feedback.+ For parents: can be played with only one hand (touchpad or mouse). Being away from keyboard for a minute if real-life calls is usually ok. Matches are usually fast (5-10min).+ Good interface in-match.- Very little single-player content.- Quite demanding for a pixel art game (<30 FPS on my laptop with Intel HD Graphics first generation, but doing fine on later generations), however for most people that won't be an issue I guess.- Awkward interface in deck building / card pool management.- Very little statistics, but there are some community mods for that.For veterans from Magic the Gathering:+ Forget all problems involving mana. Here you get mana for free; each round your pool increases. One less random factor to care about, but definitely doesn't make the game trivial as there are ways to manipulate the mana curve.+ Much less worrying about picking a good hand, because you get to mulligan two cards at the beginning (while seeing who your opponent will be, allowing strategic decisions already), and you can replace a card for free every turn (guaranteed not drawing the same card)!+ There's a proper board which leads to more tactical depth.+ A match is quickly found.- Obviously not as many cards as MtG, but that's the same for most CCGs out there.Lastly, especially if this guide helped you, you may use zypsilon as a referral code and we both profit!

												I routinely play this game.  I'm playing the game as I write this review.    It's awesome.  All the packs.  I'm an RNG junkie.  I play every day for the packs.  The pixel art is nice too. They update the game twice a month with new features, bug fixes and usually four new cards.  Sets come every one in a while.  Rewards pop up way more frequently than hearthstone.  Wait times for games are about 10 seconds.  The game is a turn based strategy board game.  You move your cards on 9 x 5 board and try to kill the guys 25 life.  Pretty standard fare.  There's a tutorial at the beginning of the game.  The game is fun.  I've been playing for around six months though the steam numbers may say otherwise.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												Not sure why this game is getting so many bad reviews. At low levels, you can easily progress using basic (free) cards, and you can get a decent way into the higher ranks having crafted a few staple common (cheap) cards. The grinding in this game is considerably less than in literally any other F2P game I've played in the last two years.Regular updates. Complex, satisfying gameplay. True, some factions are currently more prevalent than others, but CPG actively balances the most powerful cards to make sure that the meta doesn't stay fixed from month to month. Crazy weird synergies can be found anywhere.Example: let's take the powerful dinosaur man faction, throw in spell cards which deal damage to summon minions at lower cost, then include minions which spawn other minions/deal AOE damage/deal damage directly to their General/etc, and we have one crazily powerful deck with 100% more green lizard men./r/duelyst is a great place to go for links to all the guides, starting out tips, FAQs and miscellaneous chat about the game. Give the game a try and have fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												It is very similar to Hearthstone and yet the differencies are enough to take it as a whole new game. The chess board you play on brings a new level of depth with new or modified card effects adapted to make you care about positionning. You can also add the fact that : - you can replace one card of your hand per turn,- your hero can trade every turn and strike back every time a minion attacks him,- his hero power (called BBS here) is a very strong but limited ressource at first,- the RNG part of the game is very minor compared to HSAll these differences change considerably the dynamic of the game and I would say the game has a very high skillcap.Its community is also growing regularly and I would say the game is more beginner-friendly than HS with all the challenges created to teach you the basics. I have to add that, while the decks can hold 3 of the same legendary, the drop rate of rare+ cards in each pack in way higher than it is in HS so you'll have no problem building good decks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												i've tried pretty much all the F2P collectible card games on steam, (and blizzard's hearthstone) and duelyst by far is the only one i play.the other CCGs didn't capture me for either of these reasons: -very high skill ceiling, too much of a grind to get cards, not enough players, too generic, p2w, too much RNG involved. but lets talk about duelyst.-6 factions, each faction has 2 different 'general's, or heros.  so you choose a faction, then 1 of the 2 general, then build up your deck with a mix of faction specific cards and neutral cards.  nothing really different from other CCGs except that it is played on a grid.  go see a youtube vid on the gameplay; easier to see it in motion.  -very generous in gaining ingame currency to be able to get more cards.  i never felt i had to use real money since the daily quests give you lots of ingame currency, especially if you compare them to other CCGs-most of the legendary cards are either very situational, or they only really fit into a particular faction's synergy.  so don't be thinking that just because you are a new player and lack legendary cards, that you are fighting an uphill battle.  -you are ranked (obviously), and majority of time only play within your ranking, from lowest to highest is bronze, silver, gold, diamond, and finally S-rank.   season restarts every month.  depending on the high rank you achieved, you will get a reward based on it.  once you reach a new rank, you can't go down to the lower rank.  your rank is account based; not faction based.   along with the generous ingame currency rewards, i feel like the difficulty, or skill ceiling is just right, at least for me.  not so complex that it turns me off, but also not so casually easy and RNG based. no matter the time of day/night, you will wait no longer than 30 seconds to get a match.  the playerbase is small , but its solid.  the average waiting time for me is 10 seconds.  of course it can be frustrating reach a new rank and then just lose after lose.  but the official dueylst forum is filled w/helpful people, and the devs do chat on the forums.   its F2P, and i believe it will be coming on mobile, xbox 1, and PS4 in the near future.

												My credentials:-Made it into S-rank, the top tier on the ladder.-12 win run in Gauntlet (the max).-Been playing about 8 months-Spent about $50 on the game.So what is Duelyst? Duelyst is a free-to-play CCG that uses a 5x9 board top play cards on. Each player has a general with 25HP and 2 ATK. Each unit can move 2 squares, and then attack (this includes generals, as they are units too). Each general belongs to a faction and has a unique "Bloodborne Spell", which refreshes at set intervals and doesn't cost a card. Your deck will consist of cards that are exclusive to your faction and the "Neutral" cards, which everyone can run. To get cards, you buy "Orbs" (aka packs of cards) with gold, the ingame currency. The resource system consists of a mana pool that grows each turn, and tiles on the board that act as "get +1 mana this turn" if you have a friendly unit walk over them. You draw one card each turn, and have the option to replace one card you dont want from your hand each turn, and you are guaranteed to not get the same card back.Why do I mention the replace mechanic specifically? Because the replace mechanic, along with the board, really set Duelyst apart from other CCGs. Since card games rely on Random Number Generators (or RNG) to create variance and make games play out differently, there will be times that you flat out lose due to simple chance. That is the nature of RNG. Duelyst's replace mechanic helps to minimize this as much as possible- if a card doesn't help you, throw it away and get a new one! Top-decking is less frustrating just because of that feature.As for the gameplay, it's awesome.-Games are relatively fast-paced-Every faction is viable at the highest levels (some generals are not as much, but you get the choice of 2 generals per faction)-Several different viable deck types-New players can, with enough skill, make it surprisingly high on the ladder without any investment.-Three copies of any given card, combined with a deck size of 40 and the replace mechanic, make decks consistent enough to feel like you can find the cards you need when you need them.-Daily challenges force you to think about unit interactions, and reward you for completing them.-Gauntlet allows you to draft a deck by choosing 1 of three randomly chosen cards of a given rarity, 30 times. You play until you either get 12 wins (the max) or 3 losses. You only need 7 wins to get a ticket for a free Gauntlet run, so going infinite is fairly easy once you have experience.However, not every game is perfect.-Devs have not been as transparent as they should have been. The past few updates have had changes that negatively impacted players gold income as well as nerfed rarity rates in the expansion orbs.-Newly added cards are "raising the bar" and causing some power creep. When playing against optimized decks in higher ranks, you can find yourself in "Answer this or die" situations several turns in a row.-Cosmetics are fairly expensive in real-world currency. Thankfully, they are ONLY cosmetic and do not affect the game. On top of that, you can craft the cosmetics you want by destroying cards you don't want for in-game currency.-Game is laggy on old rigs. Even some newer rigs can struggle at times.-Managing decklists is painful. There is no officially supported API, and no official way to import/export decklists. One player has created scripts to do this, but this should be officially supported and not require the community to fix.Overall, there is too much to say in one post. The game is great and well worth giving a try. For a short time, Humble Bundle is giving out free codes to brand new players for 20 free orbs and a free legendary. So there's no better time than now to give it a shot. There are some things that need to be addressed, but few games are perfect. This one comes pretty close to it though.Overall: 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Perhaps the most important thing to say about Duelyst is that it is NOT just a card game.Duelyst does something that very few other games do with the CCG genre: it mixes it with other genres. It takes as a base the core mechanics of card games such as Hearthstone, but combines them with that of Turn-Based Strategy; in the end, it plays as a hybrid of a game like Hearthstone and Fire Emblem.It is also a consistent card game. Each deck has 40 cards, but every single turn you can choose to replace one card in your hand, challenging you to more accurately know your deck and what could be useful in the situation you are in. It also helps to reduce the chances of not being able to play something, such as mulliganing high-cost cards in Hearthstone or being manastarved/manaflooded in Magic: The Gathering. Random effects are few and far between, with most of them being very predictable.Due to the nature of the playing field and how minions and your General move, the game also has open to it many unique keywords as well as more impactful iterations of keywords devised in other games - many of which place great importance on proper positioning. For example, there is Frenzy, which causes a minion to deal its damage to all enemies around it when it attacks - alongside Provoke (All enemy minions around this cannot move or attack anything but this minion) it is perfect for punishing your opponent when he bunches up his minions. There are also keywords that offer greater mobility - such as Airdrop, which allows you to summon a minion anywhere on the map, or Flying, which lets a minion move anywhere before attacking - as well as ones that have no real analogues to other card games, like the faction-specific Zeal (The minion gains a special effect, such as +2 attack or self-healing, when it is next to your General) or Backstab (Deals extra damage equal to the backstab number and takes no counterattack damage - but only if it attacks from behind).Duelyst is also surprisingly easy to play on a budget; it is entirely possible (and surprisingly common) to be able to get past Silver division (Ranks 20-10) using only what you first start the game with, though once in Gold (Ranks 10-5), most players begin to grind to a halt. This is because, in Duelyst, you may have 3 copies of any one card in your deck - including legendary spells, artifacts and minions. This is balanced out by the fact that Legendaries are only worth 900 Spirit (Think Dust from Hearthstone), which is a paltry sum compared to those of other card games. Regardless, once in Gold and beyond, it becomes incredibly hard to progress without certain Epics and Legendaries; how many will be required depends on your own skill as well as the faction you play as. Thankfully, however, the game is very generous with the in-game currency, and as such, by the time you get to Gold, you should have enough of a card collection to be able to adjust your deck to survive in higher ranks.All in all, Duelyst is a card game that is more than a card game and hinges greatly on one's skill in positioning and knowledge of what your enemy can bring to the field, rather than luck. It has a kind community, diligent developers and great skill ceiling. If you enjoy card games such as Hearthstone, but end up frustrated with them due to their lack of depth and poor game balance, I would suggest trying Duelyst.Oh yeah, and if you didn't look at the images and videos of it, the art and animations are gorgeous and the soundtrack is really good.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												I'm just saying again, as others have said, that there is a solid amount of potential here in its presentation and gameplay, but the price of the paid content is just too high.  On the plus side, the sprite art is impressive, the combination of card game and strategy RPG mechanics is deep and engaging, there is a great amount of variety in the factions and units available, and the length of each match is just right.  But if the paid content remains so expensive, I just foresee the game becoming either too expensive to support itself on the income it makes from the paying community or becoming truly pay to win in order to provide incentives for more people to pay that price.  Neither option is particularly appealing.  That said, I do still recommend people at least try it because the game itself may be worth that price to some.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												Not sure why this game is getting so many bad reviews. At low levels, you can easily progress using basic (free) cards, and you can get a decent way into the higher ranks having crafted a few staple common (cheap) cards. The grinding in this game is considerably less than in literally any other F2P game I've played in the last two years.Regular updates. Complex, satisfying gameplay. True, some factions are currently more prevalent than others, but CPG actively balances the most powerful cards to make sure that the meta doesn't stay fixed from month to month. Crazy weird synergies can be found anywhere.Example: let's take the powerful dinosaur man faction, throw in spell cards which deal damage to summon minions at lower cost, then include minions which spawn other minions/deal AOE damage/deal damage directly to their General/etc, and we have one crazily powerful deck with 100% more green lizard men./r/duelyst is a great place to go for links to all the guides, starting out tips, FAQs and miscellaneous chat about the game. Give the game a try and have fun!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Duelyst is a F2P strategy card game. It is one that is easy to learn, but hard to master. Imagine Hearthstone but the "board" is instead a large grid. Each players general starts with 2 attack and 25 health. First player to get the enemy general down to 0 health wins.Things get interesting however when players can summon minions to fight alongside them and each general can use spells. Duelyst covers nearly every playstyle including aggressive players who like running up and smashing their enemies (Magmar), players who want to zerg rush their enemy (Abyssian), players who excel at playing tactically and focusing on positioning (Songhai) and much more.It's not very p2w, as powerful legendary cards often are not a requirement until you get into the very top of the playerbase and many players have gotten to the top ranks using only basic cards/decks.It's a great game any card game/strategy fan should give a try.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												So take Hearthstone, and give it a tactical layer. That's basically Duelyst, where positioning is king alongside good cardplay and overall strategy. Add top notch pixel-art animations and overall art direction, this is a game I have unhesitantly paid money towards - and will when budget allows and they continue to keep my goodwill. With 5 factions to choose from and 2 Generals each with their own abilities, there are plenty of niches to play Duelyst with.It also helps there's less RNG apart from your card draw, and even that is ameliorated by the fact you can Replace - basically cyce one card out back into your deck for another, which helps when you have a bad draw. RNG is predominantly in random summoning placement which can make or make some plays, as well as some Mythic/Legendaries with unique abilities.Their microtransaction model is again like Hearthstone, buying packs and cosmetics with real money or earned "Spirit". While this game is not as generous as Eternal which has AI grinding to help you build your deck up, it makes sense not to do that since the current card pool is quite small, though as of writing we are a week away from another expansion.Overall, I strongly recommend Duelyst, with its slick presentation and very solid mechanics, makes for very compelling games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 30
												Wow, where to start with this game. First off it's one of the best strategy collectible card games I've played in the last couple of years, and I've done my duty to properly vet all the ones that come out. As an ex PoxNora player I was particularly attracted to the use of a board and the skill that goes into any game using those features, on top of that the game is very fast paced, with my quickest match ending in a win within three minutes and my longest being only ten minutes long!Like any collectible card game you may get the thought that it is very "pay to win" at first, I sure did when I watched a couple S-Rank matches and saw the use of legendary/epic rarity cards to be extremely heavy. But the use of the crafting system quickly allowed me to almost mimic some of the top tier decks I observed within TWO days of playing, by disenchanting legendary cards I got from factions I didn't play I was quickly able to obtain rare and legendary cards that directly aided in my main decks win condition.After playing for only two days (6 hours) I have come to the conclusion this is the game I've been waiting for. Heck sometimes I can manage to pull off a win using only faction leveling cards (free cards given just for practicing and leveling a faction before jumping into ranked) and common cards, this is very rare in any card game nowadays, just because I use strategy and unit placement that the use of a board gives.If you've been waiting for a gem of a collectible card game that can be more fun than even Hearthstone, MTG, or Shadowverse. Hit the download button NOW!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 15
												Although im not card games aficionado, i did test couple of card games, and none of those games managed to impress me as this one.This game is played in an unique way, actually, it isnt just a card game, your cards are monsters which you move around the 9x5 chessboard map. This being said, this game can be considered as a turn based strategy and card game mix. Goal of the game is to kill the general, which acts as a main monster of each player in the game. It has very nice clean and smooth pixel art style which really stands out, and talking about complexity of the game, you can do some card combos even, but its nothing too complex so even new players can get into it easily. Currently there are 6 different factions and around 100 different cards. Each faction has special cards and you must have cards from only 1 faction in deck. However there is card group called "Neutral" which are cards that you can use with any faction. There is even lore about game and factions that you can listen to (small audiobook) in game.Game features competitive mode with 30 different ranks and there are daily quests. You even get reward after every season (1 month) depending on your rank, and sometimes there are unique monthly quest rewards.It does of course have problems too, main one is that it is grindy, and it could use more modes Pros:- Unique mix between card games and turn based strategy games- Competitive game mode with 30 ranks and rewards- Game has some depth but its not too complicated for new players- 6 different factions with unique playstyles and over 100 cards - Beautiful and clean pixel art- You can gain all the cards in game for free, and there are some emotes too- Emotes, card backs, skins for certain monsters- Special gauntlet mode where you use random cards instead of your own deck- Daily quests and events with unique rewards from time to time- Practice mode and i think game also has tutorial (cant recall)- Good music and sounds- Lore about factions in a form of audiobook- Steam achievements- Game is alive, there are players playing itNeutral:- This game doesnt actually have chat besides whispers you can use after you add someone as friend. Instead, you can use emoticons and four preset messages during the match. This helps alot to reduce the toxicity of playerbase, however we dont know if the playerbase is actually toxic. Chat system might've been done like this to make profit off of emotes.Cons:- It feels grindy. Newest card pack requires you to play alot in order to fully unlock it. One of the main problems about this is that players who pay will gain serious advantage, especially when the update with new cards hit, until the rest of players earn the cards. Although it is extremely annoying, i respect this because they have to earn somehow from the game and they still let us earn all cards for free which makes the game non p2w- Could use more game modes, or more different maps maybe. If possible, i'd really like to see 2v2, or even more players in one match- No guilds or chat while in lobby- Still waiting for mobile version- Factions can feel unbalanced at certain times

												Magic: The Gathering meets Chess.That's how I heard about, and that's kind of how it is. A CCG with a board, where positioning is one of the most important aspects of the match (unless you're ♥♥♥♥ing Songhai). The crafting system is really fair, and there is a bunch of powerful cards of common rarity.The monthly season system is very fair and it gives rewards in the form of new cards at the end of it, the rewards is based on your highest position in the month (also you cannot drop Divisions, like S Rank, Platinum, Gold and Silver) once you obtained it. Two monthly patches as well!The pixel art seems to be a hit or miss, some people hate it, and some people love it (I find it astonishing well made)

												I'm just saying again, as others have said, that there is a solid amount of potential here in its presentation and gameplay, but the price of the paid content is just too high.  On the plus side, the sprite art is impressive, the combination of card game and strategy RPG mechanics is deep and engaging, there is a great amount of variety in the factions and units available, and the length of each match is just right.  But if the paid content remains so expensive, I just foresee the game becoming either too expensive to support itself on the income it makes from the paying community or becoming truly pay to win in order to provide incentives for more people to pay that price.  Neither option is particularly appealing.  That said, I do still recommend people at least try it because the game itself may be worth that price to some.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												Not sure why this game is getting so many bad reviews. At low levels, you can easily progress using basic (free) cards, and you can get a decent way into the higher ranks having crafted a few staple common (cheap) cards. The grinding in this game is considerably less than in literally any other F2P game I've played in the last two years.Regular updates. Complex, satisfying gameplay. True, some factions are currently more prevalent than others, but CPG actively balances the most powerful cards to make sure that the meta doesn't stay fixed from month to month. Crazy weird synergies can be found anywhere.Example: let's take the powerful dinosaur man faction, throw in spell cards which deal damage to summon minions at lower cost, then include minions which spawn other minions/deal AOE damage/deal damage directly to their General/etc, and we have one crazily powerful deck with 100% more green lizard men./r/duelyst is a great place to go for links to all the guides, starting out tips, FAQs and miscellaneous chat about the game. Give the game a try and have fun!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												I love CCGs (Collective Card Games) but my favourite so far is Duelyst without a doubt. This game is like a combination of an online card game(like Hearthstone) and a tactical turn-based rpg (like Fire Emblem or Final Fantasy Tactics), so if you like those type of games you are going to love this one.The best things about this game:Easy to learnEasy to understand mechanics Really fun and fast-pacedEvery play you make requires a lot of thought as positioning matters a lot in this gameLess RNG ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t than other online card gamesHigh gold income from quests and victoriesEasy to get rare cards from packsYou don`t need to spend money or grind a lot to get a decent and competitive deckYou may struggle at first but once you know how the game works, the key cards for each faction and how to position your units properly you'll rank up in the ladder easily.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Positives:I've had my backside handed to me by decks made using only common and rare (read: uncommon) cards. And it had nothing to do with luck either. They were just good. Very well balanced with the exception of a few odd cards, but the developers stay on top of everything and release nerfs and buffs quickly when needed. Grid based gameplay makes so much sense for the extremely Hearthstone-esque style. Every game feels like at least 80-90% skill as you think carefully about your positioning before each move, add up all the numbers, and try and deny your opponent the advantage.Much like a certain other card game, you have several factions all with unique playstyles and a choice of two generals that changes the way the deck plays. Some brief examples: Abyssians flood the board with puny minions or produce shadow creep that damages enemies when they stand on it. Lyonar have loads of bulky minions and support spells to face threats head-on and bog the opponent down under massive bodies. Songhai are the assassins that specialize in aggro tactics, ranged minions, and high damage combos. Magmar are a bunch of huge lizards who specialize in becoming unreasonably powerful if left unchecked.And here's the kicker: a lot of the paid stuff is really reasonable. If you can earn it with cash you can earn it in game and it never feels like you're climbing a mountain-sized progress bar for something that you could be forking out $2.99 for. If you do decide to spend some cash, you get pretty reasonable value too. I dropped $20 to support the publishers for a great game, and got (all up) 3 guranteed legendaries and 17 booster packs worth 5 cards each (one guranteed rare per pack). Better yet I did the math later and figured out that I could have got a better deal. Negatives:I love all the art personally, but almost everyone I've talked to seems to have a problem with either the hand-drawn stuff or the pixel art. Minor grievance but worth noting if you are bothered easily by art. The match announcer at the start is also a bit jarring and doesn't really mesh with the rest of the game. There are a few combos using mainly epic cards that can flatten newer decks, but that doesn't often happen in bronze and by the time you get to silver you should be armed to put up a good fight at the very least.As far as microtransactions go, the loot boxes you are sometimes given are the only really irksome part. The first one comes with a key but after that there doesn't seem to be any way to get more for free, and the highest level chest required $10 for a key. The chests contain guranteed high value cards and cool cosmetics (which can all be earned free anyway), but in my opinion they don't contain enough items to warrant their current pricetag. I've been letting my loot crates form a dusty pile in the corner for now, as I heard somewhere that a free source of keys is on the developers to do list.Overall:Great developer support, tactical gameplay, fairly well balanced. Mostly good monetization (the bad bits are easy to ignore and nothing is locked off to free players).

												I routinely play this game.  I'm playing the game as I write this review.    It's awesome.  All the packs.  I'm an RNG junkie.  I play every day for the packs.  The pixel art is nice too. They update the game twice a month with new features, bug fixes and usually four new cards.  Sets come every one in a while.  Rewards pop up way more frequently than hearthstone.  Wait times for games are about 10 seconds.  The game is a turn based strategy board game.  You move your cards on 9 x 5 board and try to kill the guys 25 life.  Pretty standard fare.  There's a tutorial at the beginning of the game.  The game is fun.  I've been playing for around six months though the steam numbers may say otherwise.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												To whom it may concern,I am a player who sees A LOT of potential in this game and I enjoy playing it a lot. In the past couple of months I have sent about 3 emails to the dev team but nobody has come back to me with a response yet. I have some suggestions that I believe will make the game a lot better. First, when I want to minimize the game window, the music of the game still plays in the background, and I really wish there was a button in the audio settings that allows players to turn off continuous music playing in the background so that it does not feel annoying sometimes that you just turn down the music volume completely. Moreover, I wish I could get some Spirits even if in little amounts from the Spirit Orbs so that disenchanting cards does not become the MAIN way of obtaining Spirits, make it easier for us to get the cards we want pretty please. And last but not least, this suggestion I have been DYING to get through to you guys because I really think it will make this game become more competitive and more user-friendly. Can you please bring Duelyst to the App Store and Google Play and build a scross-platform system just like Hearthstone? You guys have to trust the community's demands because you're not stripping away ANYTHING from this amazing game, but you're only ADDING more to what's already amazing! I know so many YouTubers who will MOST DEFINITELY play your game if it was on the App Store and Google play and I'll name some of them off the top of my head right now: Nickatnyte, GAMINGwithMOLT, BenTimm1 and phonecatss. All of them are very well-known YouTubers inside of their communities. Plus, I really badly wish I could play Duelyst wherever I go, and whenever I want. It is good to be powered by Steam, but if you take the risk and expand with the intention of conquering the market, you will succeed, because I assure you, I have searched the App Store and Google Play in hopes of finding a turn-based strategy game that was THIS good and I have found almost nothing that lived up to my own expectations as an average turn-based games' player (other than Hearthstone). Electronic Arts has released a card game just very recently called Plants vs Zombies: Heroes, and YouTubers instantly started streaming it on various streaming websites such as YouTube Gaming, Twitch, Kamcord and Azubu and it is running EA's business because these Streamers are apparently advertising their game for them. Bottomline, despite the fact that what I'm about to say is just MY opinion, but I really think that Duelyst offers something (in the turn-based genre) that Hearthstone does not have and will NOT have which is an actual gridded board for ACTUAL strategic positioning of each card, plus, EA's new game PvZ Heroes does not have what it takes to actually be primarily strategic rather than just pile up some good cards together and the better combo wins, because from what I have seen in streams and playing the game, that's how PvZ Heroes is for the most part. I am NOT here to dis on other games, but instead I feel like the Duelyst dev team is not trying to make this game more widely known and played on a very competitive level using the simplest way to make sure that ALL players will have access to it which is through the App Store and Google Play. I know some people who do NOT even have a PC, but they have multiple generations of tablets. And to clarify my point, I am not saying the game is bad on steam, but I am humbly asking of you to expand your platform coverage so that you could captivate people's hearths with this game, and I am only sending this to show you guys what you are capable of! No one cares if the game has superior pixels because I bet you guys are a group of gamers too and you KNOW that your game is epic and that this style of play will appeal to sooooo many people, all you have to do is take the risk and conquer! If you need more info or feedback I will be really happy to share whatever it is that I can suggest to make this game a lot better. And I am looking forward to hearing what you guys might think of this suggestion and I apologize for the long message but please do read it.- Blurreth

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												It is very similar to Hearthstone and yet the differencies are enough to take it as a whole new game. The chess board you play on brings a new level of depth with new or modified card effects adapted to make you care about positionning. You can also add the fact that : - you can replace one card of your hand per turn,- your hero can trade every turn and strike back every time a minion attacks him,- his hero power (called BBS here) is a very strong but limited ressource at first,- the RNG part of the game is very minor compared to HSAll these differences change considerably the dynamic of the game and I would say the game has a very high skillcap.Its community is also growing regularly and I would say the game is more beginner-friendly than HS with all the challenges created to teach you the basics. I have to add that, while the decks can hold 3 of the same legendary, the drop rate of rare+ cards in each pack in way higher than it is in HS so you'll have no problem building good decks.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Found this game through Humble Bundle a little over two months ago, and have played it since. I was a bit fed up with Hearthstone's overreliance on RNG, and though this game isn't perfect, it's got some good ideas. The visuals also happen to be amazing- each unit with its unique pixel art and animation, no corners cut. However, some of the audio could use some work, though I'm saying this mainly because I'm not a fan of the victory voiceover, as it feels like it clashes somewhat with the feel of the rest of the game. Considering this is a free-to-play game, I would highly suggest everyone to give it a try whether they have had previous turn-based/card game experience or not.There is a decent-sized community on Reddit already despite this game being fairly new, so beginners can easily find support for anything ranging from deck-builds to fanart.

content:

												I won't beat around the bush here: Duelyst is Hearthstone with a board. But the addition of the board makes such a difference. The element of positioning is so important that the skill ceiling is raised, and it is possible to play with a weaker deck than your opponent and out-play them on the board.The monthly balance changes are great for mixing up the meta too. Sure, you get a bunch of whining on the forums but I've been very happy with how they're approaching it.
